questions.text:
Which of the below statements are correct?
  1. A is present on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets
  2. B is present on APCs (Antigen-presenting cells)
  3. Alpha3 of A binds to CD4 on Tc cells
  4. The antigen presentation pathway of B is endocytic
  5. A presents exogenous antigens
questions.solution:
In the given question, A is MHC class I molecule, and B is MHC class II molecule. Statements 1,2,4 are correct.

Alpha3 of MHC class I molecule binds to CD8, not CD4. MHC class I molecules present endogenous or intracellular antigens(viral/tumor), not exogenous.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes, does not play a role in the production of reducing equivalents required for fatty acid synthesis and hydroxylation of aromatic compounds?
questions.solution:
NADPH is the reducing equivalents majorly required for fatty acid synthesis and hydroxylation of aromatic compounds. Mitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase produces NADH, it is the cytosolic isocitrate dehydrogenase that produces NADPH.

 This NADPH is derived from three sources:

  • HMP shunt pathway (main source) - It is a cytosol pathway. The enzymes producing NADPH in the HMP pathway are Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (Option C) and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase (Option D)
  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Cytosolic Malic enzyme (Option B)

questions.text: The condition in the given image is caused by the non-fusion of which of the following structures?

choices.text: Medial nasal prominence with lateral nasal prominence
Maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence
Maxillary prominence with lateral nasal prominence
Medial nasal prominence of both sides

questions.solution:
The image shows unilateral cleft lip which is due to the non-fusion of maxillary prominence with the medial nasal prominence.

The upper lip is formed by the fusion of two medial nasal prominences and the two maxillary prominences. The lateral nasal prominences do not participate in the formation of the upper lip.

The lower lip and jaw are formed by the mandibular prominences. Non-fusion of maxillary prominence with the lateral nasal prominence leads to oblique facial cleft, which usually causes exposure of the nasolacrimal duct.

Development of the nose:

  • The bridge is formed by the frontal prominence
  • Crest and tip by the merged medial prominences
  • Alae are formed by the lateral nasal prominences

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl was brought to the physician by her mother for an examination of her first menstrual period one week ago. Physical examination shows Tanner's stage 3 breast and pubic hair 
development.  Which of the following is the best next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution:
This 7-year-old girl presenting with early menarche and Tanner stage 3 breast and pubic hair development is concerning for precocious puberty. The best next step is to determine whether her development aligns with her chronological age by using bone age estimation.

Precocious puberty is the development of secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 years in girls and age 9 years in boys. It results from either early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis (central precocious puberty) or excess sex hormone production from peripheral sources (peripheral precocious puberty). Early puberty can lead to rapid growth and early bone maturation, potentially causing short adult stature due to the premature closure of growth plates.

The best initial step is bone age estimation, determining whether her skeletal maturation is advanced for her chronological age. If bone age is advanced, further hormonal tests (LH/FSH levels) and imaging can distinguish between central and peripheral causes.

  • Central precocious puberty (increase in GnRH) is often idiopathic but can also result from brain tumors (hamartomas, astrocytomas, pinealomas).
  • Peripheral precocious puberty (GnRH-independent) arises from excess sex hormone production due to conditions like granulosa cell tumors, congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), or McCune-Albright syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: TSH Level: Hypothyroidism rarely causes precocious puberty (via TSH activation of FSH receptors), but bone age should be checked first.

Option B: Pelvic ultrasound is useful after bone age estimation if a peripheral cause (e.g., ovarian/adrenal tumor) is suspected.

Option C: Serum prolactin is used to evaluate galactorrhea or pituitary adenomas, which typically cause delayed puberty or amenorrhea, not precocious puberty.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound. The wound shows typical ‘swallow tails’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and a closer examination shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as:
questions.solution:
The characteristics described are consistent with that of a lacerated wound.

In a lacerated wound, the margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails.

The edges of the laceration may indicate the direction in which the blow or force was applied. The depth of the wound shows bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels, and nerves and can be soiled by mud, sand, glass, brick particles, vegetation, machine oils, hair, or fibres. These materials embedded in the wound are of great medicolegal value.

Lacerated wounds do not bleed much as the vessels are crushed and torn, thus facilitating hemostasis. The exception to this is injuries to the scalp, where temporal arteries may bleed freely as they are firmly bound and unable to contract. Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed and buried into the depth of the wound. Because of the crushing and tearing nature of the production of lacerations, there can be associated abrasion or bruising.

Swallow tail in a lacerated wound is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A- An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width. The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is higher at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

Option B- Chop wounds or slash wounds are the wounds produced by chopping motion, made with heavy and sharp weapons like axe, cleave, etc. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound.

The image below shows a chop wound.

Option C- A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc, into the depth of the body. 

The margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade. The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface. The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc. The shape of the wound is usually triangular or wedge-shaped. Depending on the type of instrument used, one side of the wound may be sharp, while another side may be blunt. The blunt side may show small splits at each corner, called fishtailing. 

Below is the image showing the fish-tail appearance of stab wounds.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, increased frequency of micturition, and pain during sex that extends to the vulva and vagina. The pain increases when the bladder is full. Cystoscopy shows fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa as shown in the image below and marked submucosal edema of the bladder. Biopsy reveals mucosal ulceration and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Interstitial cystitis is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women presenting as intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria. Hunner ulcers are characteristic ulcers seen in interstitial cystitis. It is characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration, seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis.

Cystoscopic findings show fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) in the bladder mucosa. Microscopically, mucosal ulceration is covered by fibrin, necrotic material, and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. The pathologic findings are nonspecific, and the main role of biopsy is to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may mimic interstitial cystitis clinically. Late in the course, transmural fibrosis may appear, leading to a contracted bladder.

Other options:

Option A: Malakoplakia is an inflammatory reaction caused by defects in phagocyte function. It occurs during chronic bacterial infections. On cystoscopy, it appears as soft, yellow, raised mucosal plaques 3-4cm in diameter with large aggregates of foamy macrophages.

Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder or urothelial neoplasms are the most common bladder tumors. Morphological variants include papillary, nodular, or flat lesions. 

Option C: Follicular cystitis is characterized by multiple lymphoid follicles in the bladder mucosa or underlying wall.

questions.text: An 18-year-old student presents for ophthalmic evaluation due to the findings shown in the below image. The patient is very tall, with long limbs and long, slender, spiderlike fingers. Slit-lamp examination in this patient reveals bilateral ectopia lentis. What is the usual site of lens subluxation in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with blue sclera as shown in the image along with long limbs, tall height, and slender fingers with ectopia lentis is likely to have Marfan's syndrome. In Marfan's syndrome, ectopia lentis is usually superotemporal.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. It involves a mutation in the fibrillin 1 gene (FBN1). It has classic cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal abnormalities. 

The most common ocular change in Marfan syndrome is bilateral ectopia lentis, seen in 80% of patients. Ectopia lentis is a hereditary or acquired displacement of the lens from its normal position. It may be partially or fully displaced. In Marfan syndrome, it is usually a superotemporal subluxation. The zonules are intact so accommodation is not affected. However, in severe cases, the lens may also dislocate into the anterior chamber or the vitreous. 

Other causes of ectopia lentis are as follows: 

Acquired: 

  • Trauma
  • Pseudoexfoliation
  • Inflammation
  • Hypermature cataract
  • Large eye due to myopia or buphthalmos
  • Anterior uveal tumors

Without systemic associations: 

  • Familial ectopia lentis
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae
  • Aniridia

With systemic associations:

  • Marfan syndrome
  • Homocystinuria - inferonasal
  • Weill-Marchesani syndrome - inferior subluxation

Other ocular manifestations of Marfan syndrome are glaucoma due to angle anomaly, lattice retinal degeneration and detachment, hypoplasia of the dilator pupillae. 

The most characteristic cardiac abnormality is aortic root dilation, which leads to regurgitation, aneurysmal dilation, and dissection, which is a cause of mortality. Mitral valve prolapse can also occur. There is also excessive linear growth of long bones leading to long extremities in proportion to the trunk. They also have joint laxity and scoliosis. 

Blue sclera is also seen in osteogenesis imperfecta, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan's syndrome, and pseudoxanthoma elasticum.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors help to signal the degree of joint rotation?
questions.solution:
The sensory receptor found in joint capsules and helps signal the degree of joint rotation are Ruffini's endings/Ruffini's end organ.

Ruffini's end organs are a type of slow-adapting receptor. They are located in the deep layers of skin and other internal tissues. They play a crucial role in signaling states where tissue deformation is continuous. These include deep touch which is prolonged and pressure signals. They are present in joint capsules as well and help in signaling the degree of joint rotation.

Other options:

Option A: Merkel discs are a type of expanded tip tactile receptors that cause the epithelium of the skin to bulge out creating a dome and are highly sensitive. They are hence grouped with touch domes. They play an important role in point discrimination, point localization, and determination of texture along with Meissner's corpuscles.

Option B: Meissner’s Corpuscles: They are encapsulated receptors found in the dermis of the non-hairy skin, most commonly on the fingertips, lips, and other locations where tactile discrimination is very good. Their field of reception is very small and hence used for two-point discrimination. These are rapidly adapting receptors that encode Point discrimination, Precise location, Tapping, and Flutter.

Option C: Krause corpuscles are specialized sensory structures found within the genitalia and other mucocutaneous tissues and have been known to aid in thermal sensation. Recently, they have been shown to play a role in sexual behaviors in mice.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: The below histopathological finding was obtained from a sigmoidoscopy-assisted biopsy in a patient with dysentery. Additionally, freshly passed stool was studied under the microscope to identify the pathogen. Which of the following microscopy features  will be seen in the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The microscopy feature of RBC in food vacuoles is seen in the causative organism. The given histopathological image shows flask-shaped ulcers typical of Entamoeba histolytica. RBCs in the food vacuoles are seen in trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica.

Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite responsible for amoebic dysentery. Its definitive host is man. There are no intermediate hosts. The parasite’s infective form is the quadrinucleate cyst, which is passed in the feces and ingested via contaminated food and water. The cyst enters the small intestine and undergoes excystation by the action of trypsin.

One quadrinucleate cyst gives rise to 8 daughter amoebae, which reach the large intestine and reside in the colonic epithelium, where they produce histolysins and other cytolytic enzymes that break down the colonic mucosa, giving rise to flask-shaped ulcers. Identification of the trophozoite in freshly passed stool is the microscopic gold standard for diagnosis of active infection. Both cysts and trophozoites may be isolated from the feces. The morphological features of each are given below:

  • Cyst: Refractile spherical wall. A mature quadrinucleate cyst contains 4 nuclei. Chromatoid bodies and glycogen granules are seen in uninucleate cysts. Staining with iodine for glycogen and Iron hematoxylin for the chromatoid body may be done.
  • Trophozoite: Seen in saline mount as a motile organism with finger-like pseudopodia, cytoplasm divided into clear ectoplasm and granular endoplasm, RBCs in food vacuoles, and a cartwheel-shaped nucleus.

RBCs in food vacuole are an important feature as it is not seen in nonpathogenic Entamoeba like E.dispar. Below are images of cysts and trophozoites of E. histolytica: 

Other options:

Option B: Falling leaf-like motility is seen in Giardia.

Option C: Cilia covering the whole body is seen in Balantidium coli. 

Option D: Oocyst is acid-fast in Cryptosporidium, Cystoisospora, and Cyclospora.

questions.text:
A young patient presented to the OPD with the inability to close one eyelid fully and drooling of saliva from the angle of the mouth for five days. On otoscopic examination, the below finding was seen in the tympanic membrane. A foul-smelling discharge is seen in the external auditory canal. The patient reports no ear pain. Which of the following management is appropriate?

1-Give antivirals+corticosteroids

2-Perform Myringoplasty

3-Send discharge for AFB/TB-PCR

4-Perform HRCT Temporal Bone

5-Perform Chest Xray and Sputum AFB
questions.solution:
The appropriate management is to perform a chest x-ray, sputum AFB, HRCT-temporal bone, and AFB/TB-PCR. 

The given clinical scenario depicts a young patient with features of facial nerve palsy and otoscopic examination findings of multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane along with foul-smelling ear discharge without otalgia. This is highly suggestive of tuberculous otitis media with facial nerve palsy, a common complication in children.

Tuberculous otitis media occurs secondary to a pulmonary infection. TB bacilli reach the middle ear through the Eustachian tube or from infective foci like cervical lymph nodes via the bloodstream. Caseating tubercles form in the middle ear and, over time, may cause extensive granulation and destruction of the architecture of the middle ear. Patients typically present with:

  • Painless, foul-smelling ear discharge
  • Multiple perforations in pars tensa of tympanic membrane
  • Pale granulations in the middle ear cleft
  • Hearing loss, usually conductive hearing loss( which may become mixed if the labyrinth is involved due to sensorineural component)
  • Facial palsy

Facial palsy may be the presenting complaint of TB otitis media, especially in children. TB causes bony destruction of the roof of the Fallopius canal, which houses the facial nerve, resulting in facial palsy.

Diagnosis of TB otitis media is done by AFB of the ear discharge, histopathology of the granulation tissue, or more recently, TB-PCR and DNA probe assays, which yield faster results. Further clinical correlation with Chest X-ray, Sputum AFB, etc, is done to confirm the diagnosis and identify the primary focus.

Complications like facial palsy, mastoiditis, osteomyelitis, etc, necessitate further evaluation with imaging modalities like HRCT Temporal bone to visualize the extent of bony destruction before deciding on management. In case there is only soft tissue swelling around the facial nerve, corticosteroids are given to reduce inflammation. In more severe cases, decompression surgery may be done.

Treatment of TB otitis media includes initiation of ATT (Anti-tubercular treatment).

Note:

Statement 1: Antivirals have no role in TB otitis media. However, they are combined with corticosteroids and given to patients with a suspected viral etiology of facial palsy. In this patient, the cause of facial palsy is not viral infection but otitis media.

Statement 2: Myringoplasty should never be performed in a wet ear(ear with active discharge). It is necessary to do an HRCT temporal bone to look for ossicular chain status as it may frequently undergo necrosis in TB otitis media. Again, myringoplasty cannot be done if the ossicular chain is not intact.

questions.text: During the dissection of a cadaver, your anatomy professor asks you to identify the nerve that is related to the pointed region in the image below. Which of the following correctly describes the function of that nerve?
questions.solution:
The pointed area corresponds to the left phrenic nerve, which gives motor supply to the left hemidiaphragm.

In the image, the left lung is identified by the vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum - pulmonary artery, principal bronchus, and inferior pulmonary vein. The aortic arch is seen superiorly and descending thoracic aorta posteriorly of the left root. The image also shows an oblique fissure dividing the lung into superior and inferior lobes.

The phrenic nerve, originating from the cervical nerves C3–C5, is a mixed nerve that carries motor fibers to the diaphragm and sensory fibers from the mediastinal pleura, pericardium, and a portion of the peritoneum.

The course of the left phrenic nerve:

In the cervical region:

    • Anterior to scalenus anterior muscle
    • Posterior to the sternocleidomastoid, inferior belly of omohyoid, internal jugular vein, transverse cervical artery, suprascapular artery, thoracic duct 
    • Anterior to the first part of the left subclavian artery
    • Posterior to the left subclavian vein 

In the thorax 

    • Enters the thorax by crossing the left internal thoracic artery superiorly
    • Within the thorax, the phrenic nerve descends anterior to the pulmonary hilum

Other options:

Option A: The motor supply to the right hemidiaphragm is incorrect. The right phrenic nerve supplies the right hemidiaphragm.

Option C: The parasympathetic supply to the visceral pleura is incorrect. The phrenic nerve does not provide parasympathetic innervation; this is primarily mediated by the vagus nerve. The vagus nerve passes posteriorly to the hilum.

Option D: Forms posterior pulmonary plexuses is incorrect. Posterior pulmonary plexuses are formed by branches of the vagus nerve and T2–T5 sympathetic ganglia, not the phrenic nerve. 

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with nausea and vomiting. She says that she has generalized weakness and fatigability for 2 months. She also complains of frequent episodes of giddiness. Her blood pressure was 90/70 mm Hg. Clinical examination revealed hyperpigmentation of her arms, face, knuckles, and knees. Investigations revealed hyperkalemia and hyponatremia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of long-standing weakness, fatigability, nausea, vomiting, hyperpigmentation, and hypotension, along with hyperkalemia and hyponatremia, are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency, as seen in Addison's disease.

Addison's disease is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis. It may also result from the destruction of the adrenal cortex due to hemorrhage, infection, or infiltration.

The symptoms of adrenal insufficiency are as follows:

  • Glucocorticoid deficiency leads to:
    • Fatigue, lack of energy
    • Weight loss, anorexia
    • Myalgia
    • Hypoglycemia 
    • Low blood pressure, postural hypotension
  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to:
    • Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
    • Dizziness, postural hypotension
    • Low blood pressure, postural hypotension
    • Hyponatremia
    • Hyperkalemia
  • Adrenal androgen deficiency leads to dry and itchy skin, loss of libido 
  • The hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas results from excess ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) secretion, which occurs in response to decreased adrenal cortical hormones.

Other options:

Option A: Cushing syndrome results from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It presents with weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Other clinical features include thin brittle skin with easy bruisability, purple stretch marks, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and osteopenia.

Option C: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is caused by mutations affecting glucocorticoid synthesis. It presents with glucocorticoid deficiency. It is present in the neonatal period or early childhood.

Option D: Conn syndrome refers to primary hyperaldosteronism. It usually results from an aldosterone-secreting adenoma. Excess aldosterone leads to increased sodium and water retention and potassium excretion, resulting in hypokalemia, volume expansion, and hypertension.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, with a history of myocardial infarction 1 year back, presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. The ECG strip obtained during his admission is given below. What does the ECG indicate and what is is the long-term treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Mobitz type 1 heart block; Atropine and isoproterenol
Mobitz type 2 heart block; Permanent pacemaker
Mobitz type 2 heart block; Atropine and isoproterenol

questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the PR segment remains the same in each successive cycle. However, some P waves are not followed by QRS complexes, which means that some of the P waves are not conducted due to an atrioventricular conduction block. This is typical of Mobitz type II block. The definitive long-term treatment is, therefore, a permanent pacemaker. 

In the ECG below, the blue arrows show P waves, and the last P wave is not followed by a QRS complex. This missed QRS complex is marked by the red arrow. Mobitz type II is often a problem in the infra-nodal conduction system, and therefore, is associated with wide QRS complexes (in leads V1, V2, and V3 of the given ECG), as indicated by the red box.

Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This occurs because the atria are unable to conduct the electrical impulse to the ventricles. Patients are usually asymptomatic unless there is significant ventricular bradyarrhythmia. They also have irregular pulse rates. 

Other options:

Option A - Amiodarone, a class III anti-arrhythmic agent, is the drug of choice in the acute treatment as well as prevention of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. It is a rate-control medication. 

Options B and D - Pharmacologic interventions such as atropine and isoproterenol serve as short-term supplementary treatment options until a pacemaker can be installed or if the AV block is transient in nature. Even in such instances, a temporary transcutaneous pacemaker is preferred until a permanent device is available.

questions.text: A prospective study is being conducted to study the effect of alcohol on the development of lung cancer. However, individuals who drink alcohol are more likely to smoke. So, smoking is also associated with exposure. Smoking is also an independent causative factor for lung cancer. Which of the following can be used to reduce confounding factors at the time of analysis?
questions.solution:
Smoking is a confounding factor in this scenario. Multivariate analysis is used to reduce confounding factors at the time of analysis. 

A confounding factor is associated with both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. For example, a prospective study is being conducted to know the effect of alcohol on the development of lung cancer. However, individuals who drink alcohol are most likely to smoke. So, smoking is associated with the exposure. Also, smoking is an independent causative factor for lung cancer. Thus, smoking is a confounding factor.

Multivariate analysis encompasses all statistical techniques that are used to analyze more than two variables at once. The aim is to find patterns and correlations between several variables simultaneously—allowing for a much deeper, more complex understanding of a given scenario.

Methods to reduce confounding are:

  • At the time of designing the study: Randomization, Matching, Restriction 
  • At the time of analysis: Stratification, Statistical modelings like regression analysis, multivariate analysis, and the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.

Option A: Randomization is a technique in which subjects are randomly assigned to study and control groups.

Option B: Matching is a technique to reduce confounding bias by ensuring that cases and controls are similar in all relevant characteristics. eg, gender, race, age, etc.

Option C: Restriction is used to restrict the analysis to a particular set of data (ie, to study subjects with certain characteristics). Eg, if a study is limited to people of just one age group, then all these factors (such as gender, race, geographical area, disease severity, etc) are removed as potential confounders.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with dyspnea, tachypnea, and paraesthesias in his extremities. He recently returned home after a long international flight. Physical examination is significant for carpopedal spasms. CT scan reveals a segmental pulmonary embolus. Which of the following alterations in calcium metabolism is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Increase in calcium bound to albumin
Decrease in calcium bound to albumin

questions.solution:
An increase in calcium bound to albumin is most likely to be present in this patient.

Plasma calcium exists in 3 forms:

  • Ionized calcium (45%)
  • Albumin-bound calcium (40%)
  • Calcium bound to inorganic and organic anions. The homeostasis of these forms is significantly influenced by the extracellular pH. 

This patient has a pulmonary embolism that has caused hyperventilation (tachypnea) and respiratory alkalosis (due to excessive CO₂ excretion). Respiratory alkalosis leads to an increase in extracellular pH, which causes hydrogen ions to dissociate from albumin, providing more protein anions to bind with free calcium. This causes more calcium to bind to albumin and, thus, a decrease in ionised calcium levels.

Ionised calcium is the only physiologically active form, which means that a decrease in ionised calcium can result in the clinical manifestations of hypocalcemia even though total calcium is unchanged. 

Hypocalcemia leads to paresthesias and carpopedal spasms (also known as hypocalcemic tetany). Carpopedal spasm is characterised by extensive spasms of skeletal muscle, especially involving the muscles of the extremities and the larynx. The ionised calcium in the body fluids is a vital second messenger and is necessary for blood coagulation, muscle contraction, and nerve function.

Other options:

Option B: A decrease in calcium bound to albumin is incorrect. Binding increases, not decreases.

Option C: The increase in total plasma calcium is incorrect. Total calcium can remain normal or decrease due to clotting disorders.

Option D: The increase in ionised calcium levels is incorrect. There is a decrease in ionised calcium levels.

questions.text: A premature neonate was admitted to the NICU in view of abnormalities in the antenatal scan done at 20 weeks. It showed "single live fetus with only two vessel cord, dilated esophageal pouch, small stomach with polyhydramnios".  His birth weight is 1.5 kg. On examination, he has respiratory distress and severe abdominal distension.  How will you manage this baby as per the Waterston criteria?
questions.solution:
A gastrostomy followed by intensive care is the most appropriate management as per Waterston's criteria.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a very low birth weight neonate with respiratory distress born with a tracheo-oesophageal fistula. According to Waterston criteria, a gastrostomy should be performed in this patient to relieve the severe abdominal distension and aid in enteral feeding. This is followed by delayed corrective surgery once the child stabilizes to withstand the surgery.

Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is a birth defect that occurs when the esophagus and trachea are abnormally connected. This abnormal connection can result in various complications, primarily due to the aspiration of food, liquid, and saliva into the lungs.

The presentation of TEF is a neonate with frothing and bubbling at the mouth and nose associated with episodes of cyanosis, coughing and respiratory distress. Feeding makes symptoms worse, may cause regurgitation and aspiration. H-type fistulas may present later in childhood with chronic respiratory problems and recurrent pneumonias. 

Pointers to diagnosis are :

  • History of polyhydramnios(with absence of fetal stomach bubble on antenatal imaging)
  • Respiratory distress in the newborn, and inability to pass an orogastric tube.
  • Plain radiograph can show coiled feeding tube in the esophageal pouch and air distending the stomach or airless scaphoid abdomen(in complete esophageal atresia).
  • An abnormal connection may be detected on endoscopy/ bronchoscopy, where leakage of an introduced dye from one lumen to another suggests a connection.

In this patient, other anomalies were also noted in the anomaly scan, such as a single umbilical artery, polyhydramnios, and small stomach, which may be related to VACTERL anomaly, which needs to be evaluated in such cases. VACTERL is vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb defects that may occur together. The exact cause of these coexistent anomalies is unknown, hence, it is an association, not a syndrome.

Initial stabilization measures for a newborn with TEF involve:

  1. Maintaining patent airway. Prone positioning may reduce gastric secretions from entering distal fistulas.
  2. Proximal pouch decompression. Esophageal suctioning to prevent aspiration from the pouch.
  3. Use of antibiotics to prevent pneumonia.
  4. Attempt to avoid endotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilation as it increases stomach distension.

Treatment strategies as per Waterston criteria for tracheoesophageal fistula are:

CATEGORY CRITERIA TREATMENT
A  2500 g weight   Immediate surgery
B 1.8-2.5 kg and/or pneumonia and/or congenital anomalies  Short-term delay plus stabilization
C Less than 1.8 kg and/or severe pneumonia and/or severe congenital anomalies Staged repair following stabilization

In this case, the infant falls under class C, and hence stabilization followed by staged repair is done. The definitive surgery is a primary repair (usually done via a right-sided thoracotomy), in the form of an esophago-esophagostomy after the identification of tracheal fistulas and their closure. Gastrostomy is a temporary measure and may be combined with fistula ligation until the newborn is ready for corrective surgery.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of postmortem hanging?
questions.solution:
The absence of a salivary dribble mark is a feature of postmortem hanging. The presence of a salivary dribble is a feature of antemortem hanging.

A salivary dribble mark is the surest sign of an antemortem hanging and is due to the consequence of pressure and friction on the submandibular salivary glands due to the ligature. This results in dribbling of the saliva from the angle of the mouth (angle opposite to the knot). 

The other options are all signs of antemortem hanging.

Option 1 - Oblique ligature mark is seen in antemortem hanging. This is in contrast to the circular ligature mark seen in postmortem hanging. 

Option 3 - Le facie sympathique is the term used to describe the phenomenon when the eye on the same side as the ligature mark remains open with a dilated pupil. This is caused by pressure on the cervical sympathetic chain of that side. It is an indicator of antemortem hanging. 

Option 4 - Tear of carotid artery intima, known as the Amussat's sign, is seen with antemortem hanging. These are transverse tears and are most clearly seen in obese victims and posteriorly placed knots. While the absence of this sign doesn't exclude antemortem hanging, it is never seen in postmortem hanging.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida visits your clinic for a regular antenatal check-up at 37 weeks of gestation. You perform the following grip by standing near the head end of the mother while facing her feet. What is this grip known as?
questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is the Fourth Leopold maneuver (also known as pelvic grip).

Pelvic grip (fourth Leopold) assesses the engagement, and attitude of the fetal head and determines the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet. It is the only grip performed facing the feet.

The fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers:

First Leopold (Fundal grip ):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the uterine fundus.
  • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
  • The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass. 
  • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

Second Leopold (Lateral grip): 

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses fetal orientation.
  • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
  • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
  • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
  • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
  • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

Pawlik's grip (third Leopold):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face.
  • Assesses the presenting part with respect to the true pelvis.
  • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
  • If the presenting part is not engaged it can be grasped distinctly.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient in ICU is being treated for complicated urinary tract infection and sepsis was suspected to have acute kidney injury. Laboratory investigations show  low GFR but the creatinine and BUN were normal.  Which of the following biomarkers would be useful in this patient  for early diagnosis of acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
In this patient with suspected acute kidney injury osteopontin can be used for early diagnosis.

BUN and creatinine are functional biomarkers of glomerular filtration rather than tissue injury biomarkers and, therefore, may be suboptimal for the diagnosis of actual kidney damage. BUN and creatinine are also slow to rise after kidney injury, hence novel biomarkers are useful for early diagnosis of AKI and for predicting AKI prognosis. 

The various novel markers of kidney injury are as follows:

  • Cystatin C
  • NGAL (neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin)
  • KIM-1 (kidney injury molecule-1)
  • suPAR (Soluble urokinase plasminogen activator receptor)
  • IGFBP7 (insulin-like growth factor binding protein 7)
  • TIMP-2 (tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-2)
  • clusterin
  • NAG (N-acetyl glucosaminidase)
  • Alanine aminopeptidase
  • Osteopontin 
  • ALP

Other options:

Option A: Osteocalcin is not a novel biomarker for acute kidney injury (AKI). It is a bone-specific marker of bone formation raised in conditions like Paget’s disease.

Option B, C: Soluble ST –2 and Galectin – 3 are newer biomarkers that can be used for determining the prognosis of heart failure patients.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient complains that he feels dejected and depressed for the past 3 years. His wife says that he has frequent mood fluctuations.  A few days a week, he appears very depressed, and on other days he is irritable and short-tempered leading to regular arguments with his wife. This causes him stress and he has recently started to consume alcohol to help himself feel better. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of depression, irritability, sudden mood fluctuations, and alcohol abuse for the past 3 years is suggestive of cyclothymic disorder.

Cyclothymia presents as a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by symptoms of hypomania and mild depression. Hypomania mainly includes symptoms like persistently elevated or irritable mood and abnormally increased energy lasting for at least 4 consecutive days. The depression seen in cyclothymia does not qualify the criteria for a major depressive episode.

Around half of the patients complain of depression as their major symptom but some may have primarily hypomanic symptoms. Most of these patients have problems in their social and professional lives due to this disorder. The mood changes are abrupt and occur within hours leading to a great amount of stress. This makes patients feel that they are out of control. 

Substances like alcohol, benzodiazepines, or marijuana are often used to self-medicate. In some cases during the hypomanic state patients may take cocaine, amphetamines, or hallucinogens to further stimulate themselves.

The DSM-5 criteria for diagnosis of cyclothymia:

A. For at least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents) there have been many periods with hypomanic symptoms not meeting the criteria for a manic episode and many periods with depressive symptoms not meeting the criteria for a major depressive episode.

B. During the above 2-year period (1 year in children and adolescents), the hypomanic and depressive periods have been present for at least half the time and the individual has not had a symptom-free interval of more than 2 months.

C. Criteria for a major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode have never been met.

D. The symptoms in criterion A are not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. The symptoms cannot be explained by the physiological effects of a substance or any other medical condition.

F. The symptoms cause significant difficulties in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.

Mood stabilizers like lithium and antimanic drugs like sodium valproate are the first lines of treatment. Psychotherapy is a great way for patients to develop coping mechanisms to help with their mood swings. Patients often require life-long treatment.

Option A: Major depressive disorder usually presents with depressed mood, anhedonia, significant change in weight or appetite, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness nearly every day. These symptoms are present for a minimum of 2 weeks. 

Option C: Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Option D: Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. It is distinguished from major depressive disorder by the fact that patients mention that they have always been depressed. There will never be an episode of mania/hypomania in this condition.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was diagnosed with monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance(MGUS). Which of the following statement is false with regard to this condition?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow clone cells >10% is a false statement regarding monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance(MGUS).

MGUS is a clinicopathological variant of plasma cell disorders. It is the most common plasma cell disorder. It is commonly seen among the elderly.

The diagnostic criteria for monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) are:

  • Non-IgM type serum monoclonal protein <30 g/L 
  • Clonal plasma cells in bone marrow <10%.
  • The absence of amyloidosis or myeloma-defining events such as hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, and lytic bone lesions.

The three distinct clinical types of MGUS are:

  • Non-IgM MGUS
  • IgM MGUS
  • Light chain MGUS (LC-MGUS)

The most prevalent non-IgM MGUS are IgG > IgA > bi-clonal > IgD.

Patients with MGUS are usually asymptomatic. MGUS is a premalignant condition with approximately 1% of patients with MGUS developing asymptomatic plasma cell neoplasm, usually multiple myeloma. A non-IgG subtype, abnormal lambda/kappa free light chain ratio, and serum M protein >15 g/L (1.5 g/dL) are associated with a higher incidence of progression of MGUS to myeloma.

Treatment is generally not recommended for patients with MGUS and periodic follow-up is advised as there is a risk of progression to lymphoproliferative malignancy.

questions.text:
A diabetic patient presents with a history of exquisitely painful, acute lesions within the nose associated with redness of the nasal tip. A history of plucking nasal hairs for cosmetic purposes is present. All of the below statements about the condition are true except:

I&D: Incision and Drainage

choices.text: Venous thrombophlebitis can spread the disease to the cavernous sinus
I&D must be done before lesion becomes fluctuant
Rifampicin is used in resistant carriers

questions.solution:
The clinical features of acute, painful lesions in a diabetic patient associated with the plucking of nasal hairs are suggestive of a furuncle of the nasal vestibule. Incision and Drainage (I & D) must not be done before the lesion becomes fluctuant.

Furuncles present as exquisitely painful acute lesions associated with redness and inflammation of the skin of the nasal tip and dorsum of the nose. Risk factors for the condition include plucking of nasal vibrissae and picking the nose.A furuncle/boil must never be prematurely incised and drained. Premature drainage results in the tracking of infection to the cavernous sinuses.

Other Options:

Option A: The vestibule of the nose is a part of the dangerous area of the face that contains valveless veins, from where infections can track to the cavernous sinus and cause cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option B: Staphylococcus is the organism usually implicated in the development of nasal furuncles. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis causes rhinoscleroma, a granulomatous condition of the nose which presents differently, in three stages, namely atrophic, granulomatous, and cicatricial stage. It is not implicated as a causative organism in Furuncle.

Option D: Nasal Staphylococcal carriers who have recurrent infections can be prescribed topical mupirocin. In resistant cases, chlorhexidine may be tried. In resistant cases posing severe problems, oral rifampicin along with another antibiotic is given to eliminate the carrier state.

questions.text: A woman presents to a Dermatologist with a complaint of alopecia and some lesions on her face. The doctor, after examination, found it to be scarring alopecia and noticed adherent scales, as shown in the image below. Histopathological exam shows lymphocytic interface dermatitis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing discoid lesions on the face with central scarring, active erythematous margins, and adherent scales suggest discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE).

A scarring type of alopecia is seen in discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE), a benign inflammatory disorder of the skin that most frequently affects the face and scalp. Histology of DLE shows lymphocytic interface dermatitis with basal layer degeneration, follicular plugging, dermal mucinosis, and epidermal atrophy.

The first-line treatment for localized lesions is topical corticosteroids. Hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine are oral antimalarial drugs that can be used along with oral steroids and have a good response rate. 

The image given below shows hyperkeratosis and plugging of the follicular ostia with keratotic material, otherwise known as the carpet tack sign, tin-tack sign, or cat's tongue sign, which is seen in discoid lupus erythematosus.

Other options:

Option A: Secondary Syphilis presents with maculopapular rash, mostly on palms and soles. They are non-itchy and coppery red. Patchy hair loss is characteristic of syphilis. The hair falls out, leaving small, scattered, irregularly thinned, ‘moth-eaten’ patches of semi-baldness as shown in the image below.

Option B: Tinea capitis is a ringworm infection of the scalp. It can lead to scarring (non-inflammatory form) or non-scarring (inflammatory form) alopecia. The image given below shows tinea capitis.

Option C: Alopecia areata causes non-scarring alopecia, as shown in the image given below.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron

  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text:
Which of the following are risk factors for uterine inversion?

1-Placenta increta

2-Short umbilical cord

3-Macrosomia of baby

4-Early cord clamping

5-Fundally attached placenta
questions.solution:
Risk factors for this complication are 1,2,3,5.

Uterine inversion is an obstetric emergency and an important cause of postpartum hemorrhage. It typically occurs spontaneously in 40% of cases but more commonly is iatrogenic and stems from poor management of the third stage of labor. Risk factors for this condition include:

  1. Incorrect methods of placental delivery: Early cord traction before placental separation from the uterus, applying fundal pressure for placental delivery in a relaxed uterus, and pulling the cord in a relaxed uterus all predispose to this complication.
  2. Placental factors: Fundally attached placenta(Statement 5), morbidly adherent placenta(Statement 1) such as placenta accreta spectrum(placenta increta,accreta,percreta) , short umbilical cord(Statement 2)
  3. Foetal factors: Macrosomia of the baby(Statement 3)
  4. Uterine factors: Weakness of uterine wall at the site of placental implantation, uterine malformations, uterine over-enlargement, etc
  5. Other factors: Tocolysis, uterine atony, prolonged labor and connective tissue diseases like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can cause the uterus to invert.

Steps in the treatment of uterine inversion include:

  1. Discontinuing uterotonic, securing two large bore IV lines to commence crystalloid infusions, and following with blood transfusion to manage shock.
  2. After confirming that the uterus is not firmly retracted/contracted, attempts are made to manually reposition it along with the placenta in situ if not completely separated. 
  3. Tocolytics like terbutaline may be used to adequately relax the uterus and reattempt repositioning. The part inverted first is repositioned last.
  4. Oxytocin infusion is commenced once uterus is repositioned and tocolytics are stopped. Spontaneous expulsion of the placenta is awaited.
  5. Uterine position is maintained while applying bimanual compression. A Bakri balloon may also be used for this.
  6. If attempts at repositioning fail or simply cannot be done, surgical methods like Huntington and Haultain are tried.

Other Statements:

Statement 4: Early cord clamping is not a known risk factor for uterine inversion.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:

choices.text: Delivery of occipitotransverse position in platypelloid pelvis
Delivery of after coming head in breech delivery
Outlet forceps used to provide traction force

questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is an outlet forceps used to provide traction force.

 Wrigley's forceps are used exclusively in outlet forceps operations for the extraction of the head. It is used to provide traction force. The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. Outlet forceps are used when:

  • The fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia
  • The fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, at or on the perineum
  • The sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°)

Other options:

Option A: Kielland forceps are used in correcting asynctilism.

Option B: Barton forceps are used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.

Option C: Piper forceps have a distinct perineal curve and allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: A surgeon uses the given instrument to visualize the lower alimentary tract for tumors in an elderly male. What structures can he visualize?
questions.solution:
The anal canal and lower rectum can be visualised.

A conventional proctoscope can visualize a lesion up to 10-15 cm from the anal verge.

A surgeon uses a lubricated proctoscope to visualize lesions in the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum. It is done as an OPD procedure to detect haemorrhoids, polyps, or ulcers. A biopsy may be taken if it is above the anoderm. It is avoided in anal fissures as it causes undue pain.

questions.text: A 27-year-old photographer presented with confusion, delirium, and corrosion near the mouth. He was found with an empty bottle containing hydrocyanic acid. He is tachycardic and hypotensive. Resuscitative measures are unsuccessful, and his body is sent for postmortem analysis. What would be the color of post-mortem hypostasis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of hydrocyanic acid (HCN) poisoning, and the colour of postmortem hypostasis in case of HCN poisoning is brick red. 

HCN is a toxic chemical acid found in bitter almonds, peaches, apples, cherries, etc. It has the smell of bitter almonds. It is usually present in its glycoside form, amygdalin, along with certain co-enzymes like emulsion complex, these co-enzymes hydrolyze amygdalin to release HCN. HCN is a common chemical used in leather tanning, electroplating, metal extractions, and photographic fixing. 

Mechanism of action: It is a protoplasmic poison releasing cyanide ions, which inhibit complex IV of cellular respiratory enzyme systems. It leads to histotoxic anoxia.

Postmortem findings: 

  • External: The smell of bitter almonds, brick red postmortem hypostasis. Rigor mortis appears early, and jaws are firmly closed.
  • Internal: In suspected cyanide poisoning cases, the cranial cavity should be opened first to perceive the bitter almond smell that is marked in brain tissue. Diffuse cerebral oedema such that white and gray matter cannot be differentiated, haemorrhages in the lungs.

Toxicological analysis: Preserve lungs to demonstrate the gas in a nylon bag. The spleen is the best specimen to demonstrate cyanide poisoning.

Laboratory diagnosis includes a classical triad of

  1. Narrow arterio-venous oxygen difference,
  2. Anion-gap metabolic acidosis, and
  3. Elevated lactate concentration.

HCN may be identified by gas chromatography or spectrophotometry.

Lee-Jones Test: This test indicates the presence of cyanide. The test can be positive for salicylates, too.

Treatment: Shift the patient to a room with fresh air and remove his clothes. Establish proper airway, breathing, and circulation. Inhalational amyl nitrate is administered, and 100% oxygen therapy is also given. Wash skin and eyes with large amounts of water to remove any contact poison, if any. A slow infusion of 3% sodium nitrate solution, followed by a slow infusion of 25% sodium thiosulfate solution, is given.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is administered the 3rd dose of Ty21a vaccine orally according to the 3-dose regimen (Day 1, 3 and 5). When is the protective immunity achieved after the last dose?
questions.solution:
Ty21a vaccine is an oral live attenuated vaccine that provides protective immunity after day 7 of the last dose of the 3-dose regimen. Schedule of Ty21a vaccine is as follows:

  • The capsules are licensed for use in individuals aged ≥ 5 years.
  • The vaccine is administered every other day: on days 1, 3, and 5. With the 3-dose regimen, protective immunity is achieved 7 days after the last dose.
  • Repeat this series every 3 years for people living in endemic areas and every year for individuals traveling from non-endemic to endemic countries.

Another vaccine for typhoid fever is the Vi polysaccharide vaccine, which is a subunit vaccine administered subcutaneously or intramuscularly. Schedule of Vi polysaccharide vaccine is as follows:

  • The vaccine is licensed for individuals aged ≥ 2 years
  • Only 1 dose is required, and the vaccine confers protection 7 days after injection
  • To maintain protection, revaccination is recommended every 3 years

questions.text: Given below is the graph representing age distribution in Hodgkin's lymphoma. Identify the marked labels 1, 2, and 3.
questions.solution:
The given graph represents the bimodal age distribution in Hodgkin's lymphoma. 1 & 2 represent the modes because they indicate the two peaks (most frequent occurrences). While 3 represents the median, as it is the middle value of the distribution.

3 also represents the mean as in a symmetrical bimodal distribution, Median = Mean unless the distribution is asymmetrical or skewed. In a distribution with outliers, the preferred measure of central tendency is the median. The better preference for the center value should always be median than mean since the mean is the most affected by the extreme values (outliers).

The description of measures of central tendency is as follows:

  • Mode is the most frequently occurring value and is not affected by the extreme values.
  • Median is the central value after arranging the values in ascending or descending order. 
  • Mean is the average of all the values. 

Hodgkin's lymphoma follows a bimodal age distribution, with two peaks—one in young adults (15-35 years) and another in older adults (over 55 years).

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A teenage boy complained of excessive daytime sleepiness for the past 6 months. He says that he is not able to move his legs or arms for 1-2 minutes while waking up in the morning. He also complains that he falls very frequently without being able to get up, as shown in the image. Which histaminergic drug can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of narcolepsy. Pitolisant is the histaminergic drug that can be given to this patient. 

Pitolisant is an H3 receptor inverse agonist that has been approved for the treatment of narcolepsy. Contraindications for this drug include end-stage renal disease and severe hepatic impairment.

Narcolepsy is a type of hypersomnolence disorder that is characterized by a tetrad of symptoms of:

  1. excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. cataplexy- sudden loss of muscle tone
  3. sleep paralysis- patients report being unable to move their muscles while waking up in the morning, even though they are awake and conscious
  4. hypnogogic hallucinations- vivid auditory or visual perceptions during sleep onset, can occur while awakening also

Narcolepsy is characterized by the sudden onset of REM sleep. Emotional triggers like laughter and anger cause cataplexy.

It has a familial incidence associated with HLA-DR2. These patients are usually deficient in the hypocretin neurotransmitter that stimulates appetite and alertness. 

Modafinil and CNS stimulant drugs like methylphenidate are being used in the treatment of narcolepsy. Recently, H3 receptor inverse agonist drugs have been approved for the treatment.

Other options:

Option B- Diphenhydramine is an H1 receptor antagonist with antimuscarinic activity. It is used in the reversal of extrapyramidal side effects caused by antipsychotics. 

Option C- Cyproheptadine is an H1 receptor antagonist with antiserotonergic activity. The major clinical applications are carcinoid syndrome and cold-induced urticaria. It is also used in the treatment of serotonin syndrome. It also acts as an appetite stimulant.

Option D- Olopatidine is a topical H1 receptor antagonist with additional mast cell stabilizing and anti-inflammatory properties. It is used in allergic conjunctivitis as drop form and in allergic rhinitis as a spray form.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with headache and weakness of the right side of the body. He demonstrates difficulty with speech. The patient's angiography is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding this disease is false?

choices.text: Occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries
Dawson’s fingers are the characteristic imaging finding

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features, along with the X-ray angiography showing a "puff of smoke" appearance, suggest Moyamoya disease. Dawson's fingers are a radiographic feature typically seen in multiple sclerosis (MS), not Moyamoya disease. 

Moyamoya disease is a chronic, occlusive cerebrovascular disorder affecting large intracranial arteries (option A), particularly the internal carotid arteries and their branches. It has a bimodal age distribution, typically presenting with ischemic strokes or TIAs in children and hemorrhagic strokes in adults.

Due to progressive vessel occlusion, collateral circulation develops (option D) via the lenticulostriate arteries, producing the characteristic "puff of smoke" (moyamoya) appearance on angiography (as shown in the scenario). Unlike vasculitides, vascular inflammation is absent (option B). The first symptom is often a stroke or recurrent TIA. Treatment involves surgical revascularization, such as extracranial-intracranial (EC-IC) bypass, to reduce stroke risk.

The picture below demonstrates Dawson's fingers.

questions.text:
A child assigned female at birth now presents with primary amenorrhoea. External genitalia appear female, but there is no pubic or axillary hair. Breast is Tanner Stage 4. Lab investigations reveal that both LH and testosterone levels are simultaneously elevated while FSH levels are normal. Imaging reveals an absent uterus.
Which of the following interventions is not done in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS) where surrogacy after oocyte retrieval is not viable as there is no oocyte due to an absent ovary.

Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome is a condition where the individual has a karyotype of 46XY in fetal development but fails to respond to testosterone due to androgen receptor insensitivity. Hence, they present at birth with female external genitalia due to the absence of action of testosterone and undescended testis. There is no ovary, and the Mullerian ducts fail to develop due to the normal production of mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS) from the sertoli cells of the testis. 

They present with inguinal hernia before puberty or primary amenorrhoea in adolescence. On examination, the individual is tall and pubic, axillary hair is absent due to a lack of testosterone activity. The breast normally develops (Tanner Stage 4 / 5 ) as excess androgen converts to estrogen through aromatase.

External genitalia appears female but on per-vaginal examination, the vagina is underdeveloped and Uterus is absent (as are all other Mullerian duct derivatives like fallopian tubes)which can be confirmed with USG/MRI. Testes may be palpable in the inguinal region or noted on abdominal ultrasound. Ovaries are absent.

Serum testosterone levels are elevated, but paradoxically, LH is also elevated due to loss of feedback of testosterone due to the absence of androgen receptor activity. Sertoli cells produce inhibin and AMH (Anti-mullerian hormone), which cause feedback inhibition of FSH; hence its levels are normal. Estrogen levels are normal for male baseline.

Karyotyping gives a definitive diagnosis and differentiates from Mullerian agenesis. Here, the karyotype is 46XY, while in Mullerian agenesis, the karyotype is 46XX. Shown below is a schematic flowchart for the evaluation of primary amenorrhoea:

Treatment options for CAIS are:

  • The individual is allowed to continue as a female.
  • The poorly developed vagina may be made sizeable for sexual activity through serial vaginal dilation(Option C) or by surgical methods like McIndoe vaginoplasty, Vecchietti procedure (Option D), and Davydov procedure. 
  • Gonadectomy is advised due to the risk of malignant transformation of the testes. According to recent research, a low risk of the development of cancer has deterred routine gonadectomy in all cases these days. However, as option A is improbable, it is the best answer.
  • Post orchidectomy, hormone replacement therapy with only estrogen is offered until menopause is induced (Option B).

Unfortunately, these individuals can neither conceive (due to absent uterus) nor opt for surrogacy with their ovum( due to absence of ovulation); hence, biological conception of offspring is not possible. Individuals with CAIS cannot have biological children.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman with a history of fever for 4 days & foul-smelling vaginal discharge for 1 week is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. On examination, her pulse is rapid & thready, and there is generalized tenderness, guarding & rigidity over the abdomen. Ultrasound reveals a multilocular complex adnexal mass with debris, septations, and irregular thick walls. She has a history of multiple OPD visits for STI treatment. Which of the following stages of PID is this patient presenting with?

STI-Sexually transmitted infection

PID- Pelvic inflammatory disease
questions.solution:
Fever with foul-smelling vaginal discharge in a patient with a history of STI (Sexually transmitted infection) points towards a diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The given ultrasound findings suggest a tubo-ovarian abscess and the clinical features suggestive of generalised peritonitis are pointing towards its rupture, which comes under Stage 4 of Gainsville Staging.

PID is the inflammation of the upper genital tract, involving the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. The most common cause of PID is sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) resulting from ascending Chlamydia & gonococcus infection. 

The fallopian tube is the most commonly affected part of PID. Depending on the extent & severity of involvement, PID is staged according to the Gainsville Staging:

Stage Condition
Stage I Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions
Stage II Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge
Stage III Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 
Stage IV Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
Stage V Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: Which of the following flaps involves the isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and finally reconnection using microsurgery?
questions.solution:
Free flaps involve isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and then reconnection using microsurgery at the new site. 

Flaps are tissues that bring vascularity as they are transferred with their blood supply. Different types of flaps are: 

  1. Random flaps have no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters. It is basically three sides of a rectangle, and the length-to-breadth ratio is less than 1.5:1. 'Delaying the flap' is a process in which cuts are partially made and the flap is partly lifted at a first operation. It is then replaced, thus ‘training’ the blood supply from a single border of the rectangle. A second procedure is conducted where it is raised further and finally transferred.
  2. Axial flaps - These are longer flaps. They are based on known blood vessels supplying the skin. This technique enables many long thin flaps to be safely moved across large distances.
  3. Pedicled/islanded flaps - They can be swung around on a stalk or even fully ‘islanded’ because of the axial blood supply. The business end of the skin being transferred can hence have the pedicle buried.
  4. Free flaps - In this case the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site 
  5. Composite flaps - Often skin with bone or muscle is transferred with the flap (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous flaps, respectively).
  6. Perforator flaps - Tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface. It is a subgroup of an axial flap.

Skin-bearing flaps are also classified based on -

  • Composition: Refers to the tissue contained within the flap, such as cutaneous, musculocutaneous, fasciocutaneous etc
  • Method of movement:
    • Local transfer, eg. advancement or rotation flaps
    • Distant transfer, eg. pedicle flaps from the abdomen to the perineum or micro-vascular free flaps.
  • Blood supply:
    • Musculocutaneous arteries travel perpendicularly through muscle to the overlying skin.
    • Septocutaneous arteries travel with intermuscular fascial septa to supply the overlying skin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis C infection presents with fatigue, arthralgia, and skin blisters predominantly on sun-exposed areas. On examination, he has a palpable purpura on his lower limbs. Laboratory investigations reveal positive cryoglobulins, low C4 levels, mild proteinuria and elevated urinary porphyrins. Which of the following best explains the pathological basis of his clinical manifestations?

choices.text: Immune complex deposition, vascular inflammation, and glomerular injury
Hepatic dysfunction, oxidative stress, and porphyrin accumulation
Immune complex vasculitis, complement activation, and porphyrin accumulation
Direct viral cytopathy, complement-mediated vasculitis, and inflammatory activation

questions.solution:
Immune complex vasculitis, complement activation, and porphyrin accumulation best explain the pathological basis of his clinical manifestations.

In a patient with chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, the presence of fatigue and arthralgia suggests vasculitis. Palpable purpura indicates cryoglobulinemia, while mild proteinuria points to membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). Sun-exposed skin blisters are characteristic of Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT).
