questions.text: Which of the following factors does not predict a better clinical outcome following hearing rehabilitation by cochlear implantation?
questions.solution:
Prelingually deafened adults with little prior auditory experience obtain limited benefit from cochlear implantation.

Factors that predict a successful clinical outcome in cochlear implantation are:

  • Previous auditory experience (postlingual patients or prior use of hearing aids) (Option A)
  • Younger age at implantation (especially for prelingual children). (Option C)
  • Shorter duration of deafness
  • Neural plasticity within the auditory system (Option D) is the ability of the brain to adapt to different sounds and stimuli. The success of hearing aids depends on how the auditory system responds to reintroduced sounds. 

A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the nerve, bypassing the damaged hearing apparatus.

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of the cochlea and convert the sound signal to electrical impulses, which directly stimulate the fibers of cranial nerve VIII. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Cochlear implant:

  • An electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and those who cannot benefit from a hearing aid
  • Principle- Surgery is performed to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea
  • Indication- bilateral severe to profound deafness
  • Prerequisites- Intact 8th nerve and higher auditory pathway
  • Surgical approach- facial recess (posterior  tympanotomy) approach
  • The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. 
  • Internal component- The receiver-stimulator implanted during surgery (under the skin), electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea)
  • External component (remains outside the body)- The microphone, speech processor, and transmitter

Note: In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for 3 months. The biopsy of the intestine is shown below. His symptoms improved with folic acid intake. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a young man presenting with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss with histopathology showing partial villous atrophy and marked intraepithelial lymphocytosis indicating inflammation of lamina propria and improvement with folic acid intake is suggestive of tropical sprue.

Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition that causes chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and folate and vitamin B12 malabsorption. It occurs in some tropical regions and is often considered a postinfectious complication. Diagnosis is based on a small intestinal biopsy showing villous atrophy and chronic inflammation, similar to celiac disease. However, tropical sprue is unresponsive to a gluten-free diet.

Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., tetracycline for up to six months) and folic acid supplementation, which can lead to improvement within weeks. Patients often recover fully if they leave the endemic area. Folic acid alone can improve symptoms and correct hematologic deficiencies, but antibiotics are typically needed for complete resolution.

Other options:

Option A: Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Patients present with iron deficiency anemia, weight loss, diarrhea, and malabsorption. A biopsy reveals blunting of the villi, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation propria. Tissue transglutaminase is involved in the pathogenesis of this disorder. Patients respond to a gluten-free diet. The image below shows histopathological findings seen in celiac disease.

Option B: Whipple's disease is a multiorgan disease caused by the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterized by arthralgia, arthritis, weight loss, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and psychiatric manifestations. The organism can be detected by tissue immunohistochemistry and tissue staining for PAS-positive macrophages. The below image shows the PAS stain in Whipple's disease.

Option D: Short bowel syndrome is characterized by extensive removal of the small intestine. The loss of small-bowel surface area leads to severe diarrhea, weight loss, and problems absorbing fat, protein, and carbohydrates.

questions.text:
What is the usual order of repair of the above procedure, in the absence of any complications?

1-Approximation of the vaginal mucosa

2-Identification of the apex

3-Perinei and Bulbospongiosus approximated

4-Approximation of skin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a mediolateral episiotomy being conducted to expedite the vaginal delivery and prevent perineal lacerations. The correct order of repair of the above procedure in the absence of any complications is to identify the apex → approximate the vaginal mucosa → approximate the perinei and bulbospongiosus muscles → approximation of skin.

A well-timed episiotomy can prevent undue perineal lacerations from occurring during delivery and also speed up and facilitate the delivery. Poorly timed episiotomy results in excess bleeding. Ideally, episiotomy should be done when crowning of the head takes place.

Repair of a properly done episiotomy is done with the help of suture materials such as polyglycolic acid or chromic catgut in the following manner:

  • The apex of the episiotomy is identified, and an anchor stitch is placed
  • Running locking closure of the vaginal mucosa is done
  • Continuous, nonlocking sutures are placed to approximate the muscles(bulbospongiosus, perinei)
  • Finally, the skin is closed by subcuticular/interrupted sutures, and skin glue may also be applied

Care should be taken to obliterate all the dead space adequately to prevent hematoma or collection. Very deep bites run the risk of injury to the rectum; hence, they must be placed with due care.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A child with recurrent urinary tract infection underwent the following investigation. Which of the following is not the complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Acute tubular necrosis is not a complication of vesicoureteric reflux.

In the given scenario, the micturating cystourethrogram shows significant ureteric dilation and tortuosity, with loss of the papillary impression suggestive of vesicoureteric reflux. 

Acute tubular necrosis is characterised by a rapid (within hours to days) decline in kidney function that leads to the retention of waste products due to necrosis of renal tubular epithelial cells. Renal ischemia, shock, hypovolemia, intake of nephrotoxic drugs, and renal vein thrombosis are some of the causes of acute tubular necrosis.

Vesicoureteric or vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a condition in which there is a retrograde urinary flow from the bladder to the ureter and kidney. It is usually congenital.

The complications associated with vesicoureteric reflux are 

  • Urinary stasis leading to urinary tract infections
  • Pyelonephritis by facilitating the transport of bacteria from the bladder to the upper urinary tract
  • Pyelonephritis can result in renal injury or scarring, also termed reflux-related renal injury or reflux nephropathy
  • Extensive renal scarring impairs renal function and can result in renin-mediated hypertension
  • Renal insufficiency or end-stage renal disease
  • Impaired somatic growth and morbidity during pregnancy

A voiding cystourethrogram is used to confirm the VUR. VUR can be graded based on the appearance of the urinary tract on the micturating cystogram. It is as follows:

  • Grade 1- Reflux into the nondilated ureter
  • Grade 2- Reflux into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade 3- reflux into a dilated ureter and/or blunting of the calyceal fornices
  • Grade 4- reflux into a grossly dilated ureter
  • Grade 5- massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression

Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in pediatric imaging for the detection of renal scarring and acute pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is admitted with symptoms of ear pain and ear discharge, which was not responsive to topical measures. He also complained of pain while chewing. A swab was taken and cultured; the isolate was a strict aerobe, and the catalase test was positive. What is the likely etiology of his infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the laboratory findings are suggestive of malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive catalase reaction. Enterococcus, Lactobacillus, and Streptococcus are catalase negative.

Catalase test: When a microbial colony is placed in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the catalase enzyme degrades H2O2 into H2O and O2. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles. People with chronic granulomatous disease have recurrent attacks of infection with catalase-positive organisms.

Catalase positive organisms:

  • Staphylococcus
  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio    
  • Nocardia
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella   
  • Enterobacteriaceae   
  • Listeria
  • Neisseria meningitidis   
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • Yersinia
  • Brucella

Catalase negative organisms:

  • Streptococci
  • Enterococci
  • Lactobacillus

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/ pyoverdin. Other pigments these organisms produce include pyorubin (red) and pyomelanin (brown).

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/ Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric, sepsis, and invasive disease
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Pseudomonas is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by producing diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses, such as burns, predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Pseudomonas is characterized by blue-green pus. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas. Biochemical tests, such as arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction, make species identification possible. 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green-colored colonies are shown in the image below.

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

Oxidase positive organisms:

  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella
  • Neisseria
  • Brucella
  • Moraxella
  • Burkholderia

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought with gradually progressive pain below his left knee over the past 6 months. An X-ray reveals the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction. This is suggestive of Brodie's abscess.

Brodie’s abscess is a subacute variant of osteomyelitis with a milder presentation. It occurs when organisms of low virulence infect an immunocompetent host. The abscess is walled off by the thickening of the surrounding bone trabeculae. It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur.

Patients present with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, and it is managed by antibiotics and curettage. The following x-ray and MRI images show Brodie's abscess of the radius in a patient.

Option B: Sclerosing osteomyelitis of Garre appears as a markedly sclerotic lesion with extensive periosteal reaction.

Option C: Chronic osteomyelitis is diagnosed by the presence of sequestrum, involucrum, and cloacae. 

Option D: Osteoclastoma commonly occurs between 20-40 years of age and is unlikely in children. On a radiograph, it appears as a lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction with a soap bubble appearance.

questions.text: Which among the following best describes the demographic gap in developing countries?

choices.text: Birth rate 7 per 1000, death rate 11 per 1000
Birth rate of 9 per 1000, death rate of 9 per 1000
Birth rate of 10 per 1000, death rate of 7 per 1000
Birth rate 9 per 1000, death rate 10 per 1000

questions.solution:
Among the given options, the birth rate of 10 per 1000, and the death rate of 7 per 1000 best describe the demographic gap in developing countries.

The demographic gap refers to the difference between the birth rate and the death rate in a given population. In developing countries, this gap is generally positive, i.e., birth rates are higher than death rates, leading to population growth. The birth rate of 10 per 1000, and death rate of 7 per 1000  shows a positive difference (+3 per 1000), which aligns with the typical pattern seen in developing nations.

Other options:

Option A: Birth rate 7 per 1000, death rate 11 per 1000 → Negative demographic gap (-4 per 1000). The death rate is more than the birth rate, leading to population decline. This is more common in aging or developed countries.

Option B: Birth rate 9 per 1000, death rate 9 per 1000 → Zero demographic gap (0 per 1000). The population remains stable, with births and deaths balancing each other out. This is not typical for developing countries, which usually experience population growth.

Option D: Birth rate 9 per 1000, death rate 10 per 1000 → Negative demographic gap (-1 per 1000). More deaths than births lead to a slow population decline, which is also uncommon in developing nations. This is more common in aging or developed countries.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male patient presented with a 3-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. There is a history of similar episodes 2 years back. Occasionally, he has noticed dark-colored urine. LFT is given below. A liver biopsy, stained with Fontana-Masson stain is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin - 4.4 mg/dL (Predominantly conjugated)

Serum AST, ALT- Normal
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the liver biopsy showing characteristic deposition of pigment are suggestive of Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver which can lead to a gross black appearance of the liver. The disease is caused by the mutation in the multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) gene in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes.

Total bilirubin concentrations are typically between 2 and 5 mg/dL and can fluctuate widely in patients. Hyper-bilirubinemia may be increased by current illness, oral contraceptive use, and pregnancy. Aside from elevated serum bilirubin levels, other routine laboratory tests (eg Liver Function tests) are normal. 

Other options:

Option A: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs due to a decrease in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UDPGT) activity. Type 1 has absent/trace UDPGT enzyme activity and type 2 has <10% of the normal UDPGT enzyme activity.

Option C: Budd Chiari syndrome is characterized by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. It is a clinical complex characterized by hepatomegaly, ascites and abdominal pain.

Option D: Gilbert syndrome is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs due to reduced UDPGT enzyme activity (10-33% of Normal).

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presents with a rapidly enlarging, painful swelling of the right breast for the past 4 weeks. She denies fever or any trauma. On examination, her right breast is warm, diffusely erythematous, indurated, and edematous, as shown below. No discrete lump is palpable. What is the most appropriate next step in confirming the diagnosis?

choices.text: Core needle biopsy of the breast
Needle aspiration followed by empirical antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given image and examination findings indicate a peau d'orange appearance on the right breast, which suggests a diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma (IBC). Core Needle Biopsy of the breast will be the next step in confirming the diagnosis in this patient.

Inflammatory breast carcinoma is an aggressive form of breast cancer and has the worst prognosis among all subtypes of breast cancer. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from edema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

The diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer are: 

  • Rapid onset of breast erythema, edema, and/or peau d'orange and/or warm breast (with or without an underlying palpable mass)
  • Duration of history: no more than six months
  • Erythema occupies at least one-third of the breast
  • Pathologic confirmation of invasive carcinoma

The pathologic hallmark is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics in skin biopsy specimens, but it is not a prerequisite for diagnosis. A core needle biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis. It is a stage T4d as per the staging of breast cancer.

For treatment, a combined modality is used, which includes:

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Modified radical mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy (for ER-positive tumors)
  • Trastuzumab (for HER-2-positive tumors)

Other Options:

Option B: PET-CT scan should be considered after the diagnosis to rule out concurrent metastatic disease, but is not used to confirm the diagnosis of IBC.

Option C: Needle aspiration followed by empirical antibiotics are the appropriate management for a breast abscess. A breast abscess is usually suspected when mastitis does not respond to antibiotics within 48-72 hours. It is more common in lactating women, and the patient typically has a fever and a fluctuating mass on examination.

Option D: IBC is an advanced disease (T4d) with widespread lymphatic involvement. The first step is to confirm malignancy by core needle biopsy before any further staging.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented with lethargy, diarrhea, and darkening around the eyes. On examination, his blood pressure was elevated and a mass was palpated in the abdomen.  A biopsy from the mass is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child presenting with a mass in the abdomen, diarrhea, ecchymosis, hypertension, histopathology showing Homer-Wright pseudorosettes is suggestive of neuroblastoma.

Neuroblastoma is a tumor of the sympathetic nervous system in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic chain that originates from neural crest cells. The most common cause of familial predisposition is the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene mutation. It is predominantly seen in children less than 5 years of age. Patients present with a mass in the abdomen, ecchymosis or proptosis due to secondary lesions in the periorbital region, and elevated blood pressure due to increased levels of catecholamines in the blood.

In neonates, multiple cutaneous metastases cause deep blue discoloration of the skin called blueberry muffin baby. In children, neuroblastoma mostly arises from the adrenal medulla. On transsection, it is composed of grey-tan tissue with hemorrhage and areas of necrosis and calcification. A biopsy of the tumor gives a pathological diagnosis. Histology shows small, round blue cells with dark nuclei, scanty cytoplasm, and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.

Urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) are elevated. CT or MRI to assess the mass and secondaries. The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor and adjuvant chemotherapy. The drugs used from chemotherapy are carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and doxorubicin.

The image below shows a typical Homer-wright pseudorosette is seen in which tumor cells are arranged concentrically with a central space filled with eosinophilic fibrillary material:

Other options:

Option A: Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically, it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells that form trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver. The image below shows the histology of hepatoblastoma, which shows proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial cells.

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a mesenchymal malignant tumor. Histologically, it comprises sheets of primitive round cells with skeletal muscle differentiation. The image below shows the histology of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma and sheets of primitive round cells.

Option C: Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is the most common primary renal tumor in childhood. Histologically, it shows the classic triphasic pattern composed of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cell types.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with thyroid swelling. She was previously treated with radiation therapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma. She has no fever or night sweats. What do you suspect this patient is likely to be diagnosed with?
questions.solution:
This patient with a thyroid swelling, who was treated for Hodgkin’s lymphoma (by radiation), is likely to have papillary thyroid cancer.

Radiation is the only established risk factor for the development of differentiated thyroid carcinoma (papillary and follicular). This association is stronger for papillary than for follicular carcinomas.

The risk of developing papillary thyroid cancer is high among individuals who

  • Received external irradiation to the thyroid as children (<5 years of age)
  • Received radiation for soft tissue malignancies, such as Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Have a history of acute environmental exposure

Note:

Risk factor for the development of thyroid lymphoma is non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (and not Hodgkin’s). Moreover, the absence of B-symptoms (fever, night sweats, and weight loss) makes the diagnosis of thyroid lymphoma unlikely.

Chernobyl disaster: The incidence of childhood thyroid cancer (specifically papillary) rose up to 100 times as compared to before the incident.

questions.text: Following anthropometric evaluation, a child is diagnosed to have chronic malnutrition. Decrease of which of the following measures will be most specific for it?
questions.solution:
A child with chronic malnutrition will have low height-for-age and low weight-for-age. Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition while low weight-for-age can be seen in both acute and chronic malnutrition.

The nutritional status of a child is assessed in terms of anthropometry:

The World Health Organization (WHO) has established international standards for normal child growth from birth to 5 years of age. The normalization of the anthropometric measures is done in terms of z-scores (standard deviation scores). The anthropometric indicators are marked in a growth chart which is compared with a reference curve.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight-for-height, or wasting, usually indicates acute malnutrition.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight-for-age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

questions.text: Which of the following ocular signs might be expected in an elderly patient with hyperlipidemia?
questions.solution:
Image B shows arcus senilis or arcus lipoides, which is an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral corneal that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma. Characteristically it is separated from the margin by a narrow zone of comparatively clear cornea.

It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition. When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder.

 

Other Options:

Image A shows Vossius ring which is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Image C shows a a KF ring/ Kayser-Fleischer ring which occurs due to intraocular deposition of copper in the corena, seen in Wilson's disease. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea.

 

Image D shows a corneal ulcer the adjacent immune ring of Wessely, formed by infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion in fungal corneal ulcers. It is due to a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).

The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the immune cells, inciting further inflammation.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with complaints of continuous urinary dribbling from the vagina. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done and the middle swab is stained with blue. Intravenous pyelogram is normal. In India, which among the following could be the most likely cause of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Continuous urinary dribbling and positive methylene blue 3 swab test suggest the diagnosis of vesicovaginal fistula (VVF). Obstetric complications are the most common cause of vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) in India.

In developed countries, surgical injury to the bladder is the most common cause of VVF. Causes of vesico-vaginal fistula:

  • Obstetric complications: Prolonged or neglected labor
  • Gynecological: As a complication of total hysterectomy or anterior colporrhaphy
  • Radiotherapy
  • Direct neoplastic infiltration:  Seen in carcinoma cervix

In a majority of the cases, the fistula requires surgical repair.

Obstetric causes:

  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section

questions.text: A child was brought dead to the casualty, and the parents gave a history of red eye, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhoea. He is also alleged to have consumed some plant seeds 4 days back. Post-mortem examination shows congested and inflamed intestines with submucous haemorrhages. Haemorrhages are also seen in the pleura and pericardium, with dilation of the heart. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely poisoning that could have occurred in this child is ricin poisoning, probably due to the consumption of ricin seeds (Fatal dose 5-10 seeds, ricin-60 mg).

Ricin blocks protein synthesis through RNA polymerase inhibition. Ricin is excreted by the intestinal epithelium. It enters gastric mucosal cells and causes severe bloody diarrhoea. It causes nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, delirium, collapse and death. The fatal period is 2 to 5 days.

Post-mortem appearance of gastrointestinal mucosa shows congestion with the presence of hemorrhagic inflammation, the heart is dilated, and pleural, pericardial haemorrhages are found, with congestion of internal organs. The ricin seeds are shown in the image below.

Other Options:

Option B: Ergot poisoning shows intimal thickening of small arterioles and thrombus formation with internal organ congestion. It is usually associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and gangrene. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat tend to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. The image given below shows wheat grains infested with a blackish fungal mass suggestive of ergotism.

Option C: Cerebra thevetia(Oleander) is a cardiac poison that causes cardiac arrhythmias, AV block, and symptoms similar to digoxin toxicity as thevatin inhibits Na K ATPase. In severe poisoning, Digifab is used in treatment. Since the patient has bloody diarrhoea and hemorrhagic manifestations, this is not the answer. The image given below shows cerebra thevetia.

Option D: Datura is a CNS poison that causes symptoms of anticholinergic syndrome, as given below:

  • Fever due to loss of sweating
  • Confusion due to CNS penetration
  • Blurred vision due to cycloplegia and mydriasis
  • Red flushed skin due to vasodilation
  • Dry skin

The image given below shows datura seeds.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient complains of dull pain in the lower back for 8 months. He also complains of early morning stiffness which improves only on exercising. Ankylosing spondylitis is suspected. Which of the following is an essential criterion for the diagnosis of this disease, as per the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis international Society (ASAS) categorization criteria?

choices.text: Limited motion of the lumbar spine
X-ray of spine showing a bamboo appearance

questions.solution:
Sacroiliitis is an essential criterion for the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis. The clinical presentation of a young male with backache, morning stiffness, redness of the eye, and the X-ray showing the classical bamboo-spine appearance are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. 

Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker (About 85 percent).

ASAS Categorization Criteria for spondyloarthritis in patients under 45 years of age with lower back pain of 3 months duration

Criteria comprise 2 sections: one ‘‘radiological section’’ and one ‘‘clinical section’’.

  • To qualify for the radiological section a sacroiliitis on simple radiography or MRI and at least one of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis needs to be confirmed.
  • To qualify for the clinical section the patient needs to have a positive HLA B27 and at least two of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis without radiologic sacroiliitis being mandatory

Radiological diagnosis of sacroiliitis 
      - Active (acute) inflammation in the MRI is highly suggestive of sacroiliitis due to spondyloarthritis 
      - Radiological sacroiliitis is defined according to the New York criteria (grade >2 bilateral or grade 3 - 4 unilateral)

Features of spondyloarthritis

  • Low inflammatory pain
  • Arthritis
  • Enthesitis
  • Uveítis
  • Dactylitis
  • Psoriasis
  • Crohn/colitis
  • Good response to NSAID
  • Family history of spondyloarthropathy
  • HLA B27
  • High CRP levels

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels
    • Long-standing cases are associated with osteoporosis. Wedging of the vertebral bodies produces hyperkyphosis of the spine.
  • Progressive bony ankylosis or erosive arthritis may be seen in peripheral joints.

Extra-articular involvements are seen as the disease progresses.

  • Ocular - The most common extra-articular manifestation is anterior uveitis, typically unilateral, and recurs often
  • Pulmonary - Fibrosis of the upper lobe of the lungs
  • Cardiac - Acute aortic insufficiency, heart blocks
  • Gastrointestinal - inflammation of the ileum or colon
  • Dermatological - Psoriasis
  • Renal - Secondary IgA nephropathy
  • Peripheral joint involvement - shoulder and hips (presence indicates poor prognosis)

Complications that are likely to be seen due to this disease are -

  • Most common serious complication is spinal fracture. Lower cervical spine is the most common area for fracture
  • Loss of lumbar curvature (lumbar lordosis) causing limitation of movements in all directions
  • Gluteal muscle atrophy
  • Forward bending (kyphosis) of the thoracic spine leading to reduced chest movements and shallow breathing

questions.text: A 20-year-old male posted for emergency open appendicectomy was given spinal anaesthesia. On examination, cremasteric reflex was absent. What could be the possible level of spinal anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the possible level of spinal anesthesia is L2 as the root value of cremasteric reflex is L1, L2.

After the administration of spinal anesthesia, monitoring of block height is done by motor, sensory, and sympathetic nervous system assessment. Spinal reflexes can also be used for monitoring the block height, which includes abdominal, cremasteric, and anal reflexes.

Cremasteric reflex is a superficial reflex that can be tested in males. The female counterpart is the Geigel reflex.

  • Procedure: Stroking of the inner part of the upper thigh causes pulling up of the ipsilateral testicle
  • Afferent: Ilioinguinal and femoral (sensory) branch of genitofemoral nerves (L1, L2)
  • Reflex Centre: L1, L2 spinal nerve nuclei
  • Efferent: Genital (motor) branch of genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2) to cremasteric muscle

The level of motor blockade is 2 spinal segments lower than sensory blockade, which is in turn 2 segments lower than autonomic block. For example, if the motor block is at the level of T8, the sensory block would be at the level of T6, and the sympathetic block would be at the level of T4.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in spinal anesthesia

  • The normal extent of the spinal cord is the lower border of L1 in adults and the upper border of L3 in infants.
  • First spinal anesthesia was given by Augustin Bier.
  • It is injected into the space between L3-L4 in adults and L4-L5 in children.
  • The deposition of the drug is in the subarachnoid space.
  • The subarachnoid space ends at S2 in adults and S3 in children.
  • Traumatic needle- Quincke
  • Atraumatic needle- Sprotte
  • Structures pierced- Ligamentum flavum, interspinous ligament, supraspinous ligament. (Posterior longitudinal ligament is NOT punctured)
  • The first fibres to be blocked- Autonomic preganglionic.
  • The last fibres to be blocked- Motor.
  • The last fibres to recover- Preganglionic autonomic.
  • Levels of anesthetic effect - Autonomic level is 2 segments above the sensory, which is 2 segments above the motor.
  • The most common complication is hypotension.
  • Brewer Luckhardt reflex- Reflex hypotension due to parasympathetic stress at a different site. 
  • Paramedian spinal anesthesia prevents penetration of the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments.
  • Anesthetics in a paravertebral block are least likely to diffuse into subarachnoid space.
  • The lowest incidence of post-spinal headache is when a thin needle is used.
  • A high level of spinal injection causes hypotension and bradycardia.
  • The vasopressor of choice in hypotension produced during the subarachnoid block is phenylephrine.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms transmits microbial pathogens by a method known as vomit drop involving regurgitation of abdominal contents?
questions.solution:
Musca domestica or the common housefly is responsible for the transmission of microbial pathogens by the vomit drop method, which involves regurgitation of the stomach contents onto various surfaces.

Musca is responsible for disease transmission by the following means:

  • Vomit drop: This vomit drop is a rich microbial culture containing various pathogenic microorganisms
  • Mechanical transmission: The external body of Musca attracts various microbes and cysts of human parasites and acts as a vehicle for their transmission
  • Excrement: The feces of Musca also contain pathogens and contaminate food and water

Note that the common household fly is a nonbiting insect. Musca transmits over 200 human pathogens, some of which are Typhoid, Paratyphoid, Cholera, Polio, Amoebiasis, Anthrax, Yaws, various helminthic organisms, etc. Control measures for this fly include:

  • Environmental control: adequate sanitation and waste disposal mechanisms
  • Insecticidal control: Residual sprays like DDT, Methoxychlor, Lindane, etc, Solid or Liquid Baits made of Diazinion, Ronnel, etc, Cords and ribbons impregnated with insecticide, larvicidal agents like 0.5% Diazinion
  • Flypapers, which are sticky and trap flies
  • Protection against flies by using screens
  • IEC (Information-Education-Communication) activities

Other Options:

Option B: Phlebotomus argentipes or Sandfly is responsible for the transmission of Leishmania, the organism responsible for Kala Azar. Transmission is by the bite of Phlebotomus.

Option C: Phthirus pubis or Crab Louse/Pubic Louse is found in the pubic and perineal region and is an ectoparasite of the human body. It is not known to be the vector of any major human disease.

Option D: Glossina palpalis or Tse-Tse fly is the vector for Trypanosoma brucei the organism responsible for sleeping sickness. Transmission is by bite of Glossina.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is rescued from the rubble of a collapsed building 12 hours after an earthquake. He was trapped under heavy debris, with his lower limbs compressed. Upon extrication, he appeared disoriented and weak, with swollen and tense legs. Emergency responders give intravenous fluids and transport him to the hospital. On arrival at the emergency department, he is hypotensive and tachycardic. Blood tests and arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis are performed. Which of the following abnormalities is least likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing Crush Syndrome, a severe consequence of prolonged limb compression. Hypercalcaemia is not seen in crush syndrome.

Crush Syndrome occurs when prolonged compression of muscle tissue leads to ischemia and necrosis, followed by a systemic inflammatory response upon reperfusion. This condition is commonly seen in victims of earthquakes, building collapses, and industrial accidents. When the pressure is released, toxic intracellular contents such as potassium, myoglobin, phosphate, and lactic acid flood the bloodstream, causing electrolyte imbalances, metabolic acidosis, and potential organ failure.

The main complications of crush syndrome include severe hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, acute kidney injury (AKI), hypocalcemia, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (leading to elevated PT and aPTT). Hyperkalemia from muscle breakdown can lead to fatal cardiac arrhythmias, while myoglobinuria can cause acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and renal failure. Hypocalcemia occurs due to calcium-phosphate binding from tissue damage, and coagulation abnormalities arise from the systemic release of procoagulants.

Management focuses on early and aggressive IV fluid resuscitation, aiming to prevent AKI by flushing out myoglobin and potassium. Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate reduces myoglobin precipitation in the renal tubules. If compartment syndrome is suspected, fasciotomy may be required, but it is avoided if the limb has been trapped for more than 12 hours to prevent the overwhelming systemic release of toxins.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Maximum penetration is seen with:
questions.solution:
Gamma rays show maximum penetration.

When a nucleus disintegrates, it will emit radiation either as photons (X or gamma rays) or as high-velocity particles. Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation (EMR) similar to X-rays, however, distinguished from the latter by the fact that they are emitted from an excited nucleus. Gamma radiation is highly penetrating and interacts with matter through ionization via two processes, the photoelectric effect, and Compton scattering.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: Which of the following modes is used for weaning patients from the Ventilator?
questions.solution:
Synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV) is used to wean the patient from the ventilator.

SIMV delivers the bare minimum number of breaths from the ventilator—4-5 breaths/minute—and promotes patient effort to take the remaining breaths. In its synchronized version, stacking of breaths is prevented, as spontaneous efforts are recognized, and machine breaths during a spontaneous effort are avoided. This helps prevent barotrauma due to a very high tidal volume. The machine breaths provide a backup if the patient becomes fatigued.

Another method to wean the patient from the ventilator is intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV). It is a sequence in which spontaneous breaths are permitted in between mandatory breaths. A selected number of mechanical breaths are given to supplement spontaneous breathing. 

Other options:

Option A: Assist Control Mandatory Ventilation (ACMV)—The machine will give time-triggered breaths and assist spontaneous breaths by effort trigger. It is the most commonly used initial ventilator setting. It can be Volume-controlled (VCV) or pressure-controlled (PCV).

Option B: Volume-controlled Ventilator (VCV)- It is a part of Assist Control Mandatory Ventilation.

Option D: Pressure Controlled Ventilation (PCV)-It is a part of Assist Control Mandatory Ventilation.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of the condition associated with the following clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows discrete raised white dots at the limbus of the cornea, called Horner Tranta's spots, typically seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), which is a type of allergic conjunctivitis. 

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis, also known as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis is a recurrent inflammation of the conjunctiva with seasonal incidence, commonly occurring in individuals with an atopic background and seasonal allergies due to Th2 lymphocyte alteration followed by IgE response. It is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction. The condition presents in three types which are :

  • Palpebral, affecting the upper tarsal conjunctiva, characterised by hypertrophied 'cobblestone' papillae
  • Bulbar-limbal, characterised by dusky red triangular congestion of the conjunctiva, gelatinous limbal papillae and Horner-Tranta's spots that are formed due to eosinophils and epithelial debris at the limbus
  • Mixed

Patients present with burning and itching sensation that worsen in warm, humid atmospheres, associated with ropy discharge (Maxwell Lyon sign), lacrimation and mild photophobia. Local spread leading to involvement of the cornea is termed vernal keratopathy. The condition is usually self-limiting but symptomatic treatment with anti-inflammatory therapy like topical steroids, mast cell stabilizers, antihistaminics and NSAID eye drops may be indicated, along with topical lubricating agents and mucolytics.

Other options:

Option A: Bacterial infection is responsible for acute or chronic bacterial conjunctivitis, usually characterized by painful red eye associated with a mucopurulent discharge.

Option B: Viral infection is responsible for various types of viral conjunctivitis which broadly present as follicular or hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. They are usually characterised by marked hyperemia with watery discharge, possibly associated with  systemic signs like fever and lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Granulomatous conjunctivitis is characterised by prominent nodule formation and unilateral involvement, and regional lymphadenitis, seen in conditions like tuberculosis, sarcoidosis and ophthalmia nodosa.

questions.text:
An individual with a Pancoast tumor is going to undergo ocular surgery for a complication arising from the tumor. MRD1 is found to be abnormal in the affected eye. The levator function is assessed to be good and the frontalis is functioning normally. Which surgery will be done?

MRD1: Margin Reflex Distance 1
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, where a Pancoast tumor causing an ocular complication is Horner Syndrome. Due to Horner’s, the patient has ptosis as suggested by abnormal MRD1 in the affected eye, which may be corrected by Fasanella Servat operation as the levator function is good here.

Fasanella Servat operation is a ptosis correction surgery that is done when the levator function and lid fold are good. It is done for minimal ptosis of 1.5 -2mm with levator excursion of >8mm which indicates good levator action. Indications for this procedure are horner syndrome and mild congenital ptosis.

In this operation, the upper eyelid is everted and the upper tarsus is identified and excised. Excision is generally double the amount of ptosis. For example, for 2mm ptosis, 4mm of tarsus is excised. 

Margin reflex distance 1(MRD 1) is the distance of the corneal light reflex from the center of the upper eyelid. Normally it is 4mm with a variation of 1 mm. Levator excursion is a parameter used to analyze the degree of functional activity of the levator by restricting head movement and frontalis action on levator function and testing eyelid excursion. A good levator function has an excursion value of 8mm or higher. 5-7mm is considered fair and 4 or less is considered poor levator function.

Other Options:

Option A: Frontalis sling operation is typically performed for treatment of severe ptosis where the levator function is poor (excursion is <4mm). Here, the poor function of the levator is compensated for by the activity of a functional frontalis muscle, to which the levator is attached using silicon rods, fascia lata graft, etc. 

Option C: Lateral tarsorraphy is a procedure where the palpebral aperture is shortened by unison of the lids at the lateral canthus. It is used in the treatment of paralytic ectropion, severe dry eye diseases, and in neurotrophic/exposure keratopathy.

Option D: Byron Smith’s modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation is done for severe ectropion of the lower eyelid with marked eversion towards the lateral canthus. In this procedure, a full-thickness lid shortening is performed at the lateral canthus. Excess skin is removed.

questions.text: A male patient on an antidepressant medication reports to the emergency with a severe headache and very high blood pressure. He says that he had consumed dried sausage accidentally at an event the previous night. What is the name of the reaction and which of the drugs belonging to the same class is most likely to cause this effect?
questions.solution:
The patient presenting with severe headache and elevated blood pressure after consuming dried sausage while on antidepressant medication suggests a hypertensive crisis, commonly referred to as the "cheese reaction."  Tranylcypromine is a non-selective and irreversible monoamine oxidase inhibitor, which is most likely to cause this effect.

Cheese reaction occurs when foods high in tyramine, such as cheese, dried meats, and sausages, are ingested by individuals taking certain monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs).

Normally, gastrointestinal and hepatic MAO enzymes break down tyramine, but when these enzymes are inhibited by MAOIs, tyramine enters the systemic circulation in high concentrations. This leads to a massive release of norepinephrine, causing a significant increase in blood pressure that can result in myocardial infarction or stroke. Due to the risk of serious adverse effects, monoamine oxidase inhibitors are typically reserved for treating resistant depression.

Serotonin syndrome is a life-threatening condition resulting from excessive serotonin activity in the central nervous system. It manifests through a combination of cognitive, autonomic, and somatic disturbances. Patients may experience mental status changes such as confusion, agitation, and irritability. Autonomic dysfunction can present as hyperthermia and unstable blood pressure, while somatic symptoms include muscle rigidity, tremors, and myoclonus. It can occur if a patient takes serotonergic drugs like SSRIs or tramadol along with monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Other Options:

Option B, D: Moclobemide and eprobemide are reversible inhibitors of monoamine oxidase enzyme.

Option C: Selegiline is a selective MAO B inhibitor used for the treatment of Parkinson's disease and is less likely to cause a cheese reaction as compared to tranylcypromine, which is a non-selective MAO inhibitor.

questions.text: A man arrives at the emergency department with an injury on his right hand, leading to significant blood loss. Which of the following blood vessels would be the major source of redistribution of the blood volume to compensate for his significant blood loss?
questions.solution:
The largest amount of blood gets redirected from venules and veins.

In this given clinical scenario of a patient with significant blood loss, the major source of redistribution would be from venules and veins, as they store a maximum percentage of blood. They are called capacitance vessels as they function as blood storage reservoirs because of their distension property.

Other Options:

Option A: Aorta has the property of elasticity/ windkessel effect. It contains a relatively large amount of elastic tissue that is stretched during systole and recoils during diastole. It has the lowest cross-sectional area and highest blood flow velocity.

Option B: Arteries and arterioles are resistance vessels and regulate blood flow through vasoconstriction and vasodilation. They are the principal site of peripheral resistance and are responsible for regulating tissue blood flow and arterial pressure.

Option D: Capillaries are also known as exchange vessels. They are responsible for exchanging nutrients and gases within the interstitial space. Approximately 5% of total blood volume is present in capillaries at any given time. They have the lowest blood flow velocity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient presents with dry eyes and a dry mouth. On examination, enlarged parotid glands are present. Laboratory examination reveals the presence of SS-A and SS-B antibodies. What is the most common renal manifestation of this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of dry mouth, dry eyes, and enlarged parotid glands with the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies is suggestive of Sjogren’s syndrome. The most common renal manifestation is tubulointerstitial nephritis.

Sjögren’s syndrome is an autoimmune disease commonly seen in women aged 50-60 years, characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands resulting in xerostomia, dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), and profound B-cell hyperactivity.  

They present with blurred vision, burning or itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens -SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome.

Other Options:

Option B: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is usually associated with Hepatitis B or Hepatitis C.

Option C: Tubulointerstitial nephritis in Sjogren’s syndrome can present as Distal renal tubular acidosis (not proximal).

Option D: Membranous nephropathy can occur secondary to drugs (NSAIDs, penicillamine, gold) and infections.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for anemia. The oral and eye examination findings are shown below. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with its image showing cheilosis, angular stomatitis, a magenta-colored tongue, and corneal vascularisation, points to the diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency. RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing this condition.

Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products.

The following signs and symptoms characterize the deficiency state of riboflavin:

  • Cheilosis- pallor in the angle of the mouth and fissuring of the lips, which extends radially to the skin.
  • Glossitis- the tongue becomes smooth, and there is a loss of papillae (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes- keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features- seborrheic dermatitis and anemia.

Note: Because of its intense yellow color, riboflavin is widely used as a food additive.

Other options:

Option A: RBC transketolase assay diagnoses vitamin B1/ thiamine deficiency. Thiamine deficiency mainly manifests as peripheral neuritis, beriberi, and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option B: The serum methyl malonate level is used to diagnose vitamin B12/ methylcobalamin deficiency. Patients typically present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and signs and symptoms of subacute combined degeneration, manifesting as loss of vibration and proprioception and absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option C: The RBC transaminase assay assesses glutamate levels inside RBCs. Human erythrocytes require a continual supply of glutamate to support glutathione synthesis, but this is not routinely tested.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was treated with a diuretic for heart failure. He now presents with complaints of hearing impairment and dizziness. Which diuretic is likely to be associated with these side effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced hearing loss, and furosemide is likely to be associated with these side effects, causing ototoxicity.

Loop diuretics have the potential to cause damage to the ears, resulting in symptoms such as ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing impairment, dizziness, and a feeling of fullness in the ears. The risk of ototoxicity is highest when loop diuretics are administered rapidly through an intravenous route and lowest when taken orally. To prevent ototoxicity, it is important to avoid infusing furosemide at a rate of more than 4 mg/min.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. It is used in cases of acute pulmonary oedema, cerebral oedema, hypertension, and hypercalcemia of malignancy.

Hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects.

Other options:

Option B: Thiazides act on the DCT. They inhibit Na+-Cl− symporter present in the distal convoluted tubule. It is used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic oedema. Their adverse effects are as follows:

  • Hypotension
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypochloremia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Decrease glucose tolerance
  • May increase the lipid levels

Option C: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like acetazolamide inhibit the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal convoluted tubule. Used to treat glaucoma and mountain sickness and to alkalinize urine. Side effects are acidosis, hypokalaemia, fever, rashes, and paresthesia. Bone marrow depression is rare but a serious side effect. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

Option D: Tolvaptan is an orally active nonpeptide selective V2 receptor antagonist. Its main mechanism of action is to enhance the excretion of free water by the kidneys, which helps restore normal sodium levels in the blood. It is a new addition to the treatment options for hyponatremia caused by congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, or syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). The most common side effects of this medication include increased thirst and a dry sensation in the mouth. Other possible side effects are fever, gastrointestinal disturbances, and elevated blood sugar levels.

questions.text: A young patient with anemia had an abnormal X-ray of the skull showing a crewcut appearance and the peripheral smear showed target cells and RBCs with basophilic stippling. She was diagnosed with a quantitative defect in hemoglobin synthesis. What will be a CBC finding generally seen in this patient?

choices.text: The ratio of MCV to RBC count is > 13

questions.solution:
An anemic patient with an X-ray skull showing crewcut appearance and a peripheral smear showing Target cells and basophilic stippling probably has thalassemia, a quantitative defect in hemoglobin synthesis. RDW is 11.5% (normal) in this patient.

RDW-CV(Red cell Distribution Width where CV stands for coefficient of variation) is a CBC parameter that calculates the distribution of red cell volume (not width) as a percentage. Its formula is:

RDW-CV = (Standard Deviation of MCV/Mean MCV)×100

Hence, RDW depends on the average mean cell volume and the distribution of RBC cell volume( standard deviation). Graphically, it is obtained as the “width” of the red cell volume distribution curve. Normal values are from 11-14%. This width can increase whenever there is a large variation in RBC volumes in the sample. There are two useful conditions where RDW is employed:

  • Differentiating IDA and Thalassemia: Both conditions present with microcytosis and anisocytosis, but RDW is normal or slightly elevated in thalassemia as the overall RBC cell volume is uniformly small, and in IDA(Iron deficiency anemia), RDW is elevated (>14%) with greater variation in volume of anisocytes.
  • Identifying dimorphic anemias: In dimorphic anemias like concomitant B12 and iron deficiency, both macrocytosis and microcytosis occur, which is seen as an elevated RDW.

The X-ray of Thalassemia patients shows a highly characteristic sign known as crewcut appearance which occurs due to extramedullary hematopoiesis stimulating new bone formation in the skull. Peripheral smear findings in Thalassemia are:

  • Microcytes and anisopoikilocytes seen.
  • RBCs are hypochromic and Target cells(where Hb collects in the cell's centre) may be seen.
  • Basophilic stippling and fragmented RBCs
  • Poorly hemoglobinized nucleated red cell precursors called normoblasts seen. 

Other Options:

Option A: The ratio of MCV to RBC count is termed Mentzer’s Index and is another screening test employed to differentiate between IDA and Thalassemia. In IDA, the Mentzer Index is > 13 while in thalassemia, it is < 13.

Option B: Microcytosis is the hallmark of thalassemia, hence, MCV should be less than 70 fL(Normal MCV IS 70-100 fL). An MCV of >100 indicates macrocytosis, as seen in conditions like B12 deficiency.

Option D: MCHC > 40 generally occurs as an error due to malfunctioning of the device as MCHC levels peak around 37%, which is the peak solubility of hemoglobin. Hence, such a value cannot be generally seen in thalassemia where the MCHC value is reduced due to low Hb production.

questions.text:
Five months ago, a 55-year-old patient of yours presented to the OPD with complaints of dry mouth and difficulty in swallowing with positive serum anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, following which you started her on treatment. Her recent blood investigations show elevated GGT and ALP levels and liver biopsy shows characteristic florid duct lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

GGT - Gamma-glutamyltransferase

ALP - Alkaline phosphatasee
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the initial presentation of dry mouth, difficulty in swallowing and positive serum anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies points to the diagnosis of Sjögren's syndrome. Based on the patient's current laboratory findings and liver biopsy showing characteristic florid duct lesion, the patient has developed Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which is an extraglandular (systemic) manifestation of Sjögren's syndrome.

Sjögren’s syndrome is a prototype autoimmune disease, commonly seen in women aged 50-60 years, characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands resulting in xerostomia, dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), and profound B-cell hyperactivity.  

They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens -SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. The extra glandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are:

  • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jaccoud's arthropathy.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Interstitial lung disease - most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Renal tubular acidosis - Type 1 (distal) RTA

Primary biliary cirrhosis(PBC) is an autoimmune destructive condition of the small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts, commonly seen in women aged 40-50 years. Clinical features of PBC include fatigue, debilitating pruritus and hyperpigmentation.

GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. About 90% of the patients will have anti-mitochondrial antibodies. 

Biopsy of the liver shows a florid duct lesion (as given in the image). This is due to the destruction of interlobular bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation. 

Option A: Primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, and steatorrhea similar to PBC. It is more common in men in the 3-5th decade. It is characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis of intra and extrahepatic ducts. The perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA), is positive and anti-mitochondrial antibodies is negative. Liver biopsy shows concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis. 

Option B: Primary ascending cholangitis is a life-threatening condition caused by an ascending bacterial infection of the intra- and extrahepatic ducts with secondary blockage of the biliary tracts. It affects both men and women aged 50 to 60 years. Charcot triad describes cholangitis as clinical findings of fever, right upper abdominal pain, and jaundice.

Liver biopsy shows cholestasis within the hepatic parenchyma and neutrophils involving the bile duct lumen. 

Option D: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is defined as the presence of hepatic steatosis in individuals who do not consume alcohol or do so in small quantities. Histopathological diagnosis requires steatosis (≥5% of hepatocytes), lobular inflammation, and ballooned hepatocytes. The ratio (AST/ALT) is less than 1. GGT, when elevated, can be a marker of increased mortality.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing. Laboratory tests are ordered, and a throat swab is sent for culture on Potassium Tellurite Blood Agar, which revealed poached egg colonies. What method is used in the special precipitation test for its toxin demonstration?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing, along with a throat swab showing poached egg colonies on potassium tellurite agar, indicates Corynebacterium diphtheriae mitis. The Ouchterlony method is used in Elek's test, a type of special precipitation test done for its toxin demonstration.

The Ouchterlony method is a double diffusion method in two dimensions. It involves pouring agar gel onto a slide and creating wells using a template. The central well is filled with antiserum, while surrounding wells contain different antigens. When two adjacent antigens are identical, their precipitation lines merge. If they are unrelated, the lines cross over each other. A spur formation indicates partial identity or cross-reaction.

A special variety of double diffusion in two dimensions is the Elek test that is used to assess diphtheria bacilli toxigenicity. In this method, bacilli are streaked perpendicular to a filter paper strip embedded with antitoxin. The presence of toxin-producing bacilli results in arrowhead-shaped precipitin lines, confirming toxigenicity.

The test is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: The Oudin procedure is a single-diffusion method in one dimension. The antibody is in an agar gel, and the antigen diffuses downward, forming a moving precipitation line. The number of bands indicates distinct antigens.

Option C: Oakley-Fulthorpe is a double diffusion method in one dimension. In this method, antigen and antibody diffuse toward each other through a plain agar layer, forming a band of precipitate at their optimal concentration balance.

Option D: Radial Diffusion is a single diffusion method in two dimensions where antigen diffuses radially from wells in an antiserum-containing gel, forming concentric precipitation rings that estimate antigen concentration.

  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)

  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with nausea, vomiting and stomach ache.  His urine is subjected to a test and the results are shown below. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The given test is Gerhardt's ferric chloride test, which is used to detect acetoacetic acid in urine in patients with ketoacidosis.

To 5 ml of urine, ferric chloride solution is added drop by drop, till a maximum precipitate of ferric phosphate is obtained. This is to eliminate the phosphates, which may obscure the color in the test, and then it is filtered. To the filtrate add excess ferric chloride. A red color indicates the presence of acetoacetic acid. The presence of salicylates in urine will give a false positive Gerhadt's test.  

This test only identifies acetoacetic acid. Acetone and beta-hydroxybutyrate can’t be detected by this method.

Other options-

Option A: Rothera’s test using nitroprusside reagent is a specific test used to detect whether ketones like acetone or acetoacetate are present in a given urine sample. A purple ring at the junction of two liquids indicates a positive test. Rothera's test does not detect beta-hydroxybutyrate. 

Option B: Seliwanoff's test will distinguish glucose and fructose. The reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose.

Option C: Fouchet's test is used for detecting the presence of bile pigments in urine. Here, urine is heated with barium sulfate, which adsorbs bilirubin. Ferric chloride is added, which oxidizes the adsorbed bilirubin to biliverdin, which produces a green color.

questions.text: Deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is seen in:
questions.solution:
A deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is seen in pneumothorax.

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. 

AP view plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax. There is an increase of transradiancy at the left lung base and the costophrenic sulcus laterally is more pronounced (‘deep sulcus sign’-yellow arrow).

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When this collection of gas is constantly enlarging with resulting compression of mediastinal structures it can be life-threatening and is known as a tension pneumothorax. The best X-ray view to diagnose pneumothorax is a PA view in full expiration.

Types of pneumothorax:

  • Primary spontaneous: No underlying lung disease
  • Secondary spontaneous: Underlying lung disease is present
  • Iatrogenic/traumatic  

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • The visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • The deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is an indication of a pneumothorax. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright.

questions.text: Which of the following genus does the RNA virus shown in the image below belong to ?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a bullet-shaped virus, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA is characteristic of rabies viruses belonging to the genus Lyssavirus.

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is classified as Lyssavirus serotype 1 under the family Rhabdoviridae. These viruses are enveloped, rod, or bullet-shaped and contain single-stranded RNA. This virus attaches to the cells via its glycoprotein spikes and the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor acts as the cellular receptor. 

Other options:

Option A: Rhabdoviridae is not a genus; it is a family of viruses. Genera within the Rhabdoviridae family include Lyssavirus, Vesiculovirus, Ephemerovirus, and Novirhabdovirus. 

Option C: Poxviridae family includes molluscum contagiosum virus, variola (smallpox) virus, and monkeypox virus.

Option  D: The rubella virus is the only member of the genus rubivirus and belongs to the family Togaviridae.

questions.text: The immunofluorescence of the skin sample is shown below. Which of the following is true about blisters seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The blisters seen in this condition rupture frequently.

The immunofluorescence pattern shown above is suggestive of Pemphigus vulgaris. 

Direct immunofluorescence of skin samples with anti- IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis. This fish net appearance is characteristic of Pemphigus vulgaris due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes, which are present intercellularly.

The bullae (blisters) of Pemphigus vulgaris occur from destruction within the epidermis, therefore they are

  • Thin and fragile- rupture frequently
  • Painful (not pruritic)
  • Involves oral mucosa
  • Nikolsky’s sign positive -Slight rubbing of the skin results in peeling off of the epidermis. It is also seen in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

The bullae of Bullous pemphigoid are deep, tense, do not rupture frequently, spare the oral mucosa and are Nikolsky’s sign negative. The immunofluorescence pattern seen in Bullous pemphigoid is a linear, subepithelial staining pattern.
