questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presents with delayed puberty. Investigations reveal increased levels of gonadotropins. Which among the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased levels of gonadotropins pointing towards Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and Klinefelter's syndrome is the only condition in the given choices causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Klinefelter's syndrome is the most common sex chromosomal aneuploidy in males. Most of them have 47 XXY chromosomes. The diagnosis is rarely made before puberty, behavioral or psychiatric disorders may be apparent long before the defects in sexual development.

Causes of delayed puberty:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central):

Hypogonadism due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production

  • Malnutrition, systemic diseases
  • Kallmann (anosmia), Prader–Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence)

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure):

Hypogonadism due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH), which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as an attempt of compensation by the body)

  • Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Ovotesticular dysgenesis

questions.text: A 70 kg athlete was posted for surgery and he was administered succinylcholine due to unavailability of vecuronium. It was administered in intermittent dosing (total 640 mg). During recovery, the patient was not able to respire spontaneously & move limbs. What is the reason for the same?

choices.text: Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine
Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness
Phase II blockade produced by succinyl choline
Pseudocholinesterase deficiency increasing action of succinylcholine

questions.solution:
The best answer to the above case scenario is phase II blockade produced by succinylcholine.

Phase II block is clinically seen with the dose >5 mg/kg.

Mechanism of action of succinylcholine:

  • Phase I block: continuous endplate depolarization and subsequent muscle relaxation.
  • Phase II block: seen with a large single dose, repeated doses, or a continuous infusion which can lead to desensitization of the receptors resulting in a prolonged neuromuscular blockade.

Causes of prolonged apnea include:

  • Atypical/pseudocholinesterase deficiency - can result in apnea even with a normal dose of succinylcholine
  • The altered response of endplate to depolarizing relaxant (myasthenia gravis)
  • Accumulation of succinylcholine leading to phase II blockade

Although options B, C, and D can lead to prolonged apnea, in the above case scenario, the patient has received ~9mg/kg of succinylcholine. Hence the most probable diagnosis is phase II blockade leading to prolonged apnea.

Related Pearl: Side effects of succinyl choline

The following are the side effects of succinyl choline:

  • Cardiovascular effects:
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Myalgia
  • Masseter spasm: Succinyl choline can trigger malignant hyperthermia
  • Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may lead to an activation of the EEG and slight increases in CBF and ICP in some patients.
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Increased intragastric pressure

questions.text: A Ph.D scholar wants to study the etiological factors leading to the development of Moebius syndrome. Which study design should she use?
questions.solution:
Moebius syndrome is a rare disease, so a case-control study should be used by the researcher to study the etiology of this disease.

The case-control study is a comparison or cross-reference study with individuals as the unit of study. It is also called a retrospective study and is a good analytical design to study rare diseases. This study is the first approach to test causal hypotheses.

The case-control method has three distinct features:

  1. Both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study
  2. The study proceeds backward from effect to cause
  3. It uses a control/comparison group to support/reject an inference 

Other options:

Option A - Cohort study is a follow-up study with individuals as the unit of study. It is used for the study of multiple outcomes related to exposure of study. It can not be used when the exposure under investigation is rare.

Option B - Cross-sectional study is a prevalence study with individuals as the unit of study. It is also known as a prevalence study and is more useful for the study of chronic diseases. It is more appropriate for the study of the distribution of a disease in a population than studying its etiology.

Option D - Ecological study is a correlational study with the population as the unit of study.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: Which of the following represents an aortic dissection originating from the descending aorta and extending below the diaphragm?

choices.text: Stanford type A + DeBakey III A
Stanford type A + DeBakey III B
Stanford type B + DeBakey III A
Stanford type B + DeBakey III B

questions.solution:
Aortic dissection originating from descending aorta and extending below the diaphragm is Stanford type B + DeBakey III B.

Classification of aortic dissections: 

  • Stanford Type A - proximal lesions, involving
    • both the ascending and descending aorta - DeBakey I
    • ascending aorta only - DeBakey II
  • Stanford Type B - distal lesions not involving the ascending part and usually beginning distal to the subclavian artery - DeBakey III.
    Debakey III is further subdivided into:
    • III A: involves descending thoracic aorta only
    • III B: extends below the diaphragm

questions.text:
Match the following opioid drugs to their mechanism of action.
 Drug Mechanism of Action
1. Methadone a. Full agonist at kappa;  partial agonist at mu
2. Buprenorphine b. 5HT/NE uptake inhibitor
3. Pentazocine c. NMDA antagonist
4. Tramadol d.Partial μ-opioid agonist; κ antagonist
questions.solution:
The correct matching is 1-c,2-d,3-a,4-b.

  Drug Mechanism of Action
1. Methadone c. NMDA antagonist
2. Buprenorphine d.Partial μ-opioid agonist; κ antagonist 
3. Pentazocine a. Full agonist at kappa;  partial agonist at mu

Opioid groups of analgesics are drugs that exert their action by acting on μ, K, or δ receptors.

Older generations of opioid agents like morphine and codeine produce profound analgesia with life-threatening respiratory depression. They have highly addictive potential. Newer generations of synthetic opioids exert variable actions on these receptors, i.e., as agonists, partial agonists, or competitive antagonists. 

The overall pattern of an agent's effect depends on the relative affinity for these receptors. Compared to morphine, such agents have limited analgesic properties, but they are advantageous in that they cause submaximal (low ceiling) respiratory depression and are less addictive. 

Methadone is a full μ-receptor agonist and has analgesic, respiratory depressant, emetic, antitussive, constipating, and biliary actions similar to morphine. It has an NMDA receptor antagonist activity and is used for maintenance therapy in rehab clinics.

Pentazocine is the first agonist-antagonist to be used as an analgesic. It is a partial agonist at mu receptor and has more marked K agonistic actions. Analgesia caused by pentazocine has a lower ceiling and is primarily spinal.

Buprenorphine is a highly lipid-soluble partial μ-opioid agonist and κ antagonist that is 25 times more potent than morphine but with lower intrinsic activity and ceiling effect.

Tramadol is an atypical opioid. Unlike other opioids, it inhibits the reuptake of NA and 5-HT, increases 5-HT release, and activates monoaminergic spinal inhibition of pain.

questions.text: You prescribe oral rehydration solution (ORS) to a child brought to the outpatient department with complaints of loose stools. ORS facilitates glucose absorption through sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter-1 (SGLT-1). This glucose co-transport with sodium ions is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Glucose co-transported with sodium is an example of secondary active transport.

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. As one of the substances (e.g., sodium) diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, energy is released, which is used to drive another substance (e.g., glucose) against the gradient. Thus, secondary active transport does not require energy directly from ATP.
 
Sodium ions are transported out of cells by primary active transport, resulting in a large concentration gradient across the cell membrane. This gradient represents a storehouse of energy, which is used by sodium to pull glucose along with it using the SGLT-1 transporter. This phenomenon, called co- transport, is one form of secondary active transport. 

Types of transport:

  • Active transport
    • Primary
      • Energy is derived from ATP.
      • Example: Na+ K+ ATPase pump.
    • Secondary:
      • Energy is derived indirectly (ion gradient).
      • Example: Sodium linked glucose transport in kidneys and intestine, Sodium linked iodine transport
  • Passive transport
    • Simple:
      • No energy is required.
      • No carrier molecule is involved.
      • Eg. O2 exchange in alveoli.
    • Facilitated:
      • No energy is required.
      • Carrier molecule involved.
      • Eg. Glucose transport by GLUT transporters.

questions.text: A child presents with a 1-month history of jaundice, dark urine, and right upper quadrant pain. On physical examination, the child appears mildly icteric. Laboratory tests show elevated conjugated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. MRCP reveals a fusiform dilation of the common bile duct, as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Type I choledochal cyst is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario and the image showing fusiform dilation of the common bile duct, which is suggestive of choledochal malformation.

The child presents with jaundice, dark urine, and right upper quadrant pain, which are characteristic symptoms of a choledochal cyst. Laboratory findings show elevated conjugated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase, indicating cholestasis.

Type I choledochal cysts are the most common type and involve fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree. They are frequently associated with anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction (APBJ), which leads to bile stasis, inflammation, and an increased risk of complications.

Type of choledochal cyst Surgical management
Type I -  fusiform dilatation of the bile duct (most common) Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II - saccular diverticulum from the common bile duct Diverticulectomy, cholecystectomy, and common bile duct repair
Type III- diverticulum within the pancreas, also known as choledochoceles ERCP + sphincterotomy 
Type IVa - multiple cysts (both intrahepatic and extrahepatic) Liver transplant
Type IVb - multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree Kasai procedure (Portoenterostomy)
Type V - multiple cysts involving only intrahepatic ducts (Caroli's disease) Liver transplant

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Feature

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: The above investigation was done as part of infertility evaluation to determine the nature of a pedunculated filling defect in the uterine cavity. What is the contrast agent used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a sonosalpingography or a saline infusion sonogram(SIS). SIS uses sterile saline as the contrast agent.

A saline infusion sonogram is a useful test used in infertility evaluation for the assessment of tubal patency and uterine cavity. Its procedure is as follows:

  1. Under TVS (trans-vaginal sonography) guidance, up to 200 ml of Saline is infused into the uterine cavity using a foley’s catheter in such a way that the bulb of the catheter prevents fluid from flowing out of the cavity.
  2. TVS is used to visualize saline flow through the tubes and gushing out from the fimbrial end. Tubal patency is also indicated by filling the Pouch of Douglas with saline.
  3. Air bubbles may be introduced into the cavity to see their movement through the tubes.

Hysterosalpingography(HSG) followed by laparoscopic chromopertubation is the investigation of choice for assessment and confirmation of tubal patency, respectively. However, saline infusion sonography has the following advantages compared to an HSG:

  • No radiation exposure
  • Better than HSG at differentiating submucous fibroid from polyp
  • Better at identifying the degree of submucous fibroid protruding into the cavity
  • Evaluation of endometrial masses
  • Complications and side effects are minimal

SIS is performed within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle, preferably on days 4,5,6, or whenever the endometrial layer is thinnest. This is done to avoid dislodging a potential pregnancy and avoid confusion of endometrial mass with a clot or missing endometrial masses due to confusion with physiological endometrial hyperplasia before menstruation.

Other Options:

Option B and D: Iodinated contrast agents such as Iohexol and Urograffin are used as contrast agents for hysterosalpingography (HSG). Below is an image of HSG:

Option C: Methylene blue is used in laparoscopic chromopertubation to evaluate tubal patency by looking for bilateral spillage from the tubes. Below is an image of laparoscopic chromopertubation.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for the below finding in a 3-year-old child who keeps bumping into furniture while walking?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows congenital cataracts of the zonular/lamellar variety. Vitamin D deficiency is believed to be an acquired cause of this condition.

Congenital cataract is a type of developmental cataract that presents at birth. Developmental cataracts are named so due to their proclivity to affect only the particular zone in the development of the lens. Zonular cataract is the most common type of developmental cataract that presents with visual acuity issues. The zone affected is the embryonic nucleus.

Well-demarcated opacities that appear like the spokes of a wheel(termed riders) are seen running toward the equator. It is usually bilateral. Possible implicated causes are:

  1. Genetic predisposition: Inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
  2. Vitamin D deficiency and coexisting Rickets
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Maternal Rubella in the 7th to 8th week of pregnancy.

The ideal time for dense cataract correction is within the first 2-4 months of life as visual fixation occurs at that time, and after that, more often than not, amblyopia will often result regardless of surgery done for dense cataracts. Lamellar cataract opacities are usually not very dense, but presentations can vary.

The decision to proceed with operative management or defer the treatment until later depends on the degree of opacity, pupillary dilation, and coexistent development of squint or nystagmus. All these factors decide when surgery may be performed. Dense, large, or symptomatic opacities are corrected by lens aspiration or lensectomy followed by insertion of a PMMA IOL. Visual outcomes in dense cataracts are usually not good and become worse with increasing age at correction.

questions.text: An IT professional was found to have vitamin D deficiency during a routine health check-up. He purchased vitamin D 60,000 IU sachets over-the-counter and started consuming them every day. After two weeks, he presented with severe colicky pain over the renal angle. His vitamin D levels are found to be elevated (170 ng/mL). Which of the following medications will be helpful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts vitamin D toxicity, which has led to hypercalcemia and renal stones. Among the given options, calcitonin can be used for the treatment of this condition.

Vitamin D toxicity occurs due to excessive intake of vitamin D supplements, usually in amounts of >40,000–100,000 IU/day. The symptoms are mainly due to hypercalcemia. Laboratory investigations will show elevated serum vitamin D levels (>100 ng/mL) and calcium.

In such patients, vitamin D supplements should be discontinued immediately, along with restricted exposure to the sun and avoiding calcium supplements. Since vitamin D is stored in the body for a long time, the symptoms may persist for some days even after stopping the intake.

Calcitonin and bisphosphonates are used in cases of severe toxicity causing hypercalcemia. Some patients might require glucocorticoids, which lower plasma calcium levels by reducing calcium absorption from the intestines and increasing its urinary excretion. 

Other options

Option B- Aspirin is used in the management of niacin-induced flushing.

Options C and D- Trientine and zinc are copper chelators. They are mainly used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with severe cramping in her legs while exercising in the gym. She has been experiencing these symptoms for the past few months. On examination, radial pulse is 88 beats/min, and distal pulses of the lower limb are barely palpable. Blood pressure is 144/88 mmHg in the right arm and 108/70 mmHg in the right leg. The obtained chest x-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and chest x-ray showing notching of ribs strongly point towards the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. According to the site of constriction, it is classified into the following types:

  • Preductal: constriction proximal to the ductus arteriosus (infantile type)
  • Postductal: constriction distal to the ductus arteriosus (adult type)

Clinical presentation of coarctation of the aorta depends on the extent of constriction and age at the presentation:

  • Infants with coarctation of the aorta may present with tachypnea, lethargy, failure to thrive, or overt congestive heart failure. Clinical signs classically worsen after the closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • Adults may present with non-specific symptoms, such as headaches and nose bleeds, or claudication of the lower limbs, which is experienced as cramping pain that increases on exertion.

Coarctation of the aorta is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, berry aneurysm, and Turner syndrome.

Physical examination findings:

  • Bounding upper limb pulses (radial, carotid) and weak lower limb pulses (femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis)
  • Increased radio-femoral delay
  • Hypertension in upper limbs and increased difference in blood pressure between upper and lower limbs
  • Continuous like murmur (due to collaterals)
  • Systolic ejection click and systolic ejection murmur in the left upper sternal border (due to bicuspid aortic valve)

Radiologic findings on chest x-ray:

  • Figure 3 sign - It is pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta. It occurs due to the indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre- and post-stenotic dilatation along the left para-mediastinum.
  • Notching of ribs - This occurs due to rib erosion by dilated collateral vessels.
  • Dilated left subclavian artery and dilated ascending aorta

It can be diagnosed using x-ray, CT or MRI, or cardiac catheterization. It is definitively managed surgically or with balloon dilation. 

The figure of 3 sign is shown in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A- Total anomalous pulmonary venous return is a clinical entity in which the pulmonary veins fail to enter the left atrium and instead drain into the right atrium or its systemic venous tributaries. It is classified into 4 types: supra-cardiac, cardiac, infracardiac, and mixed types. On chest radiography, the supra-cardiac type shows a characteristic snowman or figure of 8 appearance.

Option B- Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis involving the aorta and the pulmonary arteries, resulting in varying degrees of stenosis, occlusion, or dilatation. It can result in diminished or absent pulses, limb claudications, hypertension due to renal artery stenosis. Chest radiograph may reveal oligemic lung fields if pulmonary artery involvement occurs.

Option C- Ebstein anomaly is characterized by an abnormal tricuspid valve that is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis. Chest x-ray findings depend on the degree to which the tricuspid valve is displaced downwards. There is usually an enlarged right atrium, resulting in severe right-sided cardiomegaly, which gives a box-shaped heart appearance.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman conceived while she was on treatment for bipolar disorder and severe acne. Her baby was born at term with features including microtia, micrognathia, ventriculomegaly,  conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia. Which of the following drugs is responsible for these defects?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin is the teratogen that is responsible for the above-mentioned defects.

It is a vitamin A derivative that is highly teratogenic when orally administered. It is commonly used to treat cystic nodular acne. It inhibits the migration of neural crest cells during embryogenesis and affects the development of multiple organs. These defects are collectively termed retinoic acid embryopathy.

Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia.

Isotretinoin also increases the risk of spontaneous abortions and stillbirths by up to 40% in pregnancies exposed in the first quarter of this medicine. Presenting with pregnancy during treatment with isotretinoin is a failure of prevention strategies.

The guidelines for isotretinoin usage are as follows:

  • Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug that should not be taken during pregnancy and nursing
  • Patients should take 2 pregnancy tests before starting isotretinoin and take a monthly pregnancy test while on the medication and another test 1 month after stopping the medication.
  • Two forms of birth control should be simultaneously used starting 1 month before treatment, during the entire course of treatment, and for 1 month after ceasing treatment with isotretinoin.

Other options:

Option B: Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is a teratogen associated with Ebstein's anomaly, which is a rare cardiac condition characterized by severe tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlargement.

Option C: Valproic acid is the anti-epileptic which confers the greatest risk to the developing fetus while used in pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Option D: Tetracyclines are associated with yellowish-brown discolouration of deciduous teeth when used after 25 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: All of the following indicate MgSO4 toxicity in a patient receiving anti-convulsive MgSO4 therapy, except:
questions.solution:
Overdose of MgSO4 is associated with loss of patellar reflex. Hyperreflexia is not seen in MgSO4 toxicity.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labor. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L. 

Patients must be monitored for the signs of magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate at <12 breaths/min (Option B)
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, slurred speech, Somnolence, and drowsiness (Option C, D)

The following clinical features occur with the overdosage of MgSO4.

Clinical response Serum levels of magnesium (mEq/L)
Loss of patellar reflex 8-12
Warmth and flushing 9-12
Somnolence 10-12
Slurred speech 10-12
Paralysis and respiratory difficulty 15-17
Cardiac arrest 30-35

Management of magnesium toxicity is as follows:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Intravenous injection of calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution)

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about Morgagni diaphragmatic hernia?

choices.text: Duodenum is the most common viscus involved
Located in the anterior part of the diaphragm
Due to failure of pleuroperitoneal membrane closure
Most infants with Morgagni hernia are symptomatic

questions.solution:
Morgagni's diaphragmatic hernia is usually located in the anterior part of the diaphragm.

The foramen of Morgagni is present in the anterior part of the diaphragm (a defect between the sternal and costal attachments). Morgagni diaphragmatic hernia is a type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The most commonly involved viscus in Morgagni hernia is the transverse colon. The diagnosis of Morgagni hernia is often delayed till childhood as most infants are asymptomatic.

Herniation through the foramen of Bochdalek which is in the dome of the diaphragm posteriorly, is due to the failure of pleuroperitoneal membrane closure.

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman commits suicide by jumping into the village lake. Which of the following is not associated with the death of this woman?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a case of freshwater drowning where death is rapid, occurring within four to five minutes. Hence, the statement that death occurs within 8-10 minutes is incorrect.

When a person drowns in freshwater, 2.5 L or more may be inhaled in 3 minutes, increasing blood volume by 50%. It leads to hypervolemia and hemodilution. Hemodilution leads to hemolysis, myocardial hypoxia, hemoglobinuria, marked hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Freshwater denatures the protective surfactant that lines the alveolar wall.

Pulmonary surfactant (lipoprotein) gets inactivated, and, alveoli collapse, lung compliance decreases, which results in a severe ventilation-perfusion mismatch. If the person survives, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) may result. Severe hypotension may occur during and after the initial resuscitation period. 

In freshwater drowning, the following are seen which results in death in 3-5 minutes:

  • anoxia
  • a disturbed sodium-potassium ratio producing arrhythmias
  • ventricular tachycardia 
  • fibrillation.
In cases of seawater drowning, hypernatremia and myocardial anoxia are seen. Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a fluid shift from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary oedema. A net decrease in blood volume causes hemoconcentration and a fall in blood pressure. This hemoconcentration in seawater drowning causes increased viscosity of blood and myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure. Hyperkalemia is not seen in seawater drowning because RBCs get shrunken in contrast to freshwater drowning. Death occurs after about 8 to 10 minutes in the case of seawater drowning.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with breathlessness, cough with purulent sputum, and a high-grade fever. On examination, the patient is tachypnoeic with SpO2 of 91% at room air, crackles and wheezing are present in the right lower lung fields. Chest x-ray shows consolidation in the right lower lobe. CBC shows leukocytosis, microscopy reveals gram-negative rods, and sputum culture is awaited. The patient has a history of severe allergy to penicillins and cephalosporins. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with symptoms and findings consistent with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), likely caused by a gram-negative organism. Given her history of severe allergies to penicillins and cephalosporins, the most appropriate antibiotic choice would be Aztreonam.

Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic (an atypical beta-lactam antibiotic) in which the other ring is missing, but it acts by binding to specific penicillin-binding proteins. It has a narrow spectrum of action against gram-negative enteric bacilli and H. influenza at very low concentrations and Pseudomonas at moderate concentrations. Its spectrum resembles aminoglycosides and is resistant to gram-negative beta-lactamases.

The main indications are hospital-acquired infections originating from urinary, gastrointestinal, biliary, or female genital tracts. Lack of cross-sensitivity with other beta-lactam antibiotics except ceftazidime (which has a chemical similarity to aztreonam) is an important feature that allows its use in patients allergic to penicillins or cephalosporins. Rashes and raised serum aminotransferases are notable side effects. 

Other options:

Option B: Metronidazole is an antibiotic targeting anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa.

Option C: Linezolid cannot be used in our patient because it is an oxazolidinone antibiotic that is effective against gram-positive bacteria (e.g., methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)).

Option D: Vancomycin cannot be used in our patient because she has a gram-negative rod causing pneumonia, which is not targeted by vancomycin. Vancomycin is primarily effective against gram-positive bacteria.

questions.text: The “Vasomotor reversal of Dale” phenomenon is seen with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
The vasomotor reversal of Dale is seen with adrenaline when an alpha blocker like phentolamine has been previously administered.

Rapid IV injection of adrenaline produces a marked increase in both systolic as well as diastolic BP. This occurs because at high concentrations α response predominates and vasoconstriction occurs. As the concentration declines, adrenaline is not able to act on α receptors but continues to act on β2 receptors.

When an α blocker has been given and then adrenaline is injected, only a fall in BP instead of an initial rise is seen, an effect first described by Dale and hence called vasomotor reversal of Dale. This is due to adrenaline's action only on β2 receptors, which are not blocked by phentolamine.

Noradrenaline and dopamine lack beta 2 action, and vasomotor reversal of the Dale phenomenon is not seen with them.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with difficulty seeing distant objects. Fundal examination reveals temporal myopic crescent, lattice degeneration, and tigroid appearance. Which of the following pathologies is the hallmark of this patient's disease?

1, 2, 3, and 4 in the image given above represent different types of staphylomas.
questions.solution:
Difficulty seeing distant objects and the given findings on fundal examination point to the diagnosis of pathological myopia. The hallmark of pathological myopia is posterior staphyloma.

In the given image:

2: Ciliary staphyloma

  • Anomalous optic nerve head with tilted conformation
  • Acquired optic disc pit formation
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Lacquer cracks are fine, irregular yellow lines crisscrossing at the posterior pole due to ruptures in the Bruch membrane.
  • Subretinal coin hemorrhages develop from lacquer cracks.
  • Fuchs spot: It is a raised, circular, pigmented scar at the macula that develops after absorption of subretinal hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman arrives at the hospital in active labor. She has a known history of HIV, but her prenatal care has been sporadic, and she admits that she has not been compliant with her antiretroviral therapy throughout the pregnancy. Shortly after delivery, the newborn appears stable, and you are consulted on the next step in managing this infant. What would be the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Start Nevirapine and Zidovudine prophylaxis immediately
Start Zidovudine, Nevirapine, and Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis immediately

questions.solution:
This scenario depicts a high-risk infant for HIV, and prophylaxis with Nevirapine with Zidovudine should be started immediately. Immediate postnatal ART prophylaxis is crucial in reducing HIV transmission risk and improving long-term health outcomes in exposed infants.

Mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV is the primary route of pediatric HIV infection, occurring during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding. High-risk infants are those born to individuals who did not achieve sustained virologic suppression, started combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) late in pregnancy, or were diagnosed with acute or primary HIV during pregnancy, increasing the risk of perinatal HIV transmission.

Risk Factors for MTCT: 

  • High maternal viral load
  • Advanced maternal HIV disease or primary infection during pregnancy
  • Rupture of membranes for more than four hours
  • No maternal ART use
  • Chorioamnionitis or placenta previa

Diagnosis in infants under 18 months requires HIV DNA/RNA PCR testing at 6 weeks using a dried blood spot test. If positive, confirmation is needed with a second whole blood test. Antibody tests are unreliable before 18 months due to passive maternal antibody transfer.

The National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) recommends a lifelong Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenzregimen for all pregnant and breastfeeding women, regardless of CD4 count or disease stage. For high-risk infants, a two-drug regimen (Zidovudine + Nevirapine) is advised if the mother has had ART for less than 4 weeks or has a high viral load. Additionally, Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis should begin at 4-6 weeks and continue until HIV is excluded at 18 months. Isoniazid prophylaxis is recommended for HIV-infected infants without active tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the casualty with an injury to his leg. On examination, bruises and ecchymoses of varying ages are noted all over the body. The x-ray shows a spiral fracture of the femur. Which of the following is less likely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Head injury as the most common cause of death

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with a spiral fracture of the femur and bruises of various ages points to a diagnosis of battered baby syndrome, where evidence of strangling or stabbing is less likely to be seen.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. The syndrome is also known as child abuse syndrome, non-accidental injury of childhood, Caffey's syndrome, and maltreatment syndrome in children.

The syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury vary with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Classical features:

  • Multiple bruises, lacerations, and abrasions of varying ages and shapes all over the body
  • Round pitted burns from cigarette stubs
  • Tear of the frenulum resulting from efforts to silence a crying or screaming child
  • Infantile whiplash syndrome - subdural hematoma and intraocular bleeding as a result of shaking the child, as described by Caffey
  • Subgaleal hematoma
  • Traumatic alopecia, appearing as bald patches
  • Perforations and rupture of abdominal viscera
  • Retinal separation, vitreous, subconjunctival, and retinal haemorrhages and black eye

Skeletal injuries that are commonly seen:

  • Skull fractures
  • Large periosteal hematomas
  • Epiphyseal separation and periosteal shearing in the limbs
  • Transverse and spiral fractures of long bones - Due to compression, bending, and direct forcible blows
  • Fractures of ribs in the midaxillary line due to anteroposterior compression of the chest
  • Fractures at the costochondral junctions due to violent squeezing of the chest from side to side
  • Multiple rib fractures (called knobbing fractures) along the posterior angles of the ribs, in the paravertebral gutter, giving rise to the string-of-beads appearance on x-ray (Option B)

A skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

Head injury is the most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome (Option C), followed by rupture of an abdominal organ(Option D).

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with sudden onset dysarthria and impaired sensation over the left side of his face. Further examination shows loss of pain and temperature on the right side of the body. When asked to walk in a straight line, he falls to the left side. Based on further workup, a vascular etiology is suspected. Identify the most likely blood vessel to be involved in the given condition:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome). The most likely blood vessel to be involved in this condition would be the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (marked as 2), which is a branch of the vertebral artery.

Lateral medullary syndrome: The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal nerve)—Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – Ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb) with falling towards ipsilateral to the lesion
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body
  • IX and X CN (nucleus ambiguus) - Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysarthria and dysphagia
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis)

Other options: 

Option B: (3) represents the anterior inferior cerebellar artery which if occluded may result in stroke involving the lateral inferior pontine region. Ipsilaterally, it causes lower motor neuron facial weakness, loss of lacrimation and salivation, loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, loss of corneal reflex (CN VII nucleus and nerve), Hearing loss and tinnitus (Cochlear nuclei), Loss of pain and temperature from the face (Nucleus of trigeminal nerve). Contralaterally, it causes loss of pain and temperature sensation from the body (Spinothalamic tract).

Option C: (1) represents the posterior cerebral artery, if thrombosed may result in midbrain syndromes like Weber's and Benedikt’s syndromes.

Option D: (4) represents the anterior spinal artery, which, if occluded may result in medial medullary syndrome. It causes Ipsilateral XII palsy (tongue deviation to the paralyzed side), contralateral decrease in proprioception, vibration, and fine touch sensation (medial lemniscus involvement), contralateral hеmiраresis (lateral corticospinal tract involvement).

questions.text: A sleep pattern of a patient with hypersomnia is being studied. During rapid eye movement sleep, it was observed that the activity of the locus ceruleus of the brain was suppressed. What likely change is expected at the level of a neurotransmitter associated with it?
questions.solution:
Locus coeruleus secrets norepinephrine. A decrease in norepinephrine is the expected change in the case of suppression of locus coeruleus.

The brainstem ascending arousal system is composed of several groups of neurons:

  • Locus coeruleus secrets norepinephrine
  • Raphe nucleus  secretes serotonin
  • Pontine nucleus secretes acetylcholine

During wakefulness, the locus coeruleus and raphe nucleus are dominant and the pontine is suppressed. Therefore, when a person is awake, the levels of norepinephrine and serotonin are increased, while that of acetylcholine is decreased. There is also a decrease in GABA levels and increased histamine levels when the person is awake.

REM sleep occurs when the pontine nucleus is dominant and locus coeruleus & raphe nucleus are suppressed. Therefore, acetylcholine is increased and norepinephrine and serotonin are decreased. Non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep occurs when there is suppression of the thalamus and cortex due to an increase in GABA and a decrease in histamine.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with sudden onset, tearing chest pain that radiates to the back. Blood pressure in right arm is 110/80, left arm is 160/100. An ascending thoracic dissection is suspected and he is given labetalol, but continues to have severe chest pain. He develops breathlessness and hypotension with jugular venous distention.  What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a type A dissection that has extended to cause a cardiac tamponade due to hemopericardium. The next step in his management would be to perform a pericardiocentesis.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output. The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade are:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus - paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) on inspiration.
  • Beck's triad - hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure with prominent x descent and absent y descent. The sensitivity of jugular venous distention in detecting tamponade is 100%.

ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans; an Echocardiogram shows a swinging heart sign.

In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. Definitive management includes emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy 

Risk factors for aortic dissection:
1. Hypertension (most common risk factor)
2. Atherosclerosis (second most common risk factor)
3. Known/prior aortic aneurysm or dissection
5. Diabetes 
6. Marfan syndrome
7. Cocaine use, particularly in younger patients.

An aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear, which allows blood to penetrate the medial layer, producing a cleavage plane (false lumen) between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of the media. The true lumen is separated from the false lumen by an intimomedial flap.

Predisposing factors for aortic dissection are:

  • Age
  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Pregnancy
  • Other connective tissue disorders, for example, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Turner or Noonan syndromes
  • Aortic cannulation site (iatrogenic)

Clinical features:

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain.
The tracheal tug sign, also known as Oliver’s sign, is seen in the arch of the aorta aneurysm.

The dissection can extend distally down the aorta to involve the:

  • Renal arteries (renal pain and renal failure)
  • Mesenteric arteries (abdominal pain and bowel ischemia)
  • Spinal arteries (paraplegia)
  • Iliac arteries (leg pain, pallor, loss or reduced pulses, and limb ischemia).
  • The dissection may track proximally to involve the:Head and neck vessels (symptoms and signs of a stroke or transient ischaemic attack)
  • Coronary vessels (MI)
  • Aortic root (aortic regurgitation)

On examination, unequal pulses or blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. There can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, and pulmonary edema. 

Imaging: 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient. In hemodynamically stable patients, the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. 

Treatment options:

Stanford type A (DeBakey types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.
Stanford type B (DeBakey type III) is best managed by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

Option A: Chest tube insertion would be appropriate for a pneumothorax, which is unlikely in this case. A tension pneumothorax may present with signs of hypotension and jugular venous distention, but there would be a tracheal deviation and hyper resonance to percussion.

Option C: Nitroglycerin may be useful to further lowering blood pressure. It would not be helpful in this case, the dissection has extended to cause a tamponade and needs pericardiocentesis.

Option D: Aortic dissection can extend to involve the coronary arteries and cause a myocardial infarction, which would warrant a coronary angiography, however, it is unlikely in this case, given the presence of Beck's triad and low voltage complexes. On EKG, ST changes would be expected.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a parapharyngeal abscess. Which of the following is not a part of the lateral relation of this space?
questions.solution:
The lateral pharyngeal wall forms the medial relation of the posterior compartment of the parapharyngeal space, not the lateral relation.

The parapharyngeal space (PPS) is a pyramidal space with its base at the base of the skull and its apex at the hyoid bone. Relations of the PPS are:

  • Medial: Buccopharyngeal fascia covering constrictor muscles
  • Posterior: Prevertebral fascia covering prevertebral muscles and cervical transverse processes
  • Lateral: Medial pterygoid muscle, mandible, and deep surface of the parotid gland

The parapharyngeal space (PPS) is divided into anterior and posterior compartments by the styloid process and attached muscles.

  • Anterior compartment: Medially related to the tonsillar fossa and laterally related to the medial pterygoid muscle
  • Posterior compartment: Medially related to the posterior part of the lateral pharyngeal wall and laterally related to the parotid gland

The image attached below shows the compartments and components of the parapharyngeal space.

The parapharyngeal space (PPS) is clinically significant because it is at risk of infection spreading to the mediastinum, leading to life-threatening mediastinitis. Abscesses in this space can cause airway obstruction, cranial nerve palsies, and vascular complications like internal jugular vein thrombosis or carotid artery rupture. 

Diagnosis of parapharyngeal abscess can be established using a CECT. Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and carbapenem antibiotics, as well as drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few centimeters below the angle of the mandible, followed by blunt dissection.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient was brought to the casualty ward with pain in the abdomen and obstipation. He has recently undergone L4-L5 laminectomy for disc herniation. On abdominal examination there was absent peristalsis. The abdominal CT image is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly patient with clinical and imaging features of intestinal obstruction and absent peristalsis is suggestive of adynamic intestinal obstruction. Hence, among the given options, the likely answer is Ogilvie's syndrome. All the other options are examples of dynamic intestinal obstruction.

Ogilvie's syndrome, also known as colonic pseudo-obstruction, is a functional disorder characterized by a massively dilated colon without any mechanical obstruction. It is usually associated with narcotics, bed rest, recent surgery, trauma, cardiovascular disease, and severe infection. CT typically shows marked colonic dilation, especially in the cecum and right colon, without a mechanical obstruction.

Conservative management is indicated in mildly symptomatic patients with cecal dilation <12 cm. It is managed conservatively with nasogastric decompression with fluid and electrolyte resuscitation. Serial abdominal X-rays and USG may be taken to assess improvement. 

Intestinal obstruction may be classified into two types:

1. Dynamic obstruction: in which peristalsis is working against a mechanical obstruction. It may occur in an acute or a chronic form. Based on the site of obstruction, it is further classified as:

  • Intraluminal
    • Fecal impaction  (Option B)
    • Foreign bodies Bezoars
    • Gallstones
  • Intramural
    • Stricture

questions.text: An elderly woman who is a known diabetic comes with frequent urination, and an increased urge to pass the urine, but passes urine in large quantities before reaching the lavatory. Which of the following autonomic dysregulation explains her symptoms?

choices.text: Detrusor muscle instability due to sympathetic overactivity
Detrusor muscle instability due to parasympathetic overactivity
Sphincter relaxation due to sympathetic overactivity
Sphincter contraction due to parasympathetic overactivity

questions.solution:
The patient here is suffering from urge incontinence/overactive bladder due to detrusor muscle instability. It is caused by parasympathetic overactivity.

The urinary bladder is innervated by three nervous systems:

  • Sympathetic efferent fibers from L1-L3 segments of the spinal cord to the wall of the bladder - associated with detrusor relaxation (option A) and contraction of sphincter (Option D)
  • Parasympathetic efferent fibers from S2-S4 of the spinal cord to the detrusor muscle. Plays major role in micturition reflex by causing contraction of the detrusor muscle, relaxation of sphincter (option C) and empties the bladder.
  • Pudendal nerves: It carries somatic impulses from S2-S4 segments of the spinal cord to the external sphincter. It is involved in the voluntary control of micturition.  

Incontinence happens when the detrusor muscle contracts on provocation/spontaneously during the filling phase when inhibition of micturition is attempted. It is mostly caused by parasympathetic overactivity, seen most commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity.

Causes of detrusor instability are functional/psychosomatic, diabetic neuropathy, cerebrovascular accidents, multiple sclerosis, spinal injury, parkinsonism, urinary infection, which can occur following surgeries, etc

  1. Lithium toxicity in a patient with bipolar disorder

questions.text:
The suture application shown in the given image will be most useful in the management of which of the following conditions?

(PPH- Postpartum hemorrhage)

choices.text: PPH caused due to  HELLP syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a B-lynch suture. It is most useful in the management of PPH caused due to polyhydramnios.

It is a technique to control severe atonic postpartum hemorrhage, which can occur as a result of polyhydramnios. B-lynch suture involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which oppose the anterior and posterior walls of the uterus. This leads to compression of the fundus and the lower uterine segment, thereby controlling the hemorrhage.

Predisposing factors for PPH are:

  • Atonic PPH:
    • Grand multipara
    • Previous history of PPH
    • Overdistented uterus: multifetal gestation, polyhydramnios, macrosomia
    • Precipitate labor, prolonged labor
    • Uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
    • Labor induction or augmentation with oxytocin
    • Placental anomalies: Placenta previa/ accreta/ increta/ percreta/ abruptio placenta
  • Traumatic PPH:
    • Instrumental deliveries
    • Episiotomy
  • PPH due to Coagulopathy:
    • Sepsis
    • IUD
    • HELLP syndrome

For PPH due to Coagulopathy - transfusion of blood products such as Fresh frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate, platelet concenterate is given.

questions.text: A 31-year-old primigravida came to the emergency room with nausea and severe pain in the abdomen. On examination, she had tenderness in the right iliac fossa; however, she was afebrile. Ultrasound with graded compression and non-contrast MRI were negative for appendicitis. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: CECT abdomen and pelvis with high-risk consent
Observation and regular monitoring in the ward
Diagnostic laparoscopy to look for another cause
Appendicectomy due to high clinical suspicion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a pregnant female shows a clinical suspicion of acute appendicitis but has negative imaging findings. Observation and regular monitoring in the ward should be done in this case.

Appendicitis is the most common non-obstetric emergency in pregnancy and the most common cause of general surgical intervention in pregnancy. Fifty percent of cases present in the second trimester.

The signs and symptoms, such as fever, nausea, and vomiting, are unreliable in pregnancy. Similarly, pregnancy is associated with mild leucocytosis and elevated CRP, making these serological tests inconclusive. Finally, round ligament pain due to uterine stretching presents with very similar features to lower quadrant pain. This makes diagnosis difficult.

Imaging is initially done with a USG with graded compression in the left lateral decubitus or left posterior oblique positions. If inconclusive, non-contrast MRI is an excellent modality to confirm the diagnosis if there is enough time to undergo the procedure. CT with the lowest radiation dose possible may also be attempted.

Complications of appendicitis include preterm labor and fetal loss. Surgical management of appendicitis is done by laparoscopic appendicectomy.

In ambiguous or inconclusive imaging cases, observation and regular monitoring in the ward are done. During observation, if the patient's condition improves, discharge can be planned. But if it worsens, diagnostic laparoscopy is indicated, as shown in the flowchart given below.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with type 1 diabetes mellitus has been brought to the emergency room with vomiting and abdominal pain for the past 12 hours. On examination, he is tachycardic and tachypneic and looks dehydrated. You ordered an arterial blood gas for him, which showed a pH of 7.1, serum bicarbonate of 12 meq/L, and blood glucose of 420 mg/dl. In this clinical scenario, which of the following enzymes is the rate-limiting step in the pathway responsible for his state?
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation is highly suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a complication of insulin deficiency. HMG-CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketogenesis, which produces ketone bodies in diabetic ketoacidosis. 

Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) is a life-threatening complication of Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) caused by insulin deficiency. It leads to hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. Without insulin, cells cannot use glucose, triggering lipolysis and ketogenesis (due to the upregulation of hormone-sensitive lipase). Ketosis results from a marked increase in free fatty acid release from adipocytes, with a shift toward ketone body synthesis in the liver.

HMG-CoA synthase catalyzes the conversion of acetoacetyl-CoA to HMG-CoA, a crucial step in ketone body production. This is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketogenesis, making it the key enzyme responsible for the metabolic state observed in DKA. This results in high blood glucose (>250 mg/dL), low pH, and anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Patients present with polyuria, dehydration, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and Kussmaul breathing. DKA is often triggered by infection, missed insulin doses, or stress.

Diagnosis is based on high glucose, acidosis, and ketonemia. Treatment includes IV fluids, insulin therapy, and electrolyte replacement to prevent complications like cerebral edema and shock.

Other options:

Option A: Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis.

Option C: Pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA for the TCA cycle, which is inhibited in DKA due to low insulin.

Option D: HMG-CoA lyase converts HMG-CoA into acetoacetate but is not the rate-limiting step in ketogenesis.

questions.solution:
The movement disorder depicted in the above image is hemiballismus, most commonly caused by a partial lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

Ballism is a severe choreiform movement disorder characterized by wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements, primarily affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body (hemiballismus). It can also involve a single limb (monoballism) or, in rare cases, both upper or lower limbs (paraballism). The movements can be intense, leading to exhaustion, dehydration, injury, or even death in extreme cases.

The most common cause is a partial lesion in the subthalamic nucleus (STN) due to infarction or hemorrhage. The subthalamic nucleus usually excites the globus pallidus internus, which inhibits the thalamus. Damage to this nucleus reduces the inhibition of the thalamus, resulting in excessive movement. However, dopamine-blocking drugs are often effective, and the condition is usually self-limiting, resolving within weeks to months. In severe cases, pallidotomy or deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the globus pallidus internus (GPi) can help control symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding placental estrogen biosynthesis is true?

choices.text: Placental 17 alpha-hydroxylase converts progesterone to estrogen
Placental aromatase deficiency leads to virilism in mother
The primary source of androgen for estrogen synthesis is the maternal adrenal gland

questions.solution:
Placental aromatase deficiency leads to virilism in the mother due to the accumulation of androgenic compounds.

The biosynthesis of estrogen in the placenta is complex and indirect. The steps are as follows:

  • Firstly, the placenta lacks the enzyme 17 alpha-hydroxylase. Hence, maternal progestogens and precursors cannot aid in estrogen synthesis
  • Secondly, the source of estrogen precursor in such a condition becomes DHEA and DHEA sulfate
  • Thirdly, this fetal DHEA is converted to estrogen by the placental enzymes: Sulfatase, Aromatase, and 3 HSD (3 hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase)

DHEA and DHEA sulfate are derived primarily from the fetal adrenal gland and a very small fraction from the maternal adrenal gland. Fetal adrenal insufficiency would thus cause low estrogen levels in that pregnancy

Deficiency of any of the three enzymes (Sulfatase, Aromatase, 3HSD) results in low estrogen levels in the pregnancy. The DHEA produced by the fetus is converted to androstenedione but cannot become estrogen in the absence of aromatase. This androgen excess causes virilization of the mother and fetus. The female fetus is born with ambiguous genitalia due to the action of androgens.

Other effects of aromatase deficiency include low estrogen levels in pregnancy, resulting in post-term pregnancy due to a lack of sufficient estrogen for the uterus to become primed for parturition.

Other Options:

Option A: As previously mentioned, the placenta does not have 17 alpha-hydroxylase enzyme. Hence, it cannot convert progestogens into estrogen.

Option C: The primary source of androgens for estrogen biosynthesis is from the fetal adrenal glands. The maternal adrenal gland acts as a secondary source of a small amount of DHEA.

Option D: Qualitatively, the most specific estrogen in pregnancy is Estriol, not Estrone. Placental estrogen synthesized from DHEA is Estriol.

questions.text: The strength of sewage is being measured in an industrial area. The sewage water being tested shows increased toxic substances. The organic load of this sewage water with toxins, is best measured by which of the following parameters?
questions.solution:
If the sewage water contains toxins, the organic load is best measured by the chemical oxygen demand.

The strength of sewage is a measure of the amount of dissolved and suspended solids in it. It's determined by measuring the sewage's biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), chemical oxygen demand (COD), and suspended solids (TSS). 

COD determines the amount of oxidizable pollutants. It measures the oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidizer. A sample of wastewater is digested with a chemical oxidant, usually potassium dichromate, in an acidic solution. The sample is heated, and the amount of oxidation is measured using a colorimeter.

COD can measure all organic contaminants, including those that are toxic to biological life. Hence, COD is the most important indicator of pollution for industrial effluents. Biochemical oxygen demand relies on microorganisms to break down organic matter. However, the presence of toxins can inhibit microbial activity, leading to an underestimation of the organic load.

Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) consist of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. It is used to assess drinking water quality, not the strength of sewage. TDS <600 mg/litre is considered to be good and >1200mg/litre is considered unpalatable. 

Related Pearl: Strength of Sewage

The strength of sewage is expressed by the following.

  • Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD):
    • It is the standard test which is an indicator of the organic content of sewage
    • It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage during a specified period (generally 5 days), at a specified temperature (generally 20 deg.C) for the aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living microorganisms.
    • A high BOD (300 mg/l) indicates a high content of easily degradable, organic material while a low BOD (100mg/l) indicates the presence of content that is not easily degradable, low volume of organic matter or measurement problems.
  • Chemical oxygen demand (COD):
    • This test measures the oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidizer
    • This is mostly used when sewage contains toxic wastes
  • Suspended solids:
    • The amount of suspended solids in sewage may vary from 100 to 500 ppm (mg/litre)
    • If the level of suspended solids is 100 ppm, then sewage is weak and if it is more than 500 ppm, sewage is strong.

questions.text: A 9-month-old male baby presents with recurrent respiratory tract infections for the last 3 months. Blood investigations show the absence of mature B cells and reduced levels of immunoglobulins. The structure marked with the arrow in the given image is underdeveloped in the patient. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the germinal center. Recurrent infections, absence of mature B cells, reduced immunoglobulins, and hypoplastic germinal centers point to a diagnosis of X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton agammaglobulinemia) is an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the failure of B-cell precursors (pro-B and pre-B cells) to develop into mature B-cells. It is caused by a mutation in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk) located on the long arm of the X chromosome (Xq21.22). The features of the disease are - 

  • Mature B cells and plasma cells are absent or markedly reduced
  • Decreased levels of all classes of Immunoglobulins
  • Germinal centers are underdeveloped in lymph nodes, peyer's patches, and tonsils
  • T-cell-mediated reactions are normal
  • The disease usually becomes apparent after 6 months of age since it is masked by the presence of maternal antibodies until 6 months of age.

The patient has recurrent pharyngitis, otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus, and Hemophilus influenzae. Gastrointestinal infections can occur by viruses or Giardia lamblia due to reduced IgA secretion. 

The treatment is replacement therapy with immunoglobulins in the form of prophylactic intravenous IgG therapy.

Other Options:

Option B: DiGeorge syndrome is a disease caused by the failure to develop third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. The characteristic features seen are T-cell deficiency due to thymic hypoplasia, tetany due to lack of parathyroids, and congenital defects of the heart and great vessels.

Option C: Hyper IgM syndrome is due to deficiency of the CD40 ligand, and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. It has elevated levels of IgM and decreased/negligible levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE.

Option D: SCID has defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immunity. SCID involves defects in both T and B cell development, leading to severe infections early in life. The absence of mature B cells alone is not sufficient to diagnose SCID. There are two types of SCID:

  • X-linked SCID—the most common form with a mutation in the common gamma chain subunit of cytokine receptors
  • Autosomal recessive SCID—deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase

questions.text: A young man presents with painful swelling and redness of his right testis. On examination, the epididymis is tender, swollen, and erythematous, and Prehn sign is positive. There is no discharge from the urethra. Which of the following is an appropriate antibiotic?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain, swelling of the epididymis and a positive Prehn's sign likely has epididymitis and is best treated with Ceftriaxone.

Epididymitis is usually caused by sexually transmitted bacteria in younger men or urinary pathogens in older men. Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men (>40 years) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from a urinary infection, most commonly caused by Escherichia coli.

Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and tenderness of the epididymis, with or without symptoms or signs of urethritis

Prehn’s sign differentiates testes torsion from acute epididymitis. In the latter, the pain is relieved by elevating the testis.

Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support. Treatment with antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone and/or doxycycline, is effective for STB-related epididymitis, while levofloxacin or ofloxacin is effective for epididymitis caused by Enterobacteriaceae.

Treatment:

  • Younger men: Ceftriaxone (500 mg as a single dose IM) followed by Doxycycline (100 mg by mouth twice daily for 10 days)
  • Older men: Oral Levofloxacin (500 mg once daily for 10 days) or Ofloxacin (300 mg twice daily for 10 days) if Enterobacteriaceae infection is suspected.

Options B and C: Are effective against gram-positive bacteria and anaerobes and are not appropriate for epididymitis.

Option D: TMP-SMX is a second-line antibiotic for epididymitis.
