questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with persistent soreness of the nipple of the right breast. A crusted red, eczematous rash is present on the areola of the right breast. Histopathology shows malignant cells scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. All of the following are true about this disease except _________

choices.text: A palpable mass is never seen
Prognosis depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma
It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. A palpable mass is seen in about half the patients with Paget disease of the nipple.

Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare manifestation of breast cancer that presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with a scale crust, which could be mistaken for eczema. Histology shows malignant cells (Paget cells), with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei, scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium.

Paget cells do not breach the basement membrane, they rather extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin.The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma.

The histology of Paget's disease of the nipple is shown in the image below.

Note: Paget cells may resemble the cells of superficial spreading melanoma, but they are periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive - Diastase resistant (i.e. stain is present after diastase predigestion), unlike melanoma cells.

Lateral point: Paget disease of the bone is a disorder of locally increased but disordered and structurally unsound bone mass.

Paget disease of the nipple is not same as Paget disease of the bone.

questions.text: On your first day of surgery posting in operation theater, you notice the following machine. The Anaethesiologist explains you that it is a continuous flow type machine, which delivers variable mixture of anaesthetic gases throughout the breathing cycle. Identify the given anaesthesia machine.
questions.solution:
The machine shown in the image is Boyle's machine. It is a type of continuous-flow machine.

Types of anesthesia machines:

1. Continuous flow: Gas flows during both inspiration and expiration ( delivers a variable mixture of anesthetic gases throughout the breathing cycle)

  • Boyle's apparatus
  • Foregger
  • Heidbrink

2. Intermittent flow: Gas flows only during inspiration ( delivers gas only when inhaled)

  • Entonox apparatus (Option B) - Delivers a fixed mixture of 50% nitrous oxide and 50% oxygen
  • McKesson's apparatus (Option C)

Boyle's machine was invented by Henry Edmund Gaskin Boyle in 1917. Although a lot of changes have been made to the original Boyle apparatus, the basic structure of the anesthesia workstation remains the same.

Horrock's apparatus (Option D) is a device used to determine the amount of chlorine needed to disinfect water. It is not related to the anesthesia workstation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P3L3 lady complained of bright red bleeding per vagina 15 days after the vaginal delivery of her 3rd baby. All of the following options could be the likely cause of this bleeding except?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with bright red vaginal bleeding on the 15th day postpartum is secondary postpartum hemorrhage, which can be caused by endometritis, placental polyp, and retained placental cotyledon. Atonic uterus is the most common cause of primary PPH.

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) can be subdivided into primary PPH and secondary PPH. Primary PPH is bleeding that occurs within 24 hours of the delivery of the baby. Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) occurring between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery is called secondary or late PPH.

Causes of primary PPH are atony, trauma, coagulopathy, and retained tissues. The atonic uterus can be caused by numerous factors that interfere with the contraction and retraction of the uterus.

Causes of secondary PPH include:

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

Though retained tissue such as placental cotyledon is the most common cause of secondary PPH, it may interfere with uterine retraction and lead to primary PPH.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with fever, joint pain, and fatigue for 2 weeks. Erythematous skin lesions are noted over the trunk and subcutaneous nodules on the extensor aspect of the arms. A diagnosis of rheumatic fever is made. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: The presence of Aschoff bodies confirms chronic rheumatic heart disease
Group A streptococcal pharyngitis triggers an autoimmune reaction causing pancarditis
Anitschkow cells are fibroblasts associated with acute rheumatic fever
The mitral valve is typically spared in this condition

questions.solution:
Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is preceded by group A streptococcal pharyngitis, which triggers an autoimmune reaction causing pancarditis.

ARF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease that typically develops a few weeks after an infection with Group A streptococcus (GAS). It is caused by an autoimmune reaction triggered by molecular mimicry between group A streptococcal antigens that cross-react with host tissues. The disease manifests with a combination of major symptoms, including

  • Migratory polyarthritis
  • Pancarditis
  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Sydenham chorea

Acute RF is particularly common in children aged 5-15 years, and each subsequent episode increases the risk of chronic valvular damage, with the mitral valve most frequently affected.

The myocardial biopsy reveals foci of mononuclear cells with plump activated macrophages containing caterpillar cells. The hallmark of acute rheumatic fever is the Aschoff body, a granulomatous lesion found in the heart comprising T lymphocytes, plasma cells, and activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, also known as caterpillar cells due to their wavy chromatin. The myocardial biopsy is shown in the image given below.

Pancarditis is common, with inflammation affecting all three layers of the heart. The mitral and aortic valves often show small vegetation along their closure lines, known as verrucae. Chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD) results from the healing and scarring of acute lesions, leading to characteristic mitral stenosis with thickened, fused leaflets and shortened chordae tendineae.

Other options:

Option A: Aschoff bodies are seen in acute, not chronic, rheumatic heart disease.

Option C: Anitschkow cells, seen in Aschoff bodies, are modified macrophages and not fibroblasts.

Option D: The mitral valve is the most commonly affected in rheumatic heart disease, often leading to mitral stenosis in adults.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of the presence of blood streaks and mucosal discharge in the stool. For the past 4 days, he has felt a soft mass descending per rectum. The histology of the growth in the rectal mucosa is given below. Which of the following options is the most appropriate description of his condition?

choices.text: Hyperplastic polyp - irregular tufting of epithelial cells
Hyperplastic polyp-  arborising pattern of connective tissue

questions.solution:
Rectal mass, presence of blood streaks, mucosal discharge in the stool, and the given image with lymphocytic infiltrates suggest the presence of an inflammatory polyp in the rectal wall. 

Inflammatory polyps are usually single and can lead to rectal mucosa prolapse. It is also known as solitary rectal ulcer syndrome. It is caused by impaired relaxation of the anal sphincter leading to repeated abrasion and ulceration of the rectal mucosa. If the polyp gets entrapped in the stool, it can lead to rectal mucosa prolapse. The histopathology usually reveals inflammatory infiltrates, erosion, and epithelial hyperplasia.

Gastrointestinal polyps can be classified into four types :

  • Hyperplastic polyp
  • Inflammatory polyp
  • Hamartomatous polyp
  • Neoplastic polyp

Hyperplastic, inflammatory, and hamartomatous polyps are classified as benign.

Hyperplastic polyps are caused by the delayed shedding of epithelial cells. They are smooth nodular protrusions and consist of mature goblet and absorptive cells. The image below shows a hyperplastic polyp.

Hamartomatous polyps can occur sporadically or due to genetic mutations. Examples are juvenile polyps and polyps associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. The arborizing pattern of connective tissue is seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. The image below shows a hamartomatous polyp.

Neoplastic polyps are intraepithelial neoplasms ranging from small pedunculated to large sessile lesions. They are most commonly seen in the colon. They can be caused by any neoplastic masses like adenocarcinoma, carcinoid tumors, stromal tumors, and lymphomas. Epithelial dysplasia can be seen. The image below shows a neoplastic polyp.

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who worked as a miner for the past 25 years, comes to the OPD with complaints of dyspnoea and cough. Routine blood work-up, pulmonary function tests, and a lung biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis. The histopathological examination of the sample is shown below. Which type of emphysema can this condition give rise to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and microscopic image show abundant black pigment within the macrophages of lung parenchyma, which is characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis/coal worker's pneumoconiosis and may give rise to centrilobular emphysema.

The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages and then accumulate in the connective tissue along the lymphatics or in lymphoid tissue along the bronchi or the hilum, blackening the tissues. Aggregates of carbon dust present as coal macules or nodules, which consist of carbon-laden macrophages.

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments with high air pollution and carbon particles, such as coal mines. Coal worker's pneumoconiosis is usually benign, and less than 10% of cases develop progressive massive fibrosis, which may lead to pulmonary dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale.

Coal workers may also develop emphysema or chronic bronchitis, independent of smoking. Unlike asbestosis, this condition does not predispose to cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Panacinar emphysema is caused by alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. It affects the entire acinus and primarily involves the lower lobes. It is not related to occupational exposures like mining but rather a genetic enzyme deficiency that leads to lung damage, making it an unlikely cause in this patient.

Option C: Paraseptal emphysema involves distal acinar destruction, often affecting subpleural areas. It is associated with spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults. Since this condition is not linked to prolonged dust exposure or mining, it is not the correct answer for this case.

Option D: Irregular emphysema occurs secondary to lung scarring, often due to previous infections or fibrosis rather than occupational lung diseases.

questions.text: The above procedure was performed on a young patient with an abnormal PAP smear suspected to have carcinoma cervix. What is the most relevant indication for this procedure?

choices.text: Treatment of choice for stromal invasion of 3-5 mm
Treatment of choice for cancer of Stage 1A1

questions.solution:
The most relevant indication for the above procedure is as the treatment of choice for cancer of Stage 1A1. The given image shows conization or cone biopsy, which is the procedure of choice done for the treatment of stage 1A1 cervix cancer.

A cone biopsy is indicated for both diagnostic and therapeutic intervention in the preinvasive and invasive carcinoma cervix. It involves the excision of a cone of cervical tissue. The cone includes the squamocolumnar zone, the ectocervix, and the distal part of the endocervical canal. Indications of conization are:

  • Diagnostic: When the transformation zone is not completely visualized, in endocervical dysplasia, when there is a discrepancy between PAP smear and colposcopic biopsy, and when the micro invasion is suspected.
  • Therapeutic: As the procedure of choice for both diagnosis and treatment in young women with cancer cervix Stage 1A1( <3mm cervix involved) who wish to preserve fertility only in cases where there is no lymphovascular space invasion or margin positivity.

In older women who have completed their family, Stage 1A1 cancer can also be treated with a simple extra fascial hysterectomy. Complications of conization include bleeding, cervical stenosis, abortion, preterm labor, and infection.

Other Options:

Option A: Conization should be avoided as much as possible in pregnancy due to the risk of bleeding after biopsy and abortion. Rather, in women with an abnormal PAP smear in pregnancy, colposcopic biopsy or multiple biopsies are preferred for diagnosis.MRI may also be done. Pregnancy does not appear to alter the biological behavior of the tumour, so treatment is still based on stage of the tumour and the woman's desire to preserve fertility.

Option B: Treatment of cancer with stromal invasion of 3-5 mm( Stage 1A2 ) involves radical trachelectomy as a fertility-sparing procedure and type 2 hysterectomy with lymph node sampling in individuals not desirous of preserving fertility. In case lymph nodes are positive, postoperative radiotherapy is indicated.

Option D: Due to the large size of the tumor, conization for fertility preservation is not employed in 1B2 cancers. The treatment of choice for 1B2 cancers is type 3 hysterectomy with lymphadenectomy followed by radiation therapy. In case the patient is pregnant and near term, a classical caesarian hysterectomy is done when the baby crosses the period of viability.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: An adolescent presents with the following clinical findings. He gives a history of consuming very spicy food at a party earlier that day. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing small wheals is suggestive of cholinergic urticaria.

Urticaria is characterized by itchy wheals, which develop due to transient oedema of the dermis (and sometimes of subcutis).

Causes of urticaria:

  • Physical: Demographics, Cholinergic, Cold, Heat, Solar, Delayed pressure
  • Hypersensitivity
  • Autoimmune
  • Drug-induced
  • Contact
  • Inherited: Hereditary angioedema (rarely seen)

Clinical features of different types of physical urticarias:

Type of urticaria Precipitating factors Morphology of lesions
Dermographic urticaria Rubbing, scratching Linear wheals
Cholinergic urticaria Sweating (anxiety, strenuous work, gustatory stimuli) Small, very transient wheals
Cold urticaria Cold stimuli (wind, drinks)  Small/large wheals
Solar urticaria Sun exposure  Lesions on photo-exposed parts
Delayed pressure urticaria Sustained pressure Urticaria develops 3–6 h after pressure. Lasts for 12–72 hours. Buttocks (prolonged sitting), hands (in manual workers), under feet (prolonged walking), and waist (tight underclothes)

Other options:

Option A: Erythema multiforme presents with target lesions (central erythema surrounded by an area of clearing and another rim of erythema). It spreads centripetally and is present symmetrically on knees, elbows, palms, and soles.

Option B: Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, non-ulcerative, painful eruption occurring due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. It can occur idiopathically or due to infections (e.g., streptococcal, fungal, mycobacterial, yersinia) or drugs (e.g., sulfa, penicillins, oral contraceptives) or in diseases like sarcoidosis.

Option D: Miliaria rubra is a maculopapular, pruritic, erythematous rash that commonly occurs in clothed areas. It is also known as prickly heat. 

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to your clinic with complaints of fatigue, weight loss and difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. A barium swallow is performed which shows the following finding. What is the most common site of carcinoma in such patients?
questions.solution:
The post-cricoid region is a common site for carcinoma in females suffering from this condition.

The barium swallow shows an esophagal web, which refers to an esophagal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen, as shown in the image below. Esophageal web is associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome. 

The post-cricoid region is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and lower borders of the cricoid lamina. It is a common site for carcinoma in females suffering from Plummer–Vinson syndrome.

Patients are usually asymptomatic, however, if the stenosis is severe, symptoms include dysphagia and regurgitation of food. 

Triad seen in Plummer-Vinson Syndrome/ Patterson-Kelly-Brown Syndrome:

  • Iron Deficiency Anemia
  • Esophageal webs
  • Dysphagia

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman came to the local emergency department with severe headache and stiffness of the neck. The CSF specimen is cloudy. While in the emergency room, an intern performs gram stain of the CSF but by mistake forgets the step in which iodine is added. Assuming that the women has meningitis caused by streptococcus pneumoniae,  how would the bacteria on the intern’s slide appear?

choices.text: No gram stain results would be obtained due to lysis of all cells

questions.solution:
In the above question, the intern forgot to add iodine, i.e., the second step of gram staining. As a result, the purple iodine-dye complex will not form, and the entire crystal violet dye will wash away during the decolorization step. Now when the safranin is added, all the cells will stain red.

The various steps in gram staining are as follows:

  • The crystal violet dye (basic dye) stains all cells purple.
  • The iodine solution (a mordant) is added to form a crystal violet–iodine complex. At the end of this step, all cells continue to appear purple.
  • In the decolorization step, the organic solvent, such as acetone or ethanol, extracts the blue dye complex from the lipid-rich, thin-walled gram-negative bacteria to a greater degree than from the lipid-poor, thick-walled gram-positive bacteria. At the end of this step, the gram-negative organisms appear colorless; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.
  • The red dye safranin (counterstain) stains the decolorized gram-negative cells red/pink; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text:
A newborn presenting with which of the following signs can be managed in a newborn stabilization unit (NBSU)?
  1. Respiratory rate of 60-70/min without grunting or retractions
  2. Sepsis who are hemodynamically stable
  3. Hypothermic who are hemodynamically unstable
  4. Jaundiced who requires phototherapy
questions.solution:
Newborns with signs mentioned in statements 1, 2, and 4 can be managed in NBSU. A hemodynamically unstable newborn should be transferred to a special newborn care unit.

Newborns that can be managed at NBSU:

  • Newborns with respiratory distress, having respiratory rates 60-70/min without grunting or retractions for observation and oxygen therapy

  • Newborns with hypothermia and hyperthermia who are hemodynamically stable 
  • Newborns who require phototherapy for jaundice
  • Newborns with sepsis and hemodynamically stable for antibiotic therapy

questions.text:
A 65-year-old hypertensive patient's ambulatory BP was recorded to be in the range of 144/86 mmHg. The consultant decided to start on an ARB with additional antiplatelet activity. Which drug is the most likely to be started in this patient?

ARB: Angiotensin Receptor Blocker
questions.solution:
The most likely drug to be used should be Losartan because of its dual ARB and anti-platelet properties.

Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that lowers blood pressure and has anti-aggregation properties due to its ability to inhibit platelet activation. This property is distinct among ARBs and makes it suitable in situations where anti-aggregation activity is desired, as mentioned in this case. Losartan blocks thromboxane A2 and has an antiaggregant effect. Losartan also has uricosuric activity.

Losartan is a competitive angiotensin (AT1) receptor antagonist that binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. Uses of losartan are:

  • Antihypertensive
  • Renoprotective drug in diabetes mellitus
  • Stroke prophylaxis
  • Anti-aggregant as it is a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor 
  • Uricosuric drug as it inhibits reabsorption of uric acid

Side effects of ARBs include sprue-like syndrome (olmesartan), hypotension, and hyperkalemia. 

Other options:

Option A, D: Other ARBs, such as Azilsartan and Candesartan, do not have well-established anti-aggregatory activity.

Option C: Telmisartan has partial PPAR-γ agonist activity. Its antiplatelet effects are not well established.

questions.text: A heavy weight lifter complains of low backache for 3 months. On examination there is asymmetric motor and sensory loss in the lower limbs with absent knee and ankle jerks. Bowel and bladder functions are normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is cauda equina syndrome. 

Cauda equina syndrome refers to an injury to the lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal, occurring distal to the termination of spinal cord at L1-L2 level. It occurs most commonly due to rupture of lumbosacral intervertebral disc. Other causes include lumbosacral spine fracture, hematoma within spinal canal, and compressive mass lesions such as tumors.

The patients present with low back ache (most often a radicular type of pain), lower limb weakness and sensory loss, and areflexia in the lower limbs. Relative sparing of bowel and bladder functions with late-onset retention symptoms is seen. Treatment is with urgent surgical decompression of the involved area.

Other options :

Option A: Central cord syndrome results from selective damage to gray matter cells and spinothalamic tracts, which are present in the vicinity of the central canal. It occurs due to syringomyelia (cervical cord involvement), spinal trauma and intrinsic tumors of the spinal cord. Patients with cervical cord involvement present with weakness in arms more than legs and loss of pain and temperature sensation over the shoulders, upper back and nape of the neck (cape-like distribution). Fine touch, vibration, and joint position sense remain preserved.

Option B: Patients with Brown-Séquard syndrome present with:

  • Ipsilateral weakness due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibration sense due to the involvement of the posterior column tracts.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.

questions.text: A young woman presents with lower back pain and decreased sensation on the dorsum of her foot following an intense workout involving heavy weight lifting. MRI findings are shown in the image. Based on the location and radiation of her pain, which of the following nerve roots is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario involves decreased sensation on the dorsum of the foot, and the given MRI findings point toward intervertebral disc prolapse at the L4-L5 level. The L5 nerve root is the traversing nerve root.

The L5 nerve root is commonly compressed in cases of lumbar disc herniation, particularly at the L4- L5 intervertebral disc level, which is one of the most frequent sites of disc herniation. This results in radiculopathy, which presents with:

  • Pain in the lower back, buttocks, lateral thigh, and postero-lateral leg
  • Sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot, particularly the first web space
  • Weakness in foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, and difficulty walking on heels

Since the dorsum of the foot is involved, this strongly suggests L5 nerve root involvement. L5 is the traversing nerve root at this level and is commonly affected in paracentral disc herniation.

Note: In contrast, lateral disc herniation at this level would more commonly affect the exiting L4 nerve root.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient who is admitted for back pain and fever of unknown etiology is being worked up. Multiple spinal lesions were seen on imaging and a differential diagnosis of spinal tuberculosis or spinal metastasis was made. Which of the following features helps to consider spinal metastasis as a diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pedicle destruction is commonly seen in spinal metastasis. Posterior elements involvement is rare in spinal tuberculosis. 

Spinal metastasis represents the spread of malignancy to the spine, causing bone destruction. MRI would demonstrate vertebral lesions, bone marrow involvement, or spinal cord compression, without evidence of vertebral slippage. Involvement of intervertebral disc is very uncommon. 

The winking owl sign refers to the appearance of the spine when a pedicle is absent. The usual appearance of the pedicle represents two eyes on the AP (Antero-posterior) projection. When one pedicle is destroyed, it appears like one eye is open and the other is winking or shut and the spinous process appears like the beak of the owl. It is almost always due to a bony metastasis. The below radiographic image shows winking owl sign.

Radiographic signs of TB spine include:

  • Destruction of the vertebral body starts with the erosion of contiguous margins, followed by wedging of the vertebra and then the destruction of the whole of the vertebral body leading to kyphosis. But Posterior elements are rarely involved.
  • Narrowing of disc space is the earliest sign of TB spine, especially in the paradisical type (Option C).
  • Appearance of cold abscess. In cervical spine disease, the retropharyngeal abscess may be evident.
  • In lower spine involvement, paravertebral abscess (Option D) may be seen in either a fusiform or globular shape.
  • Thoracic spine disease may be seen as widened mediastinum on AP view.
  • Rarefaction above and below the vertebra (Option A)
  • Signs of healing - the bone becomes sclerotic and regains its density. The adjacent vertebra may undergo fusion.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not included in NP-NCD?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is not included in the NP-NCD program.

The NPCDCS (National Program for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke) has been changed to NP-NCD (National Program for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases). It now includes initiatives and guidelines on the prevention and management of new diseases like:

  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Chronic Kidney disease
  • Asthma, COPD
  • STEMI
  • Stroke

It continues to include the diseases already covered in NPCDCS. For effective program management, the NCD divisions have been established at National, State, and District headquarters to ensure the activities' planning, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation.

The NPCDCS program was first introduced under the NHM(National Health Mission) umbrella in 2010, to prevent screen, and treat Non-communicable diseases in India. In 2018, Non-Communicable Diseases like Cardiovascular diseases, Cancer, Chronic Respiratory Diseases, Diabetes, and other NCDs were estimated to account for 63% of all deaths, thus making them the leading causes of death. Hypothyroidism has never been a part of the program.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding chest compression during CPR in an infant?

choices.text: Depth should be 1/5th of the depth of the infant’s chest
Done 1 cm below the nipples over the sternum

questions.solution:
The depth of the chest compression in a one-month-old child receiving CPR is 1/3rd the depth of the infant’s chest.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below.
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands with both thumbs pointing cephalic positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.
  • Press hard and fast.
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:

  • The compression rate is 100-120/min (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One or both palms are placed in the midline.
  • The depth of compression is 2 inches.
  • Press hard and fast.
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

The compression-to-ventilation ratio for pediatric CPR depends on the number of rescuers present:

  • For a single rescuer: 30:2 (30 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths)
  • For two rescuers: 15:2 (15 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths)

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: A trial on a new antiemetic drug that can be used in post-chemotherapy patients was done. 20% of the patients in the treatment group had vomiting whereas 80% had vomiting in the placebo group. Calculate the relative risk reduction.
questions.solution:
Relative risk reduction in the above clinical trial is 75%.

Relative risk reduction(RRR) is the relative measure of treatment effectiveness. It shows an estimate of the proportion of the baseline risk that is removed by the intervention in a clinical trial.

RRR= (CER- EER)/CER where CER is the control event rate (adverse outcome in the control group) and EER is the experimental event rate (adverse outcome in the intervention group).

In the above clinical trial, 

CER= 80%=0.8, EER= 20%=0.2

RRR= (0.8-0.2)/0.8= 0.75 or 75%

RRR can also be calculated by finding the risk ratio (RR), i.e. RRR= 1- RR.

CER- EER: is risk difference.

Note:

Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo and the drug.

In this scenario, ARR = 80% - 20% = 60%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man underwent endoscopic resection for adenocarcinoma of the stomach. In the recovery room, the anaesthesiologist had difficulty with ventilation, and abdominal distension was observed. His pressure measured by trans-bladder catheter was 33 mmHg. Which of the following can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is indicative of abdominal compartment syndrome, a complication where the intra-cranial pressure can be raised.

Abdominal compartment syndrome is a condition in which the intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) is raised, resulting in various complications due to a compromise in blood supply to the viscera as a result of reduced venous return to the heart. Causes of increased IAP include ascites, bleeding, packs, and bowel edema post-surgery.

It is measured using a trans-bladder catheter, which measures the intra-bladder pressure and extrapolates the abdominal compartment pressure from it indirectly. A pressure of >20 mmHg is diagnostic of abdominal compartment syndrome. Following are the pathological changes that occur as a result of increased IAP:

  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Compression of the kidneys- reduction in renal blood flow and thus urine output
  • Reduced venous return- fall in ventricular end-diastolic volume, cardiac output, stroke volume, and rise in systemic vascular resistance, which results in hypotension(low BP)
  • Raised intrathoracic pressure-hypoxemia causing increased airway pressure, pulmonary artery pressure, central venous pressure, and fall in compliance of the lungs
  • Intestinal permeability increases due to vasoconstriction of intestinal vessels and bacteria leak across the intestinal epithelium, increasing the risk of sepsis

Usually, 35 mmHg is taken as the cutoff value beyond which emergency decompression becomes necessary. It may also be carried out whenever end-organ dysfunction occurs due to raised IAP. This may be achieved via percutaneous drainage of fluid in case there is any collection or by an urgent laparotomy. The abdomen can be closed later after the primary cause is managed.

questions.text: The following image shows the electron microscopic image of chromatin. Which of the following amino acid pairs are most commonly found in the spherical structures in the given image?
questions.solution:
Lysine and arginine are the most abundant amino acids in histone proteins (spherical structures in the image).

The given electron microscopic image depicts chromatin's "beads on a string" appearance. Nucleosomes (beads) consist of DNA wrapped around a histone octamer. This octamer includes two copies of histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, with approximately 145–150 base pairs of DNA wrapped around each core particle. Linker DNA (about 30 bp) (string) separates these nucleosomes, creating chromatin's characteristic repeating structure.

Histones are rich in lysine and arginine, both of which are positively charged. These positively charged amino acids allow strong interactions with the negatively charged phosphate groups of DNA and ensure chromatin stability.

Other Options:

Option A: Aspartic acid and Glutamic acid are acidic amino acids that are rich in positively charged side chains, not found in histones.

Option C: Phenylalanine and Tyrosine are aromatic amino acids that are not particularly abundant in histones.

Option D: Serine and Threonine are polar amino acids that contain hydroxyl groups, which are not abundant in histones.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with a fungating mass on the glans penis, along with inguinal lymphadenopathy. A biopsy reveals a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Further histopathological examination shows small hyperchromatic cells with a destructive invasion pattern. Which of the following is the most likely histologic subtype of this penile carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of squamous cell carcinoma with the histological findings suggests basaloid carcinoma subtype.

Basaloid carcinoma is a poorly differentiated, HPV-related subtype of penile squamous cell carcinoma. It consists of small hyperchromatic cells with a destructive invasion pattern and follows an aggressive clinical course.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the penis typically arises from the glans or the inner surface of the prepuce near the coronal sulcus. Macroscopically, it can present as irregular, fungating cauliflower-like masses, flat indurated lesions, or large verruciform/papillary tumors. The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies penile squamous cell carcinoma into HPV-related and non–HPV-related types, each with distinct histologic subtypes.

Conventional (usual) squamous cell carcinoma is the most common HPV-negative type, accounting for nearly half of all penile cancers. Histologic subtypes also correlate with tumor grade; for example, verrucous and papillary carcinomas are well-differentiated (grade 1), while sarcomatoid and basaloid carcinomas are poorly differentiated (grade 3).

Among special subtypes, verrucous carcinoma is a well-differentiated, non-HPV-related variant with an exophytic, warty appearance that invades locally but rarely metastasizes. In contrast, basaloid carcinoma is an aggressive, HPV-related tumor, leading to a more severe prognosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease visits your clinic. He has smoked 20 cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. Besides smoking cessation, which of the following interventions is most effective in improving survival in this hypoxemic patient?
questions.solution:
In a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patient with a significant smoking history, the most effective intervention for improving survival, besides smoking cessation, is long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT).

LTOT is proven to increase survival in COPD patients with chronic hypoxemia (PaO₂ ≤ 55 mmHg or SaO₂ ≤ 88%). It reduces mortality by preventing complications like pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure.

Other options:

Option A: Inhaled corticosteroids help reduce exacerbations.

Option C: Long-acting beta agonists (LABAs) improve symptoms and lung function.

Option D: Chronic use of oral glucocorticoids is associated with significant side effects like osteoporosis, weight gain, cataracts, glucose intolerance, and increased risk of infection.

questions.text: A physician asked the intern to examine a patient's nails who is diagnosed with  suppurative lung disease to look for a characteristic finding. Which of the following is not an abnormal nail finding on inspection?

choices.text: Curth angle is less than 160 degrees
Lovibond angle is less than 160 degrees

questions.solution:
Lovibond angle of less than 160 degrees is not an abnormal finding. All the given nail findings are related to Clubbing, a clinical inspection finding seen in suppurative lung disease. Lovibond angle of less than 160 degrees is a normal finding.

The Lovibond angle is the angle formed where the nail emerges from the proximal nail fold. A normal Lovibond's angle is less than 180°, while in cases of true clubbing, the angle exceeds 180°.

Digital clubbing is a physical sign characterized by bulbous enlargement of the fingertips/toes due to connective tissue proliferation. Its pathophysiology is complex and associated with chronic diseases affecting the lungs, heart, and gastrointestinal tract, potentially resulting from vasodilatation, increased blood flow, and changes in growth factors and connective tissue metabolism.

Conditions in which clubbing is seen:

  • Cardiac causes: Cyanotic congenital heart disease, infective endocarditis
  • Pulmonary causes: Suppurative lung disease, Cystic fibrosis, Bronchiectasis, Tuberculosis, Lung cancers
  • Gastrointestinal: Hepatic cirrhosis, Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Occupational: Jackhammer users

Other Options:

Option A: Curth angle is the angle made at the distal interphalangeal joint, which is normally about 180 degrees but becomes less than 160 degrees in clubbing.

Option C: Schamroth sign is performed by asking the patient to place the dorsal surfaces (the backs) of the terminal phalanges (the fingertips) of corresponding right and left fingers together. In a patient with normal fingers, this maneuver creates a diamond-shaped window between the fingertips. However, in a patient with clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window is obliterated due to the increased soft tissue and bone growth at the fingertips.

Option D: Thyrotoxicosis is sometimes associated with clubbing of the bones of the hands and feet, a condition known as Acropachy. It is not a normal finding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about lung compliance?

choices.text: Compliance is increased if the lung remains unventilated for a longer period of time
Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air
Compliance is slightly lesser when measured during deflation than during inflation
For a given lung size, the compliance becomes more at extremes of lung volume

questions.solution:
Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air is the correct statement about lung compliance.

When the lungs are filled with air, an interface forms between the alveolar fluid and the air, causing both surface tension and elastic forces to act on the alveoli. Surface tension, created by the air-fluid interface, resists lung expansion. However, in a saline-filled lung, there is no air-fluid interface, meaning surface tension is absent, and only the elastic forces of the lung tissue are in effect. As a result, lung compliance (the ease with which the lungs can expand) is higher when measured with saline than air.

Lung compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure. It means how easily the lungs expand and contract. It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Other options:

Option A: If a lung remains unventilated for a longer period, then it collapses, which decreases compliance and increases surface tension.

Option C: Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation as compared to inflation due to hysteresis. During inflation, higher pressure is needed to overcome initial alveolar surface tension.

Option D: For a given lung size, the compliance becomes lesser at extremes of lung volumes due to an increase in the elastic forces and surface tension.    

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with 2 weeks of productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. A chest radiogram was done as shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for him?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has a lung abscess, as the chest X-ray shows an air-fluid level. Clindamycin is the drug of choice for treating lung abscesses.

Chest X-ray showing lung abscess(yellow) with air-fluid level (arrow):

Clindamycin is preferred over penicillin for primary lung abscesses (caused by aspirating oral flora in healthy individuals) due to its effectiveness against β-lactamase-producing anaerobes. Recommended treatments include IV clindamycin followed by oral clindamycin or a β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combination like amoxicillin-clavulanate. Therapy continues until imaging confirms resolution. Metronidazole alone is ineffective since it does not cover microaerophilic streptococci.

Secondary lung abscesses (caused by underlying conditions like malignancy, immunosuppression, or bronchial obstruction) are treated by targeting the identified pathogen and prolonging antibiotic courses based on the patient’s immune status. If no improvement is seen in 7 days, further evaluation is needed to rule out underlying causes.

Large abscesses (>6–8 cm) are less likely to resolve without additional interventions, such as drainage or surgery. Patients who fail antibiotic therapy, especially if they are poor surgical candidates, may require surgical resection or percutaneous drainage. Possible complications of drainage include pleural infection, pneumothorax, and hemothorax.

Note: Pneumatoceles are thin-walled cavities in the lung parenchyma that are seen in respiratory tract infections. They are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus in children and Pneumocystis jirovecii in immunocompromised adults. Below is the chest X-ray showing a pneumatocele.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive difficulty gripping objects and frequent falls over the past four years. Examination reveals asymmetric muscle weakness of the finger flexors and quadriceps. Laboratory tests show a creatine kinase (CK) level of 400 U/L. Muscle biopsy reveals endomysial CD8+ T cell infiltrates, rimmed vacuoles, and amyloid deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM). 

IBM is a common autoimmune inflammatory myopathy in older adults (>50 years old). Anti-cN-1a antibodies target the cytosolic enzyme 5'-nucleotidase 1A, contributing to the pathogenesis. 

It causes slowly progressive muscle weakness and atrophy, primarily affecting the wrist and finger flexors in the arms and quadriceps in the legs. IBM selectively involves distal muscles with asymmetric weakness. Dysphagia is common, further distinguishing it from other inflammatory myopathies.

Creatine kinase is normal or mildly elevated. Muscle MRI may show a predilection for involvement of the flexor digitorum profundus in the arms and the vastus medialis and lateralis muscles with sparing of the rectus femoris muscle. 

Immunostaining for p62 is the most sensitive stain for inclusion detection. The mainstay of treatment is physical and occupational therapy to improve function and swallowing therapy in those with dysphagia.

Other Options:

Option A: Polymyositis- Unlike IBM, polymyositis presents with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness (shoulders, hips) without distal involvement. CK levels in polymyositis are usually markedly elevated (>1000 U/L).

Option B: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis- ALS causes both upper and lower motor neuron signs (e.g., hyperreflexia, muscle fasciculations, atrophy). Weakness in ALS is usually asymmetric but involves both proximal and distal muscles.

Option D: Dermatomyositis- It is characterised by proximal muscle weakness and characteristic skin findings (heliotrope rash, Gottron’s papules). CK levels in dermatomyositis are usually markedly elevated (>1000 U/L).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia.  The bone marrow tap was dry. You prepare a peripheral blood smear, which reveals the findings shown in the given image.   What is the most likely feature and a drug used in managing the condition?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows abnormal B cells with fine hair-like cytoplasmic projections characteristic of hairy cell leukemia. This leukemia is Annexin A1 positive and cladribine is the treatment of choice. 

Hairy cell leukemia:

  • It is associated with BRAF mutations.
  • It mainly occurs in older males.
  • Splenomegaly is the most common physical finding. 
  • It is extremely sensitive to chemotherapeutic agents.
  • Overall prognosis is excellent.
  • Pathology:
    • Hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp of the spleen, which is heavily infiltrated. This leads to the obliteration of white pulp and a beefy red gross appearance.
    • Hairy cells can be identified in the peripheral blood smear.
    • Pancytopenia results from marrow infiltration and splenic sequestration.
    • A "dry tap" is common on aspiration.
    • Detection of annexin A1 in bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies.
    • Trephine biopsy: Leukemic cells have a nucleus surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo giving them a fried-egg appearance.
    • CD11c, CD25, and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers.
    • Cells test positive for pan-B-cell markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22.
    • Cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).

The image given below shows small cells with clear cytoplasm and a round central nucleus—fried-egg appearance.

Other options:

Options A and B: Synaptophysin positivity is seen in neuroendocrine tumours. 

Option C: Dacarbazine is used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

questions.text: Identify the given sign on a uterine artery doppler seen at 22 weeks of gestation in a pregnant woman.
questions.solution:
The given red arrow in the doppler image points to the diastolic notch in a uterine artery doppler.

The uterine artery doppler waveform in pregnant women is characterized by high diastolic flow velocities and markedly turbulent flow. Diastolic notch is present in uterine artery flow between 22 and 24 weeks (high resistance index in the second trimester). In normal pregnant women, the diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks.

Persistence of the notch beyond 24 weeks of gestation is associated with the development of gestational hypertension and IUGR. However, this finding is not used in clinical practice as it has a poor predictive value.

questions.text: The items shown below are employed as part of what level of health prevention?
questions.solution:
Items employed above are employed as part of the secondary level of prevention. The given image shows an Ayers spatula and slide-holding bottle, which are used for obtaining a pap smear. Pap smear is a screening test for detecting cervical cancer in women. Hence, it is a secondary level of prevention.

Screening tests are a form of secondary prevention as in these conditions, the disease has already occurred and the main aim of the test is early diagnosis and treatment initiation before complications occur.

Prevention is categorized into various levels based on when the specific health intervention is applied to the population. Levels of prevention are:

  • Primordial prevention: Prevention strategies employed even before the occurrence of the risk factors of disease. For example, the promotion of a healthy lifestyle with adequate exercise in normal individuals prevents the development of obesity, a risk factor for cardiovascular disease
  • Primary prevention: Prevention of occurrence of disease by reducing the effect of risk factors on the population. For example, going to the gym to reduce weight is a form of primary prevention in obese individuals to prevent cardiovascular disease from developing
  • Secondary prevention: Prevention of complications from occurring in an already diseased individual. For example, the treatment of individuals with a history of myocardial infarction with statins, to maintain a good lipid profile and prevent further morbidity
  • Tertiary prevention: Prevention of disability or death resulting from the complications of a condition. For example, daily dressing in a leprosy patient with trophic ulcer to prevent infection and promote healing
  • Quaternary prevention: It is a new term that refers to the prevention of harm to patients from unnecessary or excessive treatment for diseases

questions.text: Which of the following is not an operational indicator under NLEP?
questions.solution:
The incubation period of Mycobacterium leprae is not an operational indicator under NLEP.

The incubation period of Mycobacterium leprae (which ranges from 2 to 10 years, sometimes up to 20 years) is a biological characteristic of the disease. It is not used as an operational indicator because it does not directly measure the performance of the leprosy control program.

The National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India uses several operational indicators to assess the effectiveness of leprosy control activities. These indicators help monitor disease trends, evaluate program performance, and guide interventions.

Operational Indicators under NLEP:

  • Prevalence Rate: This measures the number of leprosy cases per 10,000 population at a given time. It helps assess the disease burden in the community and is an important indicator for determining whether leprosy elimination goals are being met
  • New Case Detection Rate: Number of new leprosy cases detected per 100,000 population per year. Reflects ongoing transmission and effectiveness of case detection efforts
  • Cure rate of multibacillary leprosy cases (MB)
  • Cure rate of paucibacillary leprosy cases (PB)
  • Grade 2 Disability Rate: The proportion of new cases with Grade 2 disability (visible deformities) at the time of diagnosis. This rate indicates late diagnosis and delay in treatment, which is a concern for leprosy control programs. It is a key indicator of early case detection efforts
  • Stigma reduction is the reduction in the level of stigma associated with leprosy

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever and diarrhea. She recalls having raw milk 5 days back. Her CBC shows leukocytosis. CRP and ESR parameters are also raised. Small gram-positive rods are seen on gram staining. Which selective media is used for isolating the causative organism?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a pregnant woman with fever and diarrhea with a history of consuming raw milk is highly indicative of Listeria monocytogenes infection. PALCAM agar is the selective media for Listeria monocytogenes. 

Listeria is a short, gram-positive bacillus that exhibits tumbling motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C. Infection occurs through ingesting contaminated dairy products, deli meats, and refrigerated foods. It commonly affects pregnant females, which can lead to complications like stillbirths and spontaneous abortions. It may cause meningitis or sepsis in neonates due to perinatal transmission. In immunocompromised and elderly, it can cause meningoencephalitis. In healthy individuals, it can present as gastroenteritis.

Listeria is isolated from blood, CSF, vaginal secretions, lochia, or meconium using blood agar under 5% CO₂. Cold enrichment (storage in tryptose phosphate or thioglycollate broth at 4°C with weekly subcultures) enhances detection. PALCAM Agar (Polymyxin Acriflavine Lithium Chloride Ceftazidime Esculin Mannitol Agar) is a selective and differential medium designed for Listeria isolation. Detection of listeriolysin O antibodies further aid diagnosis.

Ampicillin alone or in combination with Gentamicin is the first-line therapy. In penicillin-allergic patients, Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is an alternative. Pregnant women require prompt antibiotic therapy to prevent fetal complications like stillbirth, preterm labor, or neonatal sepsis.

Other options:

Option A: Tellurite agar is used for Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Option B: XLD agar (Xylose Lysine Deoxycholate Agar) is used for Salmonella and Shigella.

Option D: Castaneda biphasic media is used for Brucella species.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with a rapidly enlarging mass above his knee. The mass has been present for several months and has recently become painful. On examination, the overlying area has a bony prominence with tenderness. On X ray cortical destruction is seen. Which malignancy can the above condition transform into?
questions.solution:
The given presentation, along with an X-ray showing a pedunculated growth, leads to the diagnosis of osteochondroma/exostosis. Osteochondroma can transform into chondrosarcoma.

Osteochondroma (exostosis) is a benign bone tumor, typically arising from the metaphysis of long bones. It consists of a bony mass, often with a pedunculated or sessile stalk, formed through endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. A pathognomonic feature is the cortical and medullary continuity of the tumor with the underlying bone, confirming the diagnosis. 

Although osteochondromas are benign, they can rarely undergo malignant transformation into low-grade chondrosarcoma. This should be suspected if there is growth after skeletal maturity, new-onset pain, cortical destruction, lucency, soft tissue mass, or a cartilage cap >2 cm. These features suggest aggressive behavior and warrant further evaluation.

Osteochondromas are classified into pedunculated and sessile types based on their shape and attachment to the bone. The more common type, pedunculated osteochondromas, has a stalk-like, narrow base that often points away from the joint, resembling a mushroom. The cartilaginous cap is not visible on X-ray, making the lesion appear smaller radiologically than its actual size. Sessile osteochondromas have a broad, flat base with no distinct stalk, appearing as a wide-based bony outgrowth.

Most patients remain asymptomatic and do not require treatment. However, symptomatic cases, especially those causing pain, neurovascular compression, or suspected malignant transformation, may require surgical resection.

Other options:

Option B: Osteosarcoma usually arises de novo, typically in the metaphysis of long bones in adolescents and young adults. It presents with sunburst periosteal reaction and Codman triangle on X-ray.

Option C: Chondroblastoma is a benign tumor that arises in the epiphysis of long bones in adolescents.

Option D: Osteoclastoma occurs in the epiphysis of long bones in young adults (20-40 years). GCTs have an eccentric, soap-bubble appearance on X-ray and can be locally aggressive.

questions.text: A completely unimmunized 2-year-old boy presents with conjunctivitis and bluish-white spots on the buccal mucosa. Four days later, he developed a widespread maculopapular rash. Which of the following families does the causative virus belong to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation suggests measles. The measles virus belongs to the Paramyxovirus family.

Measles is a lipid-enveloped single-stranded RNA virus that belongs to the Paramyxovirus family. Other members of this family include the Nipah virus, RSV, the Hendra virus, and the Parainfluenza virus.  

The clinical features of measles include mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection (Conjunctivitis, coryza, and cough -classic "3 C’s"), and pathognomic Koplik spots. The Koplik spots are red lesions with bluish-white spots seen in the inner cheeks at the level of the premolars. The red maculopapular rashes begin on the forehead, behind the ears, and on the upper neck on the 4th day. It then spreads towards the torso and extremities and reaches the palms and soles. The virus spreads 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of the rash through body secretions.

The diagnosis is mainly clinical, but a serological demonstration of IgM and IgG antibodies is also used. The inclusion bodies formed by the measles virus (as shown in the lymph node biopsy) are multinucleate giant cells called Warthin-Finkeldey cells. They result from the fusion of infected lymphocytes due to the cytopathic effect of the measles virus.

Complications include pneumonia, croup, and tracheitis. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a nearly fatal complication of chronic measles, is diagnosed by elevated IgG levels in cerebrospinal fluid. 

Active immunization can prevent measles. The live attenuated vaccine (MMR vaccine -Measles, Mumps, Rubella) is given subcutaneously, except for immunocompromised and pregnant women.

Other options:

Option B: Influenza belongs to the Orthomyxovirus family. It presents with fever, myalgia, and respiratory symptoms but lacks Koplik spots and a maculopapular rash.

Option C: Flaviviridae includes flavivirus (all arbovirus), which causes yellow fever.

Option D: The rubella virus belongs to the family Matonaviridae (previously called Togaviridae). Rubella has a postauricular/occipital lymphadenopathy, and a pink, non-coalescing maculopapular rash which disappears by the third day.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient came to the Dermatology OPD with dermatitis, hair loss, loss of appetite, and nausea. He is a gym trainer by profession and has a history of consuming 25 raw uncooked eggs per day for 2 months. Which of the following metabolic pathways in this patient is not getting affected?

choices.text: Beta Oxidation of Odd Chain Fatty Acid

questions.solution:
Pyrimidine Synthesis is not getting affected in this patient.

The following three enzymes needed for carboxylation use Vitamin B7(Biotin) as their coenzyme:

  1. Propionyl CoA Carboxylase - It is needed for the conversion of propionyl CoA to Methyl Malonyl CoA in the beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids.
  2. Acetyl CoA Carboxylase - It is needed for the conversion of acetyl CoA to malonyl CoA in fatty acid synthesis.
  3. Pyruvate Carboxylase - It is needed to convert pyruvate to oxaloacetate in gluconeogenesis.

Pyrimidine Synthesis needs carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II (CPS-II), which does Vitamin B7 (Biotin) independent carboxylation, and therefore, it is not affected by Vitamin B7(Biotin) deficiency. CPS II is responsible for the synthesis of carbamoyl phosphate from glutamine and CO2, which is unlike other carboxylation reactions where the COO- group is added to the substrate.

Raw, uncooked egg white contains a glycoprotein called avidin, which tightly binds biotin and prevents its absorption from the intestine. Consuming more than 20 raw, uncooked eggs daily is sufficient to induce vitamin B7 deficiency. Vitamin B7 (Biotin) deficiency causes dermatitis, hair loss, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations, loss of appetite, and nausea.  

Injection of 100–300 mg of biotin will rapidly cure these symptoms.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man who had an episode of acute pancreatitis one month ago presented with abdominal pain. His CECT was done, which showed a circumscribed collection with a well-defined enhancing wall, as shown below. The collection was also found to be communicating with the pancreatic duct. Which of the following interventions should not be attempted?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with imaging findings, points towards a pancreatic pseudocyst with communication to the pancreatic duct. In such cases, external drainage via a percutaneous route should not be attempted.

Pancreatic pseudocysts communicate with the pancreatic duct in many cases. External drainage is not done in these cases as it can result in a pancreatico-cutaneous fistula and emptying of the pancreatic contents via the fistula thus formed. Peripancreatic fluid collections are a common complication of acute/chronic pancreatitis and may be of the following types:

  • Early peripancreatic fluid collection -acute cases, no wall of fibrosis or granulation tissue
  • Early pancreatic necrosis(sterile)-focal/diffuse nonviable pancreatic tissue containing fluid and debris
  • Late pancreatic necrosis(sterile)-organized, walled sterile collection within normal pancreatic tissue
  • Acute pseudocyst-collection of pancreatic juice surrounded by early granulation tissue wall within 3-4 weeks of acute pancreatitis
  • Chronic pseudocyst-collection of pancreatic fluid surrounded by well-defined wall persisting for >6w
  • Pancreatic abscess- any of the above with purulent material where an organism has been identified

Treatment options for pseudocysts include:

  1. Cystogastrostomy/Cystoenterostomy
  2. Roux-en-Y Cystojejunostomy
  3. Endoscopic methods like endoscopic transgastric/transduodenal puncture followed by multiple stent placement.
  4. External drainage by percutaneous methods- only if there is no connection with the pancreatic duct.

Acute pseudocysts resolve spontaneously in nearly half of cases over 6 or more weeks, while pseudocysts larger than 6 cm take much longer. They may become complicated by secondary infection, erode into adjacent arteries/ obstruct adjacent vessels, expand to involve nearby organs, or perforate and result in peritonitis.

questions.text: A patient in the ER who had a 2cm deep laceration on the cheek after a road traffic accident was managed by your unit. Choose the option with the correct type of suture used and the time of suture removal.
questions.solution:
Nylon is the type of suture used, and it can be removed after 3-5 days.

Nylon is a non-absorbable polyamide polymer suture that has a low tissue reaction. It is available as a monofilament or braided multifilament. Braided sutures are more prone to infection due to the presence of nidus for bacterial proliferation. It is suitable for skin closure, abdominal wall closure, and hernia repair and can be used in various surgeries. It is available under the brand names Ethilon or Dafilon.

Polyglactin is an absorbable polymer suture that absorbs in 60-90 days. As a synthetic suture material, it causes a mild tissue reaction. It can be used for gut anastomoses and vascular ligatures. It is available under the brand names Vicryl and Novosyn. 

The time gap for the removal of sutures is as follows:

  • Neck sutures- 5-7 days
  • Abdominal sutures- 10-14 days.

questions.text: A patient was rushed to the emergency room after he suffered a lower limb injury in a road traffic accident. To decide whether to save the limb, you calculate the Mangled Extremity Severity Score, which adds up to a score of 5. What would you infer from this?

choices.text: Patient should be reassessed after 6 hours

questions.solution:
A Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) of 6 or less is consistent with a salvageable limb.

MESS can help decide between amputation and limb salvage in crushing injuries.

Components of MESS: mnemonic - ELiSA

questions.text: Three days after being initiated on a certain enzyme inhibiting drug, a patient developed sharply demarcated skin lesions with necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs was likely started for this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient developing skin necrosis a few days after starting a new drug is likely to be suffering from warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Warfarin is an anti-coagulant which acts by competitive inhibition of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase thereby preventing the activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S. Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation). Skin necrosis is a rare, potentially life-threatening side-effect of warfarin use that usually begins 2-5 days after initiation of therapy.

Individuals with Protein C & S deficiency are, particularly at risk for developing warfarin-induced skin necrosis. This is because these proteins, which are anti-thrombotic, have a shorter half-life as compared to the clotting factors inhibited by warfarin. Initiation of warfarin caused a sudden drop in the levels of protein C and S before they inhibit the clotting factors, due to which there is hypercoagulability and consequent thrombosis of microvasculature which leads to necrosis. The toes, thighs, buttocks and breasts are commonly involved.

This adverse effect can be prevented by co-administration of warfarin with a parenteral anticoagulant such as heparin in the initial few days, until the therapeutic INR range is achieved, before continuing with warfarin alone.

Treatment of this condition is by immediately discontinuing warfarin. Vitamin K can be administered for reversal of the drug effect. Patients are started on an alternative anticoagulant such as heparin or LMWH.

Other Options:

Option B: Aspirin acts by irreversibly inhibiting the enzymes cyclo-oxygenase and thromboxane. It is an antiplatelet drug and the most important side effects include bleeding tendencies. 

Option C: Atorvastatin is a statin drug which inhibits the enzyme HMG CoA reductase. Important side effects inclue myositis and hepatotoxicity.

Option D: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone which inhibits the enzyme DNA gyrase. Important side effects include cartilage damage in children and Achilles tendon rupture in adults.

questions.text: A small for gestational age newborn was brought to the OPD. On examination, small palpebral fissures, smooth philtrum and microcephaly were noted. His echocardiogram revealed a ventricular septal defect. These features are caused due to consumption of which of the following substances by the mother during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
These features are caused due to consumption of alcohol by the mother during pregnancy. The given clinical scenario is fetal alcohol syndrome. 

Fetal alcohol syndrome is caused by ethanol which is a potent teratogen. The features of fetal alcohol syndrome are:

  • Growth restriction before and/or after birth
  • CNS dysfunction - microcephaly, mental retardation, abnormal neurobehavioral development like attention deficit with hyperactivity
  • Facial anomalies - small palpebral fissures, thin vermilion border of the upper lip, smooth philtrum
  • Cardiac anomalies - Ventricular septal defect, Atrial septal defect .

Other options:

Option A: Maternal use of phenytoin causes fetal hydantoin syndrome, characterized by an upturned nose, mild facial hypoplasia, long upper lip with a thin vermilion border and distal digital hypoplasia. 

Option B: Maternal use of opioids causes neonatal abstinence syndrome which presents with hypertonia, irritability, poor sucking reflex and seizures. 
 
Option C: Maternal use of lithium leads to Ebstein's anomaly. It causes the apical displacement of the tricuspid valve resulting in tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlagrment. Chest X-ray showing a box-shaped heart is shown below:
