questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is diagnosed with epilepsy and is started on phenytoin for management. She presented to the emergency with abdominal pain, dysuria, and hypertension. She was confused and disoriented. A provisional diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria was made. Which of the following is false about this condition?

ALA - δ-aminolevulinic acid

PBG - porphobilinogen

choices.text: ALA and PBG increased in urine and plasma

questions.solution:
Blistering skin lesions are not seen in acute intermittent porphyria. They are characteristic features of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). 

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is a hepatic porphyria inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It occurs due to a deficiency of HMB-synthase/uroporphyrinogen I synthase enzyme in heme synthesis. AIP is generally latent before puberty and is more common in women. 

Reduced carbohydrate intake during fasting or illness can precipitate acute attacks of AIP. This occurs due to the upregulation of ALA synthase 1 (ALAS1) by hepatic peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ coactivator 1α (PGC-1α), thus increasing heme biosynthesis. Attacks can also be provoked by infections, surgery, and ethanol. A large number of drugs are classically known to precipitate AIP.

AIP presents with neurovisceral symptoms and no cutaneous manifestations are seen. The clinical features of AIP include:

  • Abdominal pain is the most common symptom.
  • Nausea and vomiting.
  • Tachycardia, restlessness, tremors, and excess sweating are due to sympathetic overactivity
  • Psychiatric symptoms like anxiety, insomnia, depression, disorientation, hallucinations, and paranoia can occur in acute attacks.
  • Seizures
  • Proximal muscle weakness and sensory loss
  • Dysuria and urinary retention
  • Persistant hypertension

Diagnosis can be made with the appearance of classic symptomology after exposure to an underlying precipitating factor. Plasma and urine ALA and PBG levels are significantly raised during an acute attack and remain high even after symptoms resolve.

Management of AIP:

  • Intravenous hematin as first-line treatment
  • Narcotic analgesia for abdominal pain
  • Phenothiazine for nausea, vomiting, restlessness, and anxiety
  • Carbohydrate loading with intravenous glucose
  • Removal of precipitating factors
  • Orthoptic liver transplant is curative in patients refractory to hemin therapy.

Blistering skin lesions are characteristic features of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). PCT is a cutaneous porphyria caused due to deficient uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase enzyme. It predominantly presents with cutaneous features like blisters, milia, hypertrichosis, and hyperpigmentation over sun-exposed areas. Neurologic features are absent.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who is anxious to conceive presents to the OPD for infertility workup on day 22 of a 28-day cycle. A vaginal swab taken at this time will reveal a maturation index of?
questions.solution:
The maturation index of this woman in the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle is likely to be 0/70/30.

The maturation index is a measure of vaginal epithelial cell response to hormonal influences, particularly estrogen and progesterone. It is expressed as the percentage of parabasal, intermediate, and superficial cells in a vaginal smear.

The vaginal epithelial cells are highly sensitive to the influence of the female sex hormones. The cells are obtained for cytological study by taking a superficial vaginal swab from the upper third of the lateral vaginal walls. There are three predominant types of cells :

  • Superficial cells- These are produced under the influence of estrogen. They are large eosinophilic cells with pyknotic nuclei (cornified cells) and a clear background.
  • Parabasal cells - They are abundant in a setting of no hormonal activity. Small, round, and basophilic cells are found in a dirty background.
  • Intermediate cells- These proliferate under the influence of progesterone and androgens during pregnancy. They are transparent and basophilic.

The maturation index is calculated based on the relative percentage of parabasal, intermediate, and superficial cells per 100 cells counted.

In this case, the woman is in the secretory phase of her menstrual cycle (day 22 of a 28-day cycle), where progesterone is dominant. Progesterone stimulates the proliferation of intermediate cells, leading to a maturation index of 0/70/30 (0% parabasal, 70% intermediate, 30% superficial cells). 0/95/5 (option A) (Intermediate-dominant index) is seen during pregnancy. In a normal woman with a regular 28-day cycle on day 22, estrogen levels are not extremely low—progesterone is high, and intermediate cells should dominate.

This differs from the preovulatory phase, where estrogen is dominant, leading to more superficial cells (0/40/60). In contrast, postpartum women have no hormonal activity, resulting in a maturation index of 100/0/0 (only parabasal cells).

questions.text: According to Indian Factories Act, which of the following provisions is incorrect with respect to an adolescent working in any factory?

choices.text: Adolescents should be duly certified for fitness
The Act prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age
They can work only between 6AM and 7PM.
The work hours should be 6 hours per day

questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act, adolescents should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.

Under the Factories Act, children below 14 years of age are prohibited from working.

  • Provisions of the Factories Act, for adolescents between 15 and 18 years:
    • They can work only between 6 AM and 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.
    • They are restricted from working in dangerous occupations.
    • Adolescents should be duly certified regarding their fitness for work.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A young man who had severe anemia underwent a blood transfusion with packed red blood cells. One hour later he appeared pale and developed fever with chills, flank pain, and dark-colored urine. A direct Coombs test was positive. Which of the following is implicated in this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Type II hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in this patient presenting with acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) following blood transfusion. It occurs most often due to ABO incompatibility and commonly occurs due to negligence in patient identification or tube labeling.

Type II hypersensitivity reaction is antibody-mediated. In ABO incompatibility, preformed IgM antibodies attack the antigens on donor red cells which causes complement fixation. This results in complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria. Complement activation produces fever with shaking chills. The patient appears pale due to hemolysis and has acute flank pain with dark-colored urine (hemoglobinuria).

The direct Coombs test is usually positive. Direct Coombs test/antiglobulin test is done on the surface of red blood cells. The Coombs reagent consists of anti-human antibodies. On combining with the red blood cells, the test becomes positive, if there are RBC antibodies present in the sample. This is because the anti-human antibodies in the reagent bind with the human antibodies in the RBCs and form a link. 

Other options:

Option A: Type I hypersensitivity reaction is IgE mediated. An anaphylactic blood transfusion reaction is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. However, it presents within seconds to minutes of blood transfusion with hypotension, urticaria, angioedema, and wheezing.

Option C: Type III hypersensitivity reaction, also known as immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, occurs when antigen-antibody complexes deposition leads to complement activation. Examples include SLE, serum sickness, and the Arthus reaction.

Option D: Type IV hypersensitivity , also known as a cell-mediated or delayed hypersensitivity reaction, is caused by activated T lymphocytes. Examples include contact dermatitis and tuberculin skin testing.

questions.text: Which of the following describes Brown's sign seen in a case of glomus tumor?

choices.text: Red reflex through the intact tympanic membrane
Erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest
Pulsation and blanching with increased ear canal pressure
Tumor appearing to arise from the floor of the middle ear

questions.solution:
Pulsation and blanching of the tumour on increasing ear canal pressure using Siegel's speculum is known as Brown's sign. This is seen in intratympanic glomus tumours.

Glomus tumours are the most common benign tumours of the middle ear. The tumours comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies, which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IX cranial nerve. 

Depending on the area from which it arises, they are classified as Glomus jugulare (dome of the jugular bulb) and Glomus tympanicum (promontory of the middle ear). The presentation of glomus tumours is as follows:

Intratympanic presentation

  • Progressive hearing loss
  • Pulsatile tinnitus is synchronous with pulse and can be stopped by carotid pressure
  • Otoscopy: Red reflex through the intact tympanic membrane 
  • Rising sign when tumour arises from the floor of the middle ear
  • Pulsation or Brown sign: the tumour pulsates and blanches when the ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel's speculum. This reverses when pressure is released.

Polyp presentation

  • Profuse bleeding
  • Otorrhea if there is a secondary infection
  • Red vascular polyp filling the meatus that bleeds easily

Cranial nerve palsies

  • Dysphagia and hoarseness with unilateral paralysis of the soft palate and pharynx (CN IX and X)
  • Vocal cord paralysis  (CN X)
  • Weakness of the trapezius and sternomastoid muscles (CN XI)
  • Atrophy of half of the tongue (CN XII)

The audible may be bruit over the mastoid. The Phelp sign on CT is the erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest, seen in glomus jugulare tumours. It is intact in glomus tympanicum.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding the organism that most commonly causes the condition given in the image ?

choices.text: It is a gram positive cocci which shows α hemolytic activity
M protein is the virulence factor

questions.solution:
The image given above shows acute paronychia, which is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Staphylococcus aureus produces both coagulase and clumping factor.  

Coagulase, an enzyme-like protein, is produced extracellularly that clots oxalated or citrated plasma. Coagulase binds to prothrombin, together, they become enzymatically active and initiate fibrin polymerization.  

The clumping factor is cell wall-bound and is an example of MSCRAMM - microbial surface components recognizing adhesive matrix molecules. It is responsible for the adherence of the organisms to fibrinogen and fibrin. When mixed with plasma, S aureus forms clumps. The clumping factor is distinct from coagulase. Because the clumping factor induces a strong immunogenic response in the host, it has been the focus of vaccine efforts.

Other options:

Option A:  Staphylococcus Aureus is a gram-positive cocci that shows β-hemolytic activity with a clear area surrounding the colony on blood agar. 

Option B: Staph aureus ferments mannitol, which distinguishes it from other subspecies. Mannitol-salt agar is a commonly used screening device for S. aureus. Staphylococcus aureus ferments mannitol, which lowers the pH, causing the agar to turn yellow, whereas S. epidermidis does not ferment mannitol, and the agar remains pink.

Option C:  Protein A is an important virulence factor of Staph. aureus. Whereas M protein is the important virulence factor of Streptococcus pyogenes, which blocks phagocytosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 4 presents for evaluation before undergoing a renal transplant. The nephrologist plans to start immunosuppressive therapy but decides to avoid nephrotoxic drugs. Which of the following immunosuppressants would be the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate immunosuppressant for this patient is Sirolimus.

Sirolimus (also known as Rapamycin) is an mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) inhibitor. mTOR is a protein kinase that blocks cell cycle progression from the G phase to the S phase transition. It suppresses T-cell activation by inhibiting IL-2 signal transduction.

Sirolimus is indicated for the prophylaxis of organ transplant rejection. It has also been incorporated into stents to inhibit local cell proliferation and blood vessel occlusion. mTOR inhibitors have been shown to have anticancer effects, especially on skin cancer; they are considered the immunosuppressants of choice in patients with a history of malignancy. Unlike calcineurin inhibitors, sirolimus is not nephrotoxic. Therefore, it is often preferred in patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction to prevent further kidney damage. 

It is associated with bone marrow suppression, delayed wound healing, and hyperlipidemia. 

Other options:

Options A, B, and D: Cyclosporine, Tacrolimus, and Voclosporin are calcineurin inhibitors, which are nephrotoxic drugs.

questions.text: The National Health Stack (NHS) developed by NITI Aayog aims to improve healthcare delivery in India. What is its primary purpose?

choices.text: To establish a unified digital health record system
Offer specialized medical software for clinical use
Create a single hospital network for metropolitan areas

questions.solution:
The primary purpose of the National Health Stack developed by NITI Aayog is to establish a unified digital health records system that facilitates better coordination, accessibility, and efficiency in healthcare services across India.

NHS is a nationwide initiative to digitize health services across India (not just limited to metropolitan areas or a single hospital network).

The key components of the National Health Stack are: 

  • An electronic national health registry that would serve as a single source of health data for the nation
  • A coverage and claims platform for schemes like Ayushmann Bharat
  • A national health analytics platform
  • Other horizontal components include a unique digital health ID, health data dictionaries, supply chain management for drugs, and payment gateways

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following is true with respect to this lesion?

choices.text: Vascular lesions characterised by the tortuous constriction of arterioles
Fill from the outer to center on applying and releasing pressure over the lesion
Seen in estrogen-deficient states such as emergency pill use and pregnancy
Mainly seen in chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease

questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi and it is mainly seen in chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease.

Spider naevi (nevus araneus) are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the center outward.

They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use.
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease, and
  • Thyrotoxicosis

questions.text:
A 55-year-old female comes for a routine eye checkup. On examination, the visual acuity is 36/60. A slit lamp examination reveals a shallow anterior chamber and close proximity of the iris to the cornea in the periphery. IOP and fundal examination are normal. What is the diagnosis?

IOP - Intraocular pressure
questions.solution:
Suspicious clinical signs on routine ocular examination such as shallow anterior chamber and close proximity of the iris to the cornea in the periphery along with normal IOP and fundus examination point towards Primary angle-closure suspect (PACS).

Classification:

Primary angle-closure suspect (PACS)
  • Gonioscopy shows posterior meshwork ITC (iridotrabecular contact) in three or more quadrants but no peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS).
  • Slit lamp examination shows a shallow anterior chamber.
  • Intraocular pressure (IOP), optic disc, and visual field are normal.
  • The risk of PACG at 5 years is increased.
Primary angle closure (PAC)
  • Gonioscopy shows three or more quadrants of ITC with raised IOP and/or PAS or excessive pigment smudging on the TM.
  • Normal optic disc and field.
Primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG)
  • ITC in three or more quadrants with glaucomatous optic neuropathy.
  • Optic nerve damage from an episode of severe IOP elevation, such as acute angle closure, may not appear as typical glaucomatous cupping.

Management of PACS:

Patients with PAC suspect in both eyes need to be followed periodically and educated about the symptoms of the disease. Prophylactic Laser iridotomy is usually done in those with a high risk of developing acute congestive angle closure or chronic angle-closure glaucoma.

Other options:

Option A: Normal IOP rules out Primary angle closure.

Option B: Normal IOP and fundus examination rule out Primary angle-closure glaucoma.

Option D: In Normal-Tension Glaucoma, there are typical glaucomatous disc changes. Visual field defects are associated with a normal IOP. The angle of the anterior chamber is open on gonioscopy and there is no secondary cause for glaucomatous disc changes.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: In pregnancy, which cardiac condition is usually stable, and ventricular function can even improve due to the reduction in afterload?
questions.solution:
In pregnancy, mitral valve prolapse is a stable condition, and ventricular function can improve due to the reduction in afterload. Mitral valve prolapse patients generally have an excellent prognosis in pregnancy.

Mitral valve prolapse is a condition where there is improper mitral valve alignment resulting in prolapse of valvular leaflets into the atrium during ventricular contraction. In pregnancy, unless valve prolapse is severe, it is not associated with adverse outcomes. An exception to this is prolapse due to myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve.

Mitral and aortic insufficiency may be associated with an improvement in ventricular function in pregnancy due to the fall in afterload due to reduced peripheral vascular resistance by the action of hormones in pregnancy.  Hypervolemia is also known to improve mitral valvular leaflet alignment in mitral valve prolapse on echocardiography.

Based on the cardiac risk of various heart conditions, the WHO risk classification of heart diseases in pregnancy has four levels.

  • WHO 1: Morbidity and mortality risk no higher than the general population. E.g., Trivial mitral regurgitation
  • WHO2: Small increase in mortality risk and moderate increase in morbidity risk. E.g., Unoperated VSD
  • WHO3: Intermediate increase in mortality risk and severe increase in morbidity risk. E.g., Moderate MS
  • WHO4: Severe increase in mortality risk, pregnancy contraindicated, and termination advised. E.g., Pulmonary arterial hypertension

Hemodynamic Parameters and their changes in pregnancy:

  1. Cardiac output: Increases
  2. Heart rate: Increases
  3. Left ventricular stroke work index: Increases
  4. Systemic and pulmonary vascular resistance: Decreases
  5. Colloidal osmotic pressure: Decreases

Other Options:

Option A: In mitral stenosis, due to a fixed cardiac output state, preload increase in pregnancy becomes increasingly difficult to accommodate. The greater the stenosis, the increased the risk for pulmonary edema and heart failure.

Option C: Pulmonary Arterial hypertension is exacerbated by the high output state of pregnancy and may swiftly result in right heart failure. Severe pulmonary arterial hypertension is an absolute contraindication for pregnancy. ( WHO Grade 4)

Option D: Coarctation of the aorta is a moderate to severe risk condition due to the morbidity associated with it. Around half of the aortic dissection cases in women are associated with pregnancy. Up to a diameter of > 15 mm at the constriction site of the coarctation is considered safe, but smaller diameters increase the risk of hypertension, congestive heart failure, and aortic rupture in that pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a metabolic condition presents with progressive right shoulder pain for the past 3 months. The pain worsens when she tries to comb her hair or touch her back. Shoulder movements are also restricted. Which of the following parameters will you consider while assessing this patient's metabolic condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of progressive right shoulder pain with painful restriction of abduction (combing the hair) and internal rotation (touching the back) are suggestive of adhesive capsulitis or frozen shoulder. It is usually seen in diabetic patients with poor glycemic control. Therefore, HbA1c levels need to be assessed in this patient.

Frozen shoulder is a disorder characterized by progressive pain and stiffness of the shoulder. It usually resolves spontaneously. Frozen shoulder can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary, due to conditions like diabetes mellitus, hyperthyroidism and cardiovascular diseases or as a complication of Colles' fracture. 

The underlying pathologic changes are synovial inflammation with subsequent reactive capsular fibrosis. The main clinical feature is a painful restriction of active and passive shoulder movements. External rotation is maximally restricted followed by abduction and internal rotation. 

Frozen shoulder passes through three stages:

  • Stage I (stage of pain) → patient complains of acute pain and movement restriction
  • Stage II (stage of stiffness) → pain gradually decreases and the patient now complains of stiff shoulder
  • Stage III (stage of recovery) → patient will have no pain and movements will gradually recover, but may not return to the normal range of motion

A painful restriction of movement in the presence of normal X-rays and a natural progression through three successive stages are considered to be characteristic of this condition. The diagnosis is made clinically.

Conservative treatment includes analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and pendulum exercises. The condition resolves spontaneously over 18 months but up to 40% of the patients may have some residual symptoms. Surgical treatment is indicated when there is prolonged movement restriction that has failed to respond to conservative management. Arthroscopic capsular release is increasingly being employed to treat frozen shoulder.

questions.text:
Arrange the following patterns of obsessions seen in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) in order from the most common to the least common:
  1. Pathological doubt
  2. Symmetry
  3. Intrusive thoughts
  4. Contamination
questions.solution:
In obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), the most common symptom patterns of obsessions seen in OCD are in the order Contamination > Pathological doubt > Intrusive thoughts > Symmetry.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions, which cause severe distress to the patient.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. Conscious, standardized, recurrent behaviours are called compulsions, like counting, checking, and are done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

Symptom patterns:

  • Contamination - This is the most common symptom pattern of OCD where objects are perceived to be contaminated followed by either washing or a severe compulsion to avoid touching objects which are thought to be contaminated. In extreme cases, patients may rub the skin off their hands due to excessive hand washing or refuse to leave the house for fear of germs.
  • Pathological doubt—This is the second most common symptom pattern. The patient presents with an obsession with doubt and a compulsion to check. This obsession arises due to possible danger or violence (e.g., forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door) and is followed by multiple trips to check, for example, whether the stove is turned off.
  • Intrusive thoughts - These patients have intrusive obsessional thoughts without compulsion and this is the third most common symptom pattern. These thoughts could be sexual or an aggressive act that the patient disagrees with, which might lead to the patient reporting themselves to the police/confessing to a spiritual leader.
  • Symmetry—This is the fourth most common pattern, and it can lead to a compulsion to be slow. Patients can take hours to eat a meal or shave their faces.

Diagnosis of OCD is by the presence of:

  1. Obsessions, compulsions or both
  2. Time-consuming symptoms
  3. Symptoms not related to substance abuse
  4. Symptoms not better explained by other mental disorders

Treatment of OCD includes:

  • Pharmacotherapy: SSRI or clomipramine
  • Behavioural therapy: 
    • Exposure and response prevention
    • Desensitization
    • Thought stopping
    • Flooding
    • Implosion therapy
    • Aversive conditioning

A combination of behavioral and pharmacotherapy is found to be the most effective.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient was diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome. Which of the following patterns of paralysis can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is associated with ascending flaccid paralysis.

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, autoimmune polyneuropathy. Most of the cases occur after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. GBS is caused when immune response/antibodies are produced against external antigens like infections (Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, HHV) and vaccines (Influenza). These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue (called molecular mimicry).

The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions.

Sensations carried by large myelinated fibers like deep tendon reflexes and proprioception are also affected. Pain and temperature sensations are relatively preserved. Pain in the neck, shoulder, back, buttocks, and thighs is a common complaint in the early phase of the disease. The pain is usually aching or throbbing in nature. Autonomic involvement is also frequent in patients with GBS and usually presents with loss of vasomotor control with wide fluctuations in blood pressure and postural hypotension.

The patient is likely to have clinical worsening during the first four weeks following the onset of weakness. After this, the symptoms plateau, and any further deterioration is unlikely. Almost one-third of the patients require mechanical ventilation due to weakness of the respiratory muscles. 

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: All of the following pass deep to the marked structure, except?

choices.text: Palmar cutaneous branch of median nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the flexor retinaculum of the wrist. It can be identified by the palmaris longus tendon passing superficial to it and becoming the palmar aponeurosis. Palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum. 

Structures lying superficial to flexor retinaculum are:

  • Palmaris longus tendon
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar vessels

The structures lying deep to flexor retinaculum are:

  • Lateral compartment:
    • Flexor carpi radialis
  • Medial compartment:
    • Median nerve
    • Flexor pollicis longus
    • 4 tendons each of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus

questions.text: An elderly female patient reports painless decreased central vision in her left eye for last 2 months. On examination her peripheral vision is normal. She is on treatment for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Fundoscopy revealed the following findings. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is not indicated in the treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with fundoscopy showing sub-retinal hemorrhage is suggestive of exudative age-related macular degeneration (ARMD). Adalimumab is not indicated in the treatment of her condition.

Intravitreal injections of anti-VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor) agents such as bevacizumab (option D), brolucizumab (option A), aflibercept, ranibizumab (option C) and pegaptanib are used in the treatment of wet ARMD. Adalimumab is an anti-TNF antibody approved for use in rheumatoid arthritis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis, plaque psoriasis, Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis;  Not an anti-VEGF agent.

ARMD is a degenerative condition affecting the retina and is a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. It is classified into two major types based on the presence or absence of subretinal fluid:

  • Dry ARMD 
  • Wet ARMD

The wet or exudative type of macular degeneration is due to leakage of fluid from neovascularization beneath the retina. This is known as a subretinal neovascular membrane. Fundoscopic exam may reveal sub-retinal hemorrhage.

Treatment of ARMD depends on the location of the choroidal neovascularization membrane:

a) For extrafoveal membrane - Laser photocoagulation.

b) For subfoveal and juxta foveal membranes, treatment options are as follows:

  • Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF agents (bevacizumab, brolucizumab, aflibercept, ranibizumab and pegaptanib)
  • Photodynamic therapy - the dye used is verteporfin, followed by exposure to light from a diode
  • Transpupillary thermotherapy

Related Pearl: Monoclonal antibodies nomenclature

Murine - 0% human: “omab” (Tositumomab)

Chimeric - 65% human: “ximab” (Rituximab)

Humanized - 95% human: “zumab” (Trastuzumab)

Fully human - 100% human: “umab” (Adalimumab)

questions.text: A patient presents with an amoebic liver abscess. He does not have any diarrhea or blood in his stool. His only complaint is vague abdominal pain. On examination of stool, cysts of Entamoeba histolytica are present. How would you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with an amoebic liver abscess and cysts in stool needs treatment with metronidazole (or tinidazole) + a luminal amoebicide like paromomycin, diloxanide furoate, or iodoquinone.

As metronidazole is so well absorbed in the gut, the levels may not be therapeutic in the colonic lumen. The drug is also less effective against cysts. Therefore, patients with amoebic colitis or amoebic liver abscess should receive a luminal agent in addition.

Note: Albendazole is an antihelmintic drug, used to treat hydatid cyst, roundworms, hookworm, etc.

questions.text: While examining  movements of the eyeball in the ophthalmology OPD, the final year PG resident asks you to name a pair of contralateral synergistic muscles. Which of the following options represent the correct pair?

choices.text: Right superior rectus and Right inferior oblique
Right superior rectus and Left inferior oblique
Right superior oblique and right inferior rectus
Right superior oblique and left inferior oblique

questions.solution:
Right superior rectus and Left inferior oblique represent a pair of contralateral synergistic muscles.

Yoke muscles are also known as contralateral synergists. They are pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during version movements

Examples:

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right LR and Left MR
  • Right SO and Left IR
  • Right IO and Left SR
  • Right SR and Left IO
  • Right IR and Left SO

(MR: Medial rectus; LR: Lateral rectus; SO: Superior oblique; IO: Inferior oblique; SR: Superior rectus; IR: Inferior rectus.)

Note: Version movements also known as conjugate movements are synchronous (simultaneous) symmetric movements of both the eyes in the same direction.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman was diagnosed with clinically significant macular edema secondary to non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy and was treated with pan-retinal photocoagulation. Despite this, she did not find any improvement in her symptoms. OCT was done and it showed vitreomacular traction with elevated fovea. What is the next best step in her management?

OCT: Ocular coherence tomography
questions.solution:
Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with the removal of the posterior hyaloid is the preferred management in diabetic macular edema with traction. 

Diabetic maculopathy or macular edema is characterized by the accumulation of excess fluid in the subretinal space. It can develop at any stage of diabetic retinopathy (DR), from mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). 

Clinically significant macular edema (CSME) is diagnosed when one of the following three are present on the slit lamp examination: 

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 microns of the foveal center
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 microns of the foveal center along with adjacent retinal thickening
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening ≥ 1 disc diameter, at least a part of which is within one disc diameter of the foveal center

For diagnosis and further deciding the treatment plan for the patients, OCT is routinely followed. It classifies DME into: 

  • Non-tractional variants are seen in cystoid macular edema, and spongy thickening of the macula, and are managed conservatively
  • Tractional DME has vitreomacular traction or thickened posterior hyaloid and is managed by surgical intervention

In vitreomacular traction, fibrovascular components leak from the vessels into the vitreous cavity and form fibrous bands. It increases the risk of tractional retinal detachment and can rapidly progress into stage 4 diabetic retinopathy.

Thus, surgical management by pars plana vitrectomy with removal of posterior hyaloid is indicated. Scleral buckling and internal tamponade with PPV are also done if the detachment includes the retina. 

The image below is of an OCT in a normal patient. 

The image below is an OCT showing vitreomacular traction. The fovea is elevated from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), as indicated by the arrows. Pseudocysts and retinal morphology distortion can also be seen at the site of traction.

Focal laser photocoagulation and pan-retinal photocoagulation are done in progressive diabetic retinopathy. They are contraindicated in tractional DME due to the risk of further injuries. Anti-VEGF agents like bevacizumab are not effective in vitreomacular traction.  

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: Which of the following is true about breast milk jaundice?

choices.text: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in the infant
It is seen in the first week of life
It is due to inadequate breastfeeding

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding should be continued in infants with Breastmilk jaundice.

Breastmilk jaundice usually occurs after the first week of life. It is caused by the presence of β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin. Therefore, it causes Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Most neonates would not have a dangerous level of Total Serum bilirubin and don't require any treatment. Mothers should continue breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding jaundice begins in the first week of life. It occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding. Inadequate breastfeeding can be caused by Improper breastfeeding technique, breast engorgement, cracked or sore nipples, late preterm gestation, and ineffective sucking.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child comes to the ED after a fall on an outstretched hand. The X-ray of the left arm is shown below. The patient is unable to abduct the thumb and flex his wrist. There is a loss of sensation over the radial three-and-a-half digits. Distant pulses are faintly felt. Which of the following would be seen when the patient is asked to make a fist?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows an anteriorly displaced supracondylar fracture of the distal humerus. The clinical features described indicate a median nerve injury. When asked to make a fist, the position of the patient's hand with the above injuries would make a pointing index sign. 

The image shows the pointing index sign:

Median nerve injuries can be described as low or high lesions.

  • Low lesions involve injury to the median nerve in front of the wrist or carpal dislocations. There is loss of abduction of the thumb and loss of sensation over the radial three and a half digits.
  • High lesions involve injury to the median nerve due to forearm fractures or elbow dislocations. It features the same symptoms as low lesions and paralysis of the long flexors to the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the radial wrist flexors, and the forearm pronator muscles. So, when asked to make a fist, the patient flexes the ulnar fingers and extends the index finger, resulting in the pointing index sign. The patient also features a characteristic pinch defect because of deficient thumb and index finger flexors. The patient is not able to pinch with the thumb and index finger flexed. Instead, the patient pinches with fully extended distal joints.

Other options:

Options B and C: Median and ulnar claw hands are seen due to loss of lumbricals, overcompensated by the other extrinsic flexors. That is, the fingers extended at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexed at the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints. Since the median nerve supplies the lateral 3 digits, clawing is seen in these digits. The ulnar nerve supplies the medial digits, and if injured will lead to clawing of these digits.

Option D: The OK gesture/ sign is made when the thumb and the index finger are pinched together, forming a ring. When the ulnar nerve is injured, there is loss of action of the lumbricals in the 4th and 5th digits. So when asked to make a fist or flex his fingers, the patient will be able to flex only the thumb, index, and middle fingers, resulting in the OK gesture.

Note: The anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) of the median nerve is another commonly injured nerve in supracondylar fractures in children. It presents with the same symptoms as high lesions but without any sensory loss. Patients with anterior interosseous nerve injury are unable to make the OK gesture due to weakness of the flexors of the thumb and the index finger.

questions.text: A patient with long-standing corticosteroid use was admitted for rhinocerebral mucormycosis. Which of the following is seen on microscopic examination?

choices.text: Broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching
Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule

questions.solution:
Under the microscope, mucormycosis is seen as broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungus that can be found in patients with acidosis, such as diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies. The most common agent is Rhizopus oryzae. The common clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis, in which the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, the eyes, and the brain invade, causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. Treatment is by surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration.

Other options:

Option B: Long conidiophores with terminal vesicles: Aspergillus

Option C: Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule: Cryptococcus neoformans

Option D: Oval, budding yeast cells: Candida

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman suffers from emotional lability, fatigue, bloating, headache, sleeplessness, and breast tenderness about 10 days before her menses. These symptoms are relieved once she starts menstruating. All of the following are recommended in the management of this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of Premenstrual syndrome (PMS). All the above-mentioned measures are recommended in the management of PMS except caffeine.

Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS) is a symptom complex associated with ovulatory cycles. It starts 7 to 14 days prior to menstruation and spontaneously resolves after menses. It occurs in the luteal phase of the cycle. When this symptom complex causes significant impairment, a diagnosis of premenstrual dysphoric disorder(PMDD) is made according to DSM-5.

Symptoms of PMS include:

  • Pain:- Headache, breast pain, abdominal cramps, muscle stiffness, backache and generalized body ache.
  • Water retention:- Breast volume increase, bloating and weight gain.
  • Behavioural changes:- Low performance, difficulty in concentration, irritability, depression, forgetfulness, low judgement, anxiety, loneliness, feeling like crying, hostility, increased appetite and cravings and sleeplessness.
  • Autonomic changes:- Dizziness, faintness, nausea, vomiting and hot flushes.

Premenstrual syndrome can be managed by dietary changes and lifestyle modifications like yoga, exercises and relaxation activities. Pharmacological therapy includes the usage of primrose oil, vitamin B1, vitamin B6, vitamin E, calcium and magnesium supplements. Foods and beverages rich in sugar and caffeine can aggravate premenstrual symptoms in some women and are generally avoided. 

Symptoms can be alleviated by the use of prostaglandin inhibitors (ibuprofen and naproxen ), Selective Serotonin Reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) like fluoxetine, GABA antagonists and anxiolytics such as alprazolam. Danazol, bromocriptine and GnRH analogues can be used to reduce breast pain. OCPs with spironolactone and Mirena IUCD can also be used.

questions.text: Under the most recent provisions of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy(MTP) Act, in which of the following situations is the abortion carried out in the most legally appropriate manner?

choices.text: Two doctors deciding MTP for a fetus>24 weeks with congenital anomalies
One doctor deciding MTP for a fetus of 22 weeks in case of rape
Two doctors deciding MTP for a fetus of 22 weeks in case of divorce
Medical board deciding MTP for fetus  of 22 weeks in case of contraceptive failure

questions.solution:
Under the most recent provisions of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy( MTP) Act, two doctors deciding MTP for a fetus of 22 weeks in case of divorce is the abortion carried out in the most legally appropriate manner.

According to the most recent amendments to the MTP Act, MTP can be offered to a woman with a change of marital status, such as divorce or widowhood, from 20-24 weeks if the opinion of two doctors is taken. MTP Act amendment has the following changes made in the most recent amendments(October 2022 ruling):

  • MTP can be offered to all women irrespective of marital status. This includes MTP conducted from 20-24 weeks in the case of married women for preexisting provisions such as rape, gross physical or mental trauma, mental illness, and congenital anomalies but also for a change in marital status such as desertion, widowhood, or divorce.
  • MTP may also be conducted in the case of unmarried women from 20-24 weeks in case of a change in the status of their partner such as death, abandonment, etc.

Other Options:

Option A: In case of >24 weeks with congenital anomalies, a medical board is required to be constituted, consisting of a pediatrician, obstetrician, radiologist, and a person appointed by the state to decide if there is an adequate clause for conducting an MTP.

Option B: While rape is an indication for MTP from 20-24 weeks, ideally two doctors must provide their opinion before MTP may be conducted. However, if a lifesaving procedure is conducted for the mother in case of an emergency, the doctor is not implicated in a crime. Option C is a legally backed answer, hence it is a better option.

Option D: Contraceptive failure is not an indication for abortion at 22 weeks. Contraceptive failure causing mental anguish is a reason for MTP up to 20 weeks.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a known case of MDR-TB, currently on BPaLM regimen, presents with diarrhea, agitation, and tremors. He was also recently diagnosed with depression and was started on duloxetine. The physician suspects the interaction of duloxetine with one of the antibiotics to be responsible for the given symptoms. Which of the following drugs is likely responsible for the given symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of diarrhea, agitation, and tremors, along with his medication history, suggest serotonin syndrome, likely triggered by the interaction between Linezolid (part of the BPaLM regimen for MDR-TB) and Duloxetine (an SNRI). Linezolid inhibits monoamine oxidase, increasing serotonin levels and precipitating serotonin syndrome.

The BPaLM MDR-TB regimen consists of Bedaquilline, Pretomanid, Linezolid, and Moxifloxacin. It is an all-oral regimen given for 6 months. 

Duloxetine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used for the treatment of depression. It acts by inhibiting serotonin reuptake and thus increasing the concentration in the synaptic cleft. In combination with other serotonergic drugs, it may lead to serotonin syndrome. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Autonomic instability - hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, vomiting, and diarrhea
  • Altered mental status - agitation, confusion, delirium
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity - tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus

The common drugs that can precipitate serotonin syndrome when used in combination include MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

Management involves stopping the offending agents, supportive care with benzodiazepines, and, in severe cases, cyproheptadine (a serotonin antagonist) can be used.

questions.text: Which type of aquaporin is present in the portion of the nephron that is responsible for maximum reabsorption of Na +?
questions.solution:
Maximum reabsorption of Na + occurs in proximal convoluted tubules and Aquaporin 1 is present at this site in the kidney.

Despite a handful number of aquaporins present in the human body, the kidneys predominantly have the aquaporins 1, 2, 3, and 4.

Aquaporin 1 is present in the proximal convoluted tubules. It is localized to both the basolateral and apical membrane of the proximal tubules. Its presence allows water to move rapidly out of the tubule along the osmotic gradients and isotonicity is maintained. 

Aquaporin 2, which is located in the collecting duct is under the influence of the antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Interaction of ADH with V2 receptors in the basolateral membrane causes the insertion of aquaporin 2 channels in the apical membrane of the tubular cell to facilitate water reabsorption.

AQP-3 and AQP-4 are present on the basolateral side of the cell membrane, especially in the collecting ducts. They provide a path for water to rapidly exit the cells, and are not regulated by ADH.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is referred to your center for evaluation of short stature. The child's parents are found to be first cousins. Further evaluation led to the diagnosis of Laron-type dwarfism. What is the best-suited management for her condition?

choices.text: Recombinant human growth hormone releasing hormone

questions.solution:
Laron-type dwarfism, also known as GH-insensitivity syndrome, is characterized by GH-receptor anomalies. Treatment is by subcutaneous injections of recombinant insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) (a growth-promoting hormone).

Laron-type dwarfism is an autosomal recessive disorder. The primary clinical symptom associated with this condition is short stature. The recombinant human growth hormone therapy is often ineffective in Laron syndrome. Only some cases with partial growth hormone insensitivity may show a response at high doses.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with hypoglycemia and muscle weakness. On examination, he had hepatomegaly and growth restriction. Investigations revealed the accumulation of characteristic branched polysaccharides on enzyme assay and distention of hepatocytes with glycogen in the liver. Which enzyme is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of growth restriction, hypoglycemia and muscle weakness with the accumulation of branched polysaccharides(limit dextrin) and glycogen deposition in the liver suggests a diagnosis of Cori disease, which occurs due to the deficiency of a debranching enzyme. Hypoglycemia and muscle weakness indicate debranching enzyme deficiency in both the liver and muscles.

Glycogen debrancher deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease III) is also known as Cori disease, Forbes disease, and limit dextrinosis. When the debranching enzyme is defective, there is incomplete glycogen breakdown with an accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branch chains, resembling limit dextrin.

It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. When both the liver and muscle are involved, it is termed type IIIa GSD, while if only the liver is involved (15% of cases), it is classified as type IIIb.

The disease presents in infancy and childhood with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, short stature, variable skeletal myopathy, and variable cardiomyopathy. Hepatic symptoms in type III GSD usually improve with age, however, progressive liver cirrhosis and failure can occur. Hepatocellular carcinoma may develop. Hypoglycemia is associated with other features:

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Fasting ketosis
  • Elevated liver transaminases
  • Normal blood lactate and uric acid levels 

It may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease (Type I GSD). However, the accumulation of limit dextrins (branched polysaccharides) is unique to Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through liver, muscle, or both enzyme assays.

Treatment is mainly by preventing hypoglycemia. Frequent high-carbohydrate meals with cornstarch supplements or nocturnal gastric drip feedings are effective. A high-protein diet during the day plus overnight protein enteral infusion is also effective. A hepatic transplant may be done for patients with progressive cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B. Glucose 6-phosphatase deficiency of this leads to Type 1 GSD or Von Gierke's disease. It presents with growth retardation, glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, ketosis, hyperlipemia, and elevated uric acid levels.

Option C. Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Type V GSD or Mc Ardle disease. It presents with poor exercise tolerance,  myoglobinuria on strenuous exercise, and increased levels of creatinine kinase.

Option D. Lysosomal acid α-glucosidase deficiency leads to Type II GSD or Pompe's disease. In infants, it presents as hypotonia, muscle weakness, cardiac enlargement, and failure, fatal early. Late-onset presentation is with progressive muscle weakness and atrophy.

questions.text: A person working in mining presents with chronic cough and dyspnea. The pulmonary function tests show a restrictive pattern. Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibres, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibres surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages suggest a diagnosis of silicosis.

Silicosis is the most common chronic occupational lung disease in the world. Occupational exposures associated with silicosis include mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass and cement manufacturing, and quarrying of granite. The pathogenic form of silica is crystalline quartz. Inhaled silica crystals are phagocytosed by macrophages and cause the release of IL-1 and IL-18. This causes the recruitment of more inflammatory cells and fibroblasts to the site, leading to collagen deposition.

Silicosis can present in the following ways:

  • Acute silicosis occurs due to exposure to high concentrations of silica in closed spaces. Patients have clinical manifestations within a few months to years of exposure
  • Chronic silicosis occurs due to long-term exposure to silica, often 10 to 30 years
  • Progressive massive fibrosis can occur following both acute and chronic silicosis. The patients present with more severe cough and dyspnea than simple silicosis and might develop respiratory failure and cor pulmonale

Since silicosis leads to macrophage dysfunction, it increases the risk of tuberculosis in patients. Silica also has immunoadjuvant properties and might lead to autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. Silica exposure is also considered to be a risk factor for lung cancer.

Calcification of hilar lymph nodes producing a characteristic eggshell pattern is seen in many cases of silicosis. The fibrotic areas present in the lung parenchyma can be identified on the HRCT of the lung. Acute silicosis may show diffuse ground-glass opacities with thickening of the interlobular septae, which is termed as crazy pavement appearance.

Other options:

Option B: Asbestosis is caused by asbestos exposure and typically shows asbestos bodies, fibrosis, and pleural plaques. The histopathological image given below shows asbestosis.

Option C: Anthracosis- It is a pulmonary lesion seen in coal miners and is also seen to some extent in urban dwellers and tobacco smokers. The inhaled carbon pigment, known as anthracotic pigment, is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages and accumulates in the connective tissue adjacent to the bronchi or in the lung hilus. The histopathological image given below shows anthracosis.

Option D: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated, predominantly interstitial lung disorder caused by intense and prolonged exposure to inhaled organic antigens. The affected individuals have an abnormal sensitivity or heightened reactivity to the causative antigen, which leads to pathologic changes that primarily involve the alveolar walls. Microscopic findings reveal interstitial pneumonitis, consisting primarily of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages (eosinophils are rare), as well as non-necrotizing granulomas, as shown in the image given below.

questions.text: The below image shows the ocular finding of an individual who was operated on for a Wilms tumor. Which of the following complications can occur in such an eye?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient who has undergone surgery for a Wilms tumor. The ocular finding reveals aniridia, a feature associated with WAGR syndrome. Secondary glaucoma is a common complication of aniridia.

Aniridia refers to the absence of an iris. It may be congenital or acquired. The causes of aniridia are:

  • Congenital: PAX6 mutations, WAGR syndrome
  • Acquired: Traumatic aniridia

In aniridia, which is usually bilateral in congenital causes, a narrow rim of iris tissue may be seen on examination using a slit lamp. The ciliary processes and suspensory ligaments can be seen. The angle of the anterior chamber has an abnormal structure, and hence these individuals are highly predisposed to the development of secondary glaucoma.

Other complications of aniridia are:

  • Keratopathy and dry eye
  • Cataract
  • Hemeralopia and glare from bright light
  • Ectopia lentis may be associated with it

In cataracts due to congenital or traumatic aniridia, a special Aniridia IOL may be inserted, which contains a peripheral zone of darkening that substitutes for the absent iris. WAGR syndrome refers to Wilms tumor, aniridia, genital abnormalities, and mental retardation and is a genetic cause of aniridia.

Other options:

Option B: Scleromalacia perforans is a necrotizing scleritis without inflammation which is seen in seropositive rheumatoid arthritis patients. It may cause perforation of the globe. The below image shows scleromalacia perforans.

Option C: Corectopia refers to the displacement of the pupil from its normal central position. It may be seen in high myopia. The below image shows corectopia.

Option D: Iridocyclitis cannot occur in Aniridia when there is no Iris or Pupil.

questions.text: Paalman and McElin's criteria is used for the diagnosis of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Paalman and McElin's criteria is used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy.

Paalman and McElin's criteria is as follows:

  • Soft enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea without cramping pain
  • Products of conception entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os

Other options:

Option A: Ovarian pregnancy- Spiegelberg’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

Option B: Abdominal pregnancy- Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.

questions.text: The deamination of ______ and the methylation of ______ both lead to the formation of thymine.
questions.solution:
The deamination of 5-Methylcytosine and methylation of uracil leads to the formation of thymine.

Thymine and uracil are pyrimidine bases found only in DNA and RNA, respectively. The only difference in the structures of these two bases is the presence of a methyl group in thymine. Thus, the methylation of uracil will form thymine.

Deamination is the removal of an amino group (NH2) from a chemical compound. Deamination of cytosine forms uracil. Thus, the deamination of methylated cytosine (5-methylcytosine) forms methylated uracil, which is thymine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice and neck swelling that increases in size on coughing and on performing the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following membranes does the swelling herniate through to appear as depicted in the figure below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, and neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver is suggestive of external laryngocele that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane to appears as a swelling in the neck.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to abnormal distention of saccule present in the ventricle of the larynx (sinus of the larynx). It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as a distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
  • External laryngocele extends further superolaterally, pierces the thyrohyoid membrane, and may appear as a neck mass.
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components
     

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele.

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old paraplegic man presents with a non-healing ulcer over the sacral region for the past 2 months. On examination, a deep ulcer with exposed bone and foul-smelling discharge is seen as given in the image below. The patient's temperature is 40.5 C, and lab tests indicate an elevated WBC count. Select the incorrect statement regarding the management of this patient.

VAC - vacuum-assisted closure

choices.text: Surgical debridement is the first step in management
Empirical IV Antibiotics should be started immediately
Negative pressure wound therapy (VAC) can be used as an adjunct
Flap reconstruction should be done immediately to prevent worsening

questions.solution:
This patient has a stage IV pressure ulcer/injury. The presence of fever, foul-smelling discharge, and leukocytosis suggests spreading infection, which could be due to osteomyelitis. Flap reconstruction should not be done immediately in this patient.

Pressure sores, also known as pressure injuries, bed sores, or pressure ulcers, are ulcers that occur due to prolonged pressure (>30 mm Hg) on certain sites, thereby leading to tissue necrosis. The common sites involved are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral >medial), and occiput. Paraplegic patients, elderly patients, and severely ill patients are at higher risk of developing pressure sores.

Pressure sores are staged as:

Stage 1 - Erythema with no blanching and no breach in the epidermis.
Stage 2- Partial-thickness skin loss with epidermal and dermal involvement.
Stage 3- Full-thickness skin loss with intact fascia but the involvement of the subcutaneous tissue.
Stage 4- Full-thickness skin loss extending to the fascia with massive tissue destruction and involvement of muscle, bone, tendon, or joint. 

The management of pressure ulcers depends upon the stage of the ulcer and other associated symptoms. Stage 3 and 4 ulcers may require surgical intervention. Surgical management (eg. flap reconstruction) of pressure ulcers follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. But, it is not done immediately.

Initial management includes proper surgical debridement of devitalized and infected tissues. The vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used as an adjunct to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. If there are systemic signs of infection, then IV antibiotics should be started empirically.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the outpatient department with a history of progressive exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and recurrent episodes of syncope. On examination, a systolic murmur is heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the changes in the murmur during specific manoeuvres?

choices.text: The murmur increases in intensity during Valsalva maneuver
Handgrip exercise increases the murmur's intensity
The murmur increases in intensity with rapid squatting
Standing from a squatting position augments the murmur

questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of dyspnoea, recurrent episodes of syncope and a systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids in an elderly patient, are suggestive of aortic stenosis. Here, the murmur increases in intensity with rapid squatting due to an increase in venous return and preload.

In aortic stenosis, maneuvres that increase left ventricular stroke volume (e.g., rapid squatting) increase the intensity of the murmur by enhancing the flow across the stenotic valve.

Conversely, maneuvres that decrease stroke volume (e.g., standing or Valsalva strain phase) reduce murmur intensity. maneuvres like handgrip increase afterload, diminishing the pressure gradient across the valve and subsequently decreasing the intensity of the murmur.

Performing dynamic maneuvres during auscultation aids in diagnosis. Dynamic maneuvres alter preload, afterload, and cardiac contractility, leading to changes in the intensity of murmurs.

The effect of dynamic maneuvres on different valvular lesions is listed in the table below:

MVP Click and murmur occur earlier.

questions.text: Gestational diabetes mellitus typically develops during the second or third trimester of pregnancy. One of the key hormones, human placental lactogen (hPL), plays an important role in developing insulin resistance. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the circulating levels of hPL in the maternal blood?

choices.text: hPL levels peak at 10th weeks of gestation
hPL levels are detectable in maternal serum by 3 weeks of gestation
hPL levels depends on the size of the placenta
As much as 1 g/day of hPL can be secreted late in the gestation

questions.solution:
Human placental lactogen (hPL) levels do not peak at the 10th week of gestation.

The hPL levels rise progressively throughout the pregnancy. Maternal hPL levels increase steadily throughout pregnancy, correlating with placental growth. Instead, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the hormone whose levels peak at the 10th week of gestation and then decline.

During pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, rising hPL levels induce insulin resistance, shifting maternal metabolism from anabolism to catabolism. This promotes lipolysis and fatty acid utilization, ensuring glucose is preserved for fetal growth.

To counteract insulin resistance, maternal β cells undergo hyperplasia, increasing insulin secretion. However, if this compensation is insufficient, gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) develops, typically resolving after delivery. Other hormones like estrogens and progestins further contribute to pregnancy-induced insulin resistance.

Other options:

Option B: hPL levels are detectable in maternal serum by 3 weeks of gestation- hPL is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast and can be detected within the syncytiotrophoblast by 10 days after conception and in maternal circulation by 3 weeks of gestation.

Option C: hPL levels depend on the size of the placenta- The quantity of hormone produced is directly related to the size of the placenta, such that as the placenta grows during gestation, hPL secretion increases.

Option D: As much as 1 g/day of hPL can be secreted late in gestation- The amount of hPL secreted is proportional to placental size, and by late pregnancy, up to 1 g/day can be produced.

questions.text: A female patient with no relevant past or medication history presents to you with a rash on the cheeks and nose, oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. Investigations showed low serum complement level. Antibody testing for which of the following is least likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The antibody test least likely to be positive in this scenario is the anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA). 

ANCAs are a group of autoantibodies involved in noninfectious vasculitis, such as microscopic polyangiitis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. They are useful diagnostic markers and can also be used to predict disease recurrence. The two most important ANCAs are anti-proteinase 3 and anti-myeloperoxidase.

SLE is an autoimmune disease that is seen more commonly in women. The abnormal immune response leads to the production of various forms of nucleic acids, proteins, and self-antigens. This, in turn, leads to the production of autoantibodies. In most cases, autoantibodies can be detected years before the start of clinical symptoms. The antibody deposition is then followed by complement-mediated destruction, resulting in tissue damage.

The most common rash seen in SLE is a slightly elevated, photosensitive rash seen around the cheeks and nose (butterfly rash). A few other clinical features include oral ulcers, non-scarring alopecia, and synovitis involving more than two joints. Some immunological features include ANA values more than reference negative values, the presence of Anti-Smith antibodies, low serum complement level, and positive direct Coombs test. 

The presence of at least four criteria with one from each category is a must for diagnosis of SLE, according to the 2012 Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinics (SLICC) classification system. 

Other options: 

Option A: The presence of anti-nuclear antibodies is the best screening test for SLE. It is seen in 98% of the cases. Repeated negative tests help to rule out the diagnosis. It has high sensitivity but poor specificity for SLE. 

Option B: Anti-ds DNA antibodies are seen in 70% of the cases. High titers are SLE specific. In a few patients, it indicates disease activity, nephritis, and vasculitis.

Option C: Anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE. It is seen more commonly in blacks and Asians than in whites.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmologist with complaints of poor night vision for the past few weeks. The child is  obese and has polydactyly in both his hands . The child also low IQ and has speech difficulties. Given below is his fundus picture. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The fundus picture has a bony spicule pattern of pigmentation of the retinal periphery, as seen in retinitis pigmentosa. This with the background of polydactyly, obesity, learning disabilities, and speech disorder is suggestive of Bardet–Biedl syndrome.

Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome (LMBBS), is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. The major features of this syndrome are cone-rod dystrophy, polydactyly, obesity, learning disabilities, hypogonadism in males, renal anomalies, nystagmus, speech disorders, developmental delay, polyuria/polydipsia, ataxia, and poor coordination/clumsiness.

Systemic associations with pigmentary retinal dystrophy:

Usher syndrome (Most common) Sensorineural deafness + RP
Bardet–Biedl syndrome (Previously called Lawrence–Moon–Biedl–Bartum Syndrome)  Polydactyly, obesity, mental handicap, hypogonadism and kidney disease + RP
Kearn–Sayre syndrome Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia with ptosis + RP
Refsum Syndrome Varied skin as well as neurological and visceral features + RP
Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome Abetalipoproteinemia and acanthocytosis + RP
Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) Neuropathy and Ataxia + RP

questions.text: The forensic examiner during the practical examination shows you 2 sets of the pelvic bones and asks you to pick the female pelvis. Observing which of the following features in a pelvis would make you not to choose that pelvis?
questions.solution:
All of the above features are seen in the female pelvis except the V-shaped sub-pubic angle, which is a feature of the male pelvis.

The male pelvis has a sub-pubic angle of 70-75 degrees, and the female pelvis has a sub-pubic angle of 90-100 degrees.
