questions.text: A young man with history of injury to his thigh and knee, came with complaints of instability of knee joint while standing. On examination, the locking of knee joint was affected. On X-ray, lateral displacement of the patella was noted. Injury to which of the following muscle can be suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient with the instability of locking of the knee joint and lateral displacement of the patella, an injury to the vastus medialis muscle can be suspected.

Locking of the knee is the medial rotation of the femur on the tibia during the later stages of extension. When standing, the knee joint is locked into position to reduce the amount of muscle work needed to maintain the standing position. The muscle responsible for locking is vastus medialis.

The image given below shows the locking of the knee joint on standing.

Unlocking of the knee joint is the lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia during the beginning of flexion. This is brought by the action of the popliteus muscle (option B)

The lowest fibers of the vastus medialis muscle, which are attached medially to the upper half of the patella, are referred to as vastus medialis obliquus. The primary function of the vastus medialis obliquus muscle is to stabilize the patella against the lateral pull of the vastus lateralis (Option A); hence weakness of vastus lateralis may cause medial displacement, not lateral. The weakness of the vastus medialis obliquus may cause patellar instability, leading to lateral displacement of the patella.

Rectus femoris (option C) primarily aids in knee extension and flexion of hip joint. No role in patellar stabilization.

questions.text: The toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae strains is mediated by the organism shown below. What is not a special feature of this  group of organisms?

choices.text: It is used as vector in recombinant DNA technology
Cosmids have DNA sequences of this organism inserted in them
This organism is responsible for gene transfer by transformation
It is used for typing various bacterial strains

questions.solution:
The given image shows a bacteriophage virus. Gene transfer by transformation is not a special feature of this group of organisms. The tox gene in Diphtheria is mediated by a bacteriophage virus(Beta phage). Bacteriophages are responsible for gene transfer in bacteria by transduction, not transformation. 

Bacteriophages are special viruses that infect bacteria. They are composed of a protein coat that usually encloses a linear DNA genome. Bacteriophages have a variety of shapes, including spheres, rods, and filaments. Bacteriophages have two phases in their life cycles, Lytic and Lysogenic.

The lytic phase is as follows:

  • The five steps of the lytic phase are attachment, penetration, replication, assembly (or maturation), and release (or burst)
  • Bacteriophages infect bacteria by attaching to the surface of the bacterial cell
  • They then inject their DNA into the cell
  • The phage genome then takes over the cell's machinery and forces it to produce new phages
  • The new phages then burst out of the cell, destroying it in the process

The lysogenic phase is different in that the bacteriophage DNA is incorporated into the cell’s DNA and replicates along with it for multiple cycles without destroying the cell. This is termed lysogenic conversion of the bacterium. Lysogenic conversion of bacteria can produce new characteristics in the bacterium. For example, the phage mediating toxicity in Diphtheria infects the bacterium and confers toxin-producing ability to it.

Transduction is a method of genetic transfer that occurs in bacteria infected by phage viruses. DNA copying and incorporation into the new phages produced in a lytic cycle is not a perfect process, and some of the bacterial genomes may be incorporated and transferred along with the phage. This is the basis of transduction. This transferred genome may be generalized or restricted to specific fragments. An image depicting gene transfer by transduction is shown below:

Other Options:

Option A: Phages are extensively used in recombinant DNA technology due to their ability to transfer genetic material and assimilate with other cells.  The specific DNA sequence to be cloned is inserted into the phage, and it is allowed to undergo a lytic cycle to produce multiple copies of chimeric DNA containing the target DNA.

Option B: Cosmids are hybrid plasmids containing cos sites (DNA sequences from lambda phage) and used in recombinant DNA technology. Due to the removal of much of the unnecessary lambda DNA, they can package more chimeric DNA (35-50 kb long inserts) into the particle head. The below image shows the DNA of interest being transferred using a cosmid into bacterial cells for production of more copies.

Option D: Bacteriophages may also be used for phage typing, which is a special method for the identification of bacteria based on the specificity of phage-bacterium interactions. It has been used for the organism's strain identification in Salmonella, Brucella, and Corynebacterium.

B: Botulinum toxin C & D

C: Cholera toxin

D: Diphtheria toxin

E: E.coli(EHEC): Verocytotoxin (Shiga-like toxin)

questions.text: A 60-year-old post-operative patient is kept in an isolation room with a ventilation system that actively pushes in filtered air, reducing airborne contamination. This method of ventilation is best described as:
questions.solution:
The best description of this ventilation system is plenum ventilation, as the room is designed to actively push in filtered air, creating a cleaner and safer environment for a postoperative patient.

Plenum ventilation is a system in which filtered air is actively pushed into a room under positive pressure to reduce the risk of airborne contamination. This method is commonly used in settings where maintaining a sterile or controlled environment is critical, such as operating rooms, isolation rooms for immunocompromised patients, and clean rooms in hospitals and laboratories.

In this system, the air is filtered (often using HEPA filters) before being introduced into the room. The room is maintained under positive pressure, meaning that air flows out of the room when doors are opened, preventing contaminated air from entering. It helps protect postoperative or immunocompromised patients from infections by minimizing airborne pathogens.

Other options:

Option A: In the exhaust ventilation system, air is pulled out rather than pushed in. It is typically used in negative pressure rooms for isolating patients with infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis) to prevent airborne pathogens from spreading.

Option C: Balanced ventilation system equalizes the amount of air coming in and going out. It does not create positive pressure, so it is less effective in controlling airborne contamination.

Option D: Air conditioning controls temperature and humidity but does not necessarily filter or pressurize air.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old male who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the bile duct was injured. The area of injury is shown in the image below. Which type of bile duct injury does this belong to, according to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injuries?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bile leak from the main bile duct without any major tissue loss. According to Strasberg’s classification, the image given belongs to type D bile duct injury.

Biliary injury may occur post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.

MRCP is the gold standard for evaluating the biliary tree's morphology completely. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. An HIDA scan can confirm the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction. The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define these injuries by location:

  • Type A: Bile leak from cystic duct stump or a minor biliary radical in the gallbladder fossa
  • Type B: Occluded right posterior sectoral duct
  • Type C: Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct
  • Type D: Bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss
  • Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury
    • E1: Transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2cm from the hilus
    • E2: Transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2cm from the hilus
    • E3: Stricture of the hilus with right and left ducts in communication
    • E4: Stricture of the hilus with separation of right and left hepatic ducts
    • E5: Stricture of the right aberrant sectoral duct and the main bile duct

For an unstable patient, temporary external biliary drainage is achieved by passing a catheter percutaneously into an intrahepatic duct. When the condition improves, definitive surgery can be undertaken. The main principle of surgery is to maintain the duct length and the restoration of biliary drainage.
